choices.text: To manage and fund the operation of the AWC, including salaries and infrastructure.
To supervise the functioning of the AWC and facilitate its role in improving the nutritional status of women and children.
To staff the AWC with qualified medical professionals for direct healthcare provision.
To establish new AWCs in villages that do not have one.

questions.text: In the context of the Village Health, Sanitation and Nutrition Committee (VHSNC), which of the following is the primary responsibility regarding the Anganwadi Centre (AWC) in the village?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To supervise the functioning of the AWC andfacilitate its role in improving the nutritional status of women and children.

 

  • The VHSNC is responsible for supervising and ensuring the functioning of the Anganwadi Centre (AWC) in the village. 
  • It facilitates the AWC's role in improving nutrition and overall health for women and children, particularly by working alongside other health service providers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To manage and fund the operation of the AWC, including salaries and infrastructure: Incorrect. The VHSNC does not manage or fund the AWC, but ensures its functioning within the community.

 

Option C. To staff the AWC with qualified medical professionalsfor direct healthcare provision: Incorrect. AWC staff is typically made up of Anganwadi workers, not directly medical professionals.

 

Option D. To establish new AWCsin villages that do not have one: Incorrect. Establishing AWCs is typically the responsibility of the government and health departments, not the VHSNC.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The VHSNC supervises the functioning of the AWC to improve nutrition and health outcomes for women and children in the village.

choices.text: Prescribe a weeklong course of ciprofloxacin
Reassure the patient and administer ceftriaxone

questions.text:
An 18-year-old nulliparous woman, Priya from Mumbai, presents with concerns about a gonorrheal infection after being notified by her boyfriend that he tested positive for gonorrhea and negative for chlamydia three days ago. Yesterday, she developed dysuria and foul-smelling vaginal discharge.

 

She has no significant past medical history, but she reports a penicillin allergy after developing a non-pruritic, non-painful rash following amoxicillin use 3 months ago. She denies trouble breathing, dizziness, fever, eye pain, or mouth sores.

 

On examination:

 

  • Purulent discharge from the cervical os
  • No cervical motion tenderness or pelvic pain

 

What is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reassure the patient and administer ceftriaxone

 

This patient has uncomplicated gonococcal cervicitis, requiring ceftriaxone as first-line treatment. Her history suggests a non-severe (likely maculopapular) penicillin allergy, which is not a contraindication to cephalosporins.

 

  • Cephalosporins (e.g., ceftriaxone) have minimal cross-reactivity with penicillins (1%-2%).
  • Life-threatening allergies (anaphylaxis, angioedema, bronchospasm, Stevens-Johnson syndrome) require alternative treatment.
  • A delayed, mild maculopapular rash, as seen in this patient, does not warrant avoidance of cephalosporins.

 

Thus, ceftriaxone can be safely administered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Administer prednisone followed by ceftriaxone: Not required, as the patient’s reaction to penicillin was mild and not IgE-mediated (no anaphylaxis or angioedema).

 

Option B. Perform penicillin skin allergy testing: Not needed in mild delayed reactions like maculopapular rash. Testing is done for patients with unclear or severe allergies (e.g., anaphylaxis).

 

Option C. Prescribe a weeklong course of ciprofloxacin: Fluoroquinolones are not recommended due to high rates of Neisseria gonorrhoeae resistance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with a mild, delayed maculopapular rash after penicillin exposure can safely receive ceftriaxone. 
  • Severe allergic reactions (e.g., anaphylaxis, angioedema, Stevens-Johnson syndrome) warrant alternative treatments.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with a history of acute ischemic stroke is being considered for thrombolytic therapy. Which of the following thrombolytic agents preferentially activates plasminogen bound to fibrin, thereby avoiding systemic fibrinolysis and minimizing bleeding complications?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Alteplase

 

  • Alteplase, a tissue plasminogen activator (tPA), works by preferentially activating plasminogen bound to fibrin at the clot site. 
  • This mechanism helps to break down the clot locally while minimizing systemic fibrinolysis and the associated risk of bleeding.
  •  Alteplase is specifically designed to target fibrin-bound plasminogen, thereby promoting clot dissolution primarily at the site of the thrombus.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Streptokinase: Incorrect. Streptokinase activates plasminogen systemically and does not have the same fibrin-binding specificity as alteplase. This increases the risk of systemic fibrinolysis.
 

Option B. Amino caproic acid: Incorrect. Amino caproic acid is an antifibrinolytic agent that works by inhibiting plasminogen activation, not by promoting it. It is used to prevent bleeding in conditions with excessive fibrinolysis.
 

Option C. Tranexamic acid: Incorrect. Tranexamic acid is also an antifibrinolytic drug that inhibits the binding of plasminogen to fibrin, preventing fibrin degradation. It does not promote plasminogen activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alteplase preferentially activates fibrin-bound plasminogen, minimizing systemic fibrinolysis and reducing bleeding risk, making it a safer option for thrombolytic therapy.

questions.text:
Which of the following are clinical signs of ovulation? 

 

  1. Increase in basal body temperature >0.5°F in the second half of the menstrual cycle.
  2. Progesterone level >5 ng/mL 7 days before menses.
  3. Presence of mittelschmerz.
  4. Elevated estrogen levels during the secretory phase of the cycle.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

Statement 1, 2 and 3- Increase in basal body temperature, elevated progesterone levels, and mittelschmerz are reliable indicators of ovulation. 

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 4- Elevated estrogen during the secretory phase is not a direct indicator of ovulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Indicators of ovulation include basal body temperature increase, progesterone rise, and the presence of mittelschmerz.

choices.text: It acts as a full agonist at the Mu receptors, leading to increased risk of myocardial infarction.
It has opioid antagonist activity at both Kappa and Mu receptors, resulting in a decreased analgesic effect.
It acts as a partial agonist at the Mu receptors and can increase heart rate and blood pressure.
It is a complete opioid antagonist, which causes severe withdrawal symptoms in chronic opioid users.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with chronic pain due to osteoarthritis is prescribed Pentazocine. He is also diagnosed with hypertension and a history of myocardial infarction. Which of the following properties of Pentazocine makes it contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It acts as a partial agonist at the Mu receptors and can increase heart rate and blood pressure.

 

  • Pentazocine is an opioid agonist-antagonist. It acts as a full agonist at the Kappa receptors, but as a partial agonist or antagonist at the Mu receptors.
  •  This partial agonism at Mu receptors can result in increased heart rate and blood pressure, which is why it is contraindicated in patients with a history of myocardial infarction or hypertension.
  •  The increased sympathetic response can exacerbate cardiovascular conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It acts as a full agonist at the Mu receptors, leading to increased risk of myocardial infarction: This is incorrect because Pentazocine is a partial agonist at Mu receptors, not a full agonist.

 

Option B. It has opioid antagonist activity at both Kappa and Mu receptors, resulting in a decreased analgesic effect: This is incorrect. Pentazocine is an agonist at Kappa receptors, which provides analgesia, and has partial agonist or antagonist activity at Mu receptors, but it still has analgesic effects.

 

Option D. It is a complete opioid antagonist, which causes severe withdrawal symptoms in chronic opioid users: This is incorrect. Pentazocine is not a complete antagonist and does not cause withdrawal symptoms in chronic opioid users like full antagonists (e.g., Naloxone) would.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pentazocine is an opioid agonist-antagonist with partial agonist activity at Mu receptors that can increase heart rate and blood pressure, making it contraindicated in patients with a history of myocardial infarction or hypertension.

questions.text: Review the molecular structure provided and classify the characteristic of this amino acid?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Nonpolar aromatic

 

  • The amino acid shown is tryptophan, recognized by its distinctive indole ring structure, which includes a nitrogen atom. 
  • Tryptophan is classified as a nonpolar aromatic amino acid due to its largely hydrophobic indole side chain, which tends to avoid water and participate in hydrophobic interactions rather than forming hydrogen bonds typically associated with polar molecules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Uncharged polar aliphatic: Incorrect. Tryptophan is not aliphatic; it contains a complex ring structure which is aromatic.

 

Option B. Charged polar aromatic: Incorrect. Tryptophan is typically uncharged at physiological pH and does not fall into the category of charged amino acids.

 

Option D. Uncharged polar aromatic: Incorrect. Tryptophan lacks a hydroxyl or significant polar group.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Tryptophan is a nonpolar aromatic amino acid due to the presence of indole ring, which influences its behavior in protein structures and interactions within biological systems.

questions.text: Which blood pressure value classifies as severe preeclampsia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 160/110 mm Hg

 

  • Severe preeclampsia is defined as systolic BP ≥ 160 mm Hg or diastolic BP ≥ 110 mm Hg.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A , B and D. 140/90 mm Hg, and 150/100 mm Hg and 145/95 mm Hg:  These values fall under mild preeclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Severe preeclampsia is defined by systolic BP ≥ 160 mm Hg or diastolic BP ≥ 110 mm Hg, with or without significant end-organ involvement.

choices.text: Increased intracranial pressure is a relative contraindication
Memory disturbance is the most common side effect
Cardiovascular monitoring is essential during the procedure

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Electroconvulsive Therapy (ECT)?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pregnancy is an absolute contraindication

 

  • Electroconvulsive therapy (ECT) is a highly effective treatment for severe depression, catatonia, treatment-resistant schizophrenia, and bipolar disorder. 
  • It is not absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy and is actually considered safe for pregnant patients with severe psychiatric illness, as it does not harm the fetus when properly monitored.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Increased intracranial pressure is a relative contraindication: While increased intracranial pressure (ICP) is a relative contraindication due to the potential risk of further elevating ICP, ECT can still be performed in carefully selected cases with appropriate monitoring.

 

Option B. Memory disturbance is the most common side effect: The most frequent side effect of ECT is transient memory disturbance, which includes anterograde and retrograde amnesia. While anterograde amnesia typically resolves within weeks, retrograde amnesia (especially for events near the time of treatment) may persist longer.

 

Option D. Cardiovascular monitoring is essential during the procedure: ECT can cause acute cardiovascular changes, such as transient hypertension, tachycardia, or arrhythmias, making cardiovascular monitoring essential throughout the procedure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There is no absolute contraindication for ECT.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and the Reason explains the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason does not explain the Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.
Assertion is false, but Reason is true.

questions.text:
Assertion: Propionibacterium acnes is involved in acne vulgaris pathogenesis.

 

Reason: Follicular hyperkeratosis in Acne vulgaris is primarily due to abnormal keratinocyte activity.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reason are true, but the Reason does not explain the Assertion.

 

  • Propionibacterium acnes is a key player in acne pathogenesis, but its primary role is the release of inflammatory mediators, not causing hyperkeratosis. 
  • Follicular hyperkeratosis is primarily due to abnormal keratinocyte activity influenced by hormones and other factors.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Propionibacterium acnes contributes to inflammation in acne vulgaris, but follicular hyperkeratosis results from keratinocyte activity and other factors.

choices.text: External cephalic version at the time of labor

questions.text: What is the recommended mode of delivery for a term singleton fetus in breech presentation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cesarean section

 

  • A planned cesarean section is generally recommended for a term singleton breech fetus to reduce neonatal morbidity and mortality.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vaginal breech delivery: Vaginal breech delivery may be considered in certain cases with experienced practitioners but is not the first choice.

 

Option C. Forceps delivery: Forceps are not typically used in breech presentations.

 

Option D. External cephalic version at the time of labor:  External cephalic version is attempted before labor but not during active labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery for a term breech fetus to ensure neonatal safety.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female with no skin lesions but nasal MRSA colonization is prescribed mupirocin nasal ointment and chlorhexidine gel. How long should she use this combination therapy to effectively decolonize MRSA?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 5 days

 

  • The standard duration for MRSA decolonization therapy using nasal mupirocin 2% and chlorhexidine gel wash is 5 days. 
  • This regimen is recommended for both nasal carriers without skin lesions and those at high risk of transmission.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • MRSA decolonization with nasal mupirocin and chlorhexidine gel wash should be done for 5 days.

choices.text: The most common site of abscess formation in supine patients is the pelvic cavity.
The investigation of choice for confirming a pelvic abscess is ultrasonography.
Pigtail catheter drainage is the preferred treatment for pelvic abscesses.
Morrison’s pouch is the most common site of abscess formation in ambulatory patients.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presents with fever, chills, and rigors on postoperative day 8 following a total abdominal hysterectomy. She reports lower abdominal pain, and examination reveals tenderness in the lower abdomen. A CT scan is performed, revealing a collection in the pelvis consistent with an abscess. Which of the following statements regarding intra-abdominal abscess management is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pigtail catheter drainage is the preferred treatment for pelvic abscesses.

 

  • Pigtail catheter drainage is the recommended treatment for pelvic abscesses, allowing minimally invasive drainage and effective management of the collection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The most common site of abscess formation in supine patients is the pelvic cavity: Incorrect. In supine patients, Morrison’s pouch (hepatorenal recess) is the most common site of abscess formation.

 

Option B. The investigation of choice for confirming a pelvic abscess is ultrasonography: Incorrect. The investigation of choice for pelvic abscess is contrast-enhanced CT (CECT), which provides better localization and characterization of the collection.

 

Option D. Morrison’s pouch is the most common site of abscess formation in ambulatory patients: Incorrect. In ambulatory patients, the pelvic cavity is the most common site for abscess formation due to gravity-dependent pooling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pelvic abscesses are commonly diagnosed using contrast-enhanced CT and effectively managed with pigtail catheter drainage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient is presenting with chief complains of tingling and numbness in lateral 3 & 1/2 fingers. Tinel’s sign and Phalen’s test are positive. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Carpal tunnel syndrome

 

  • Carpal Tunnel Syndrome is caused by compression of the median nerve as it passes through the carpal tunnel in the wrist. 
  • The tingling and numbness in the lateral 3 and 1/2 fingers is a classic symptom of CTS because the median nerve supplies sensation to these fingers.
  • Tinel’s sign (tapping over the carpal tunnel causing tingling) and Phalen's test (holding the wrists in full flexion for 30-60 seconds to provoke symptoms) are common positive tests for CTS.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ulnar nerve compression: Ulnar nerve compression (often at the elbow or at the wrist, near Guyon's canal) causes symptoms like numbness and tingling in the medial 1 and 1/2 fingers (i.e., the little finger and half of the ring finger).

 

Option B. Pronator teres syndrome: Pronator Teres Syndrome is a condition caused by compression of the median nerve at the elbow, as it passes through the pronator teres muscle. Symptoms can include numbness, tingling, and sometimes weakness in the forearm and hand, but the sensation typically involves the lateral 3 and 1/2 fingers. However, the classic signs of Pronator Teres Syndrome do not include positive Phalen’s test or Tinel's sign at the wrist, which are more indicative of Carpal Tunnel Syndrome.

 

Option D. De Quervain's Tenosynovitis: De Quervain’s Tenosynovitis involves inflammation of the tendons and their sheaths on the thumb side of the wrist (the first dorsal compartment). It typically causes pain and swelling near the base of the thumb, especially with activities involving gripping or twisting. This condition would not typically cause tingling or numbness in the fingers, and it would not produce positive results for Tinel’s sign or Phalen’s test (which are specific to nerve compression, not tendon issues).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most likely experience in Carpal Tunnel Syndrome (CTS) is tingling and numbness in the lateral 3 and 1/2 fingers (indicative of median nerve involvement), along with positive Tinel’s sign and Phalen’s test that support compression of the median nerve at the wrist.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of herpes simplex virus infection develops acyclovir-resistant herpes. Her physician decides to switch her therapy. Which of the following antiviral agents would be most effective in treating acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus infections, given its mechanism of action independent of viral thymidine kinase?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Foscarnet

 

  • Foscarnet is effective in treating acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus infections because it directly inhibits viral DNA polymerase, bypassing the need for activation by thymidine kinase, the enzyme typically required by acyclovir.
  •  Foscarnet's activity is not affected by thymidine kinase mutations, making it the preferred treatment for resistant strains.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Cidofovir: Incorrect. Cidofovir is primarily used to treat CMV infections and is less effective in treating acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus infections.
 

Option B. Ganciclovir: Incorrect. Ganciclovir is used to treat CMV and has some activity against herpes viruses, but it is not first-line for acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex.
 

Option D. Valacyclovir: Incorrect. Valacyclovir is a prodrug of acyclovir and would not be effective in acyclovir-resistant herpes infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Foscarnet inhibits DNA polymerase and is effective against acyclovir-resistant herpes simplex virus by bypassing thymidine kinase dependence.

questions.text: From where does the fiber bundle marked with an arrow (A) in the following cut section of brain originate?
questions.solution:
Ans B) Amygdala

 

  • The fiber bundle marked in the image represents the stria terminalis, which originates from the amygdala.  
  • The stria terminalis is a major output pathway of the amygdala that connects it to the hypothalamus, particularly the anterior hypothalamus and septal nuclei. 
  • It plays a role in emotional and autonomic regulation.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hippocampus: The hippocampus primarily gives rise to the fornix, which connects it to the mammillary bodies and the septal nuclei. The stria terminalis is not associated with the hippocampus.

 

Option C. Mammillary bodies: These structures are primarily connected to the hippocampus via the fornix and do not give rise to the stria terminalis.

 

Option D. Insular cortex: The insular cortex is involved in functions such as taste perception and emotional responses but does not contribute fibers to the stria terminalis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The stria terminalis is a major output pathway of the amygdala, connecting it to the hypothalamus and septal nuclei. 
  • It plays a key role in the regulation of emotions and autonomic responses.

choices.text: Initiate ORS therapy at 5 mL/kg/hour immediately.
Administer 100 mL/kg of Ringer’s lactate over 6 hours.
Administer intravenous antibiotics and continue ORS.
Provide oral rehydration only after 12 hours of IV fluids.

questions.text: An 11-month-old child presents to the ER with 12 episodes of watery diarrhea, sunken eyes, and reduced skin turgor. The child is lethargic, with a pulse rate of 130/min and capillary refill >2 seconds. What is the most appropriate management based on WHO IMNCI guidelines?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Administer 100 mL/kg of Ringer’s lactate over 6 hours.

 

  • WHO IMNCI guidelines recommend 100 mL/kg Ringer’s lactate or normal saline over 6 hours for children under 12 months with severe dehydration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Initiate ORS therapy at 5 mL/kg/hour immediately: Incorrect as ORS alone is inadequate for severe dehydration.

 

Option C. Administer intravenous antibiotics and continue ORS: Antibiotics are not required unless there are signs of infection.

 

Option D. Provide oral rehydration only after 12 hours of IV fluids: ORS should be started immediately if the child can drink, alongside IV fluids.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Severe dehydration in children requires immediate fluid resuscitation with 100 mL/kg of IV fluids over 6 hours.

choices.text: Located between 5 cm and 1 cm above GE junction
Located between 2 cm above and 1 cm below GE junction
Located between 1 cm above and 2 cm below GE junction
Located between 1 cm above and 1 cm below GE junction

questions.text: In Siewert’s classification of gastroesophageal (GE) junction tumors, which description corresponds to a true GE junction tumor?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Located between 1 cm above and 2 cm below GE junction

 

  • Siewert’s classification of GE junction tumors (adenocarcinomas):
  • Siewert type 2 are true GE junction tumors. 
  • Siewert type 2 tumors, which are considered true GE junction tumors, are located within 1 cm above to 2 cm below the GE junction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Tumors located between 1 cm above and 2 cm below the GE junction are classified as Siewert type 2 and are considered true GE junction tumors.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with chronic ear discharge, hearing loss, and dizziness. On otoscopic examination, image seen is as below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cholesteatoma

 

  • The image shows a retracted TM with keratin debris in the attic region, characteristic of cholesteatoma. Chronic discharge and hearing loss further support the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Otitis Media: Incorrect as acute otitis media typically presents with fever and acute onset of symptoms without keratin debris.

 

Option B. Otitis Externa: Incorrect as otitis externa involves pain with pinna manipulation and external canal inflammation.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma: Incorrect as vestibular schwannoma involves sensorineural hearing loss and would not show changes on TM examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize cholesteatoma from its characteristic presentation of retracted TM, keratin debris, and chronic symptoms.

questions.text: Match the ASA (American Society of Anesthesiologists) grading with their respective descriptions.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B

 

  • 1-C: ASA II represents a mild systemic disease like asthma without functional limitations.
  • 2-D: ASA III involves moderate systemic disease with functional limitations, such as CKD or CLD.
  • 3-A: ASA IV includes patients with severe systemic disease posing a constant threat to life, like unstable angina or recent myocardial infarction.
  • 4-B: ASA V includes moribund patient not expected to survive 24 hrs

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • ASA grading is a crucial risk stratification tool used preoperatively to assess anesthetic and surgical risks.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man, Ramesh from Mumbai, is admitted for acute alcoholic pancreatitis. His APACHE II score of 20 indicates severe disease.

 

Over 48 hours, he has received 10 liters of IV fluids, but his condition has deteriorated:

 

  • Respiratory failure → Intubated, on high PEEP and FiO₂
  • Rising creatinine (from 1.2 mg/dL to 2.2 mg/dL) and decreased urine output
  • Elevated JVP, bilateral lung crackles, tense abdominal distension, and pitting edema
  • Abdomen: Diffusely tender, diminished bowel sounds
  • Urinalysis: Normal, ruling out intrinsic renal causes (e.g., glomerulonephritis, hematuria, pyuria, or casts)

 

What is the best next step to establish the cause of AKI?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Measurement of bladder pressure

 

  • The patient presents with acute kidney injury (AKI) in the setting of severe pancreatitis and massive fluid resuscitation, along with abdominal distension and oliguria, strongly suggesting abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS).

 

Key Features Suggesting ACS:

 

  • Massive IV fluid resuscitation → Third spacing, leading to increased intra-abdominal pressure
  • Oliguria with rising creatinine
  • Tense abdominal distension, elevated JVP, and pitting edema
  • Bowel dysfunction (diminished bowel sounds)
  • Pulmonary dysfunction (worsening hypoxia, bilateral lung crackles)

 

Confirmatory Test:

 

  • Bladder pressure measurement (>25 mmHg confirms ACS)
  • If ACS is confirmed, urgent decompression via paracentesis or surgical decompression is needed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abdominal CT scan

 

  • While CT may show pancreatic necrosis or ascites, it does not diagnose ACS
  • Bladder pressure measurement is the gold standard for diagnosis

 

Option B. Fractional Excretion of Sodium (FeNa)

 

  • FeNa is useful to differentiate prerenal vs. intrinsic AKI, but it does not diagnose ACS
  • In ACS, FeNa may be low due to renal compression, but this is not a definitive test

 

Option D. Renal ultrasound

 

  • Useful for ruling out hydronephrosis (obstruction), but not helpful in diagnosing ACS
  • The primary pathology here is extrinsic compression due to elevated intra-abdominal pressure

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Abdominal compartment syndrome (ACS) is a life-threatening cause of AKI in critically ill patients receiving aggressive fluid resuscitation.
  • Diagnosis: Measure bladder pressure (>25 mmHg is diagnostic).
  • Treatment: Immediate decompression (paracentesis or surgery) to prevent permanent organ damage.

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus presents with dyspnea and chest pressure for 6 hours. She is hypotensive (BP 82/62 mmHg), tachycardic (pulse 104/min), and hypoxic (SpO₂ 92% on 15L O₂). She is mildly confused, has distended neck veins, a displaced apical impulse with an S3 heart sound, bilateral crackles in the lungs, and cold extremities with weak pulses. ECG is shown below. 

 

 

What is the best immediate intervention to improve survival?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI)

 

  • This patient has cardiogenic shock due to acute myocardial infarction (AMI), indicated by hypotension, tachycardia, S3 gallop, pulmonary congestion, cold extremities, and new left bundle branch block (LBBB)—a STEMI equivalent. 
  • Urgent PCI is the most effective intervention to restore coronary perfusion and improve survival.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intra-aortic balloon pump insertion: Provides temporary support but does not treat the underlying coronary occlusion.

 

Option B. Milrinone infusion: Can worsen hypotension in cardiogenic shock due to its vasodilatory effect.

 

Option C. Norepinephrine infusion: Supports blood pressure but does not fix the primary issue of myocardial ischemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In cardiogenic shock due to AMI, early PCI is the most critical intervention for survival.

choices.text: Insulin resistance due to worsening renal function
Increased hepatic clearance of sulfonylurea due to renal insufficiency

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with type 2 diabetes and renal insufficiency is started on glibenclamide for blood glucose control. After 2 weeks, he presents with symptoms of hypoglycemia, including dizziness, sweating, and confusion. What is the most likely reason for his hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Impaired renal clearance of glibenclamide

 

  • In patients with renal insufficiency, the clearance of sulfonylureas, including glibenclamide, is significantly reduced. 
  • This leads to an accumulation of the drug in the body, increasing the risk of hypoglycemia. 
  • Sulfonylureas stimulate insulin release from the pancreas, and in renal impairment, the drug persists longer than expected, leading to excessive insulin release and low blood glucose levels.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Insulin resistance due to worsening renal function: Incorrect. While renal dysfunction can exacerbate insulin resistance, the hypoglycemia here is more likely due to the prolonged effect of the sulfonylurea.
 

Option C. Drug interaction with antihypertensive medications: Incorrect. While certain antihypertensive medications (e.g., beta-blockers) can mask symptoms of hypoglycemia, they do not cause hypoglycemia directly.
 

Option D. Increased hepatic clearance of sulfonylurea due to renal insufficiency: Incorrect. Renal insufficiency impairs drug excretion, leading to decreased, not increased, clearance of glibenclamide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Impaired renal clearance of sulfonylureas like glibenclamide in patients with renal insufficiency can lead to hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A 23-year-old cricketer had an avulsion of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon of his ring finger. This was diagnosed early and despite proximal migration, he had it reinserted with a button technique. Six months later, he complains that he can’t close his fingers tightly over a cricket ball. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Quadrigia effect

 

  • The Quadrigia effect occurs when the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon of one finger is injured or repaired, leading to impaired function of the adjacent fingers. 
  • This is especially common after tendon repairs (like the button technique used in this case), where the repair site becomes stiff or weak, and the force of flexion needed to close the fingers is distributed among all the fingers. 
  • Essentially, the force required to flex one finger may now be shared by the others, leading to inability to flex the fingers tightly. 
  • The cricketer's complaint that he cannot close his fingers tightly over a cricket ball fits this scenario.
  • The issue with gripping is most likely due to the altered biomechanics following the tendon repair of his FDP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lumbrical Plus Effect: The Lumbrical Plus effect occurs when the lumbrical muscles, which normally help flex the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and extend the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints, become overly active due to an injury or dysfunction. This leads to hyperextension of the PIP joint and difficulty in flexing the finger properly. This is often seen after flexor tendon injuries and can cause issues with finger function. However, the cricketer's issue is more related to grip strength and the ability to close the hand tightly, which is not typical of the Lumbrical Plus effect.

 

Option B. Swan Neck Deformity: A Swan Neck deformity is characterized by hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint. It is usually caused by damage to the central slip of the extensor mechanism or ligamentous injuries. This deformity often results in difficulty with gripping or flexing the fingers because the PIP joint is stuck in hyperextension. An avulsion of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon, primarily affects finger flexion at the DIP joint, not the extensor mechanism that causes a Swan Neck deformity.

 

Option D. Intrinsic Tightness: Intrinsic tightness refers to tightness of the intrinsic hand muscles, such as the lumbricals and interossei. These muscles are responsible for fine motor control and finger positioning, and tightness or shortening of these muscles can lead to difficulty in flexing the fingers fully or may cause contractures that impede proper hand function. Intrinsic tightness typically occurs in conditions like Dupuytren's contracture or after nerve injury. Intrinsic tightness does not explain the difficulty with grip related to the tendon repair.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The complaint of not being able to close fingers tightly is most consistent with the Quadrigia effect, which happens after tendon repairs, especially of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon, leading to difficulty in flexing the fingers due to altered force distribution across all fingers.

questions.text:
Regarding the contents of the Suprasternal space of burns, which of the following statements are correct?

 

  1. The suprasternal space contains the jugular venous arch formed by the anterior jugular veins.
  2. The suprasternal space contains the external jugular vein.
  3. The interclavicular ligament is part of the contents of the suprasternal space.
  4. The sternal head of the sternocleidomastoid (SCM) is a content of the suprasternal space.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 3 and 4

 

Statement 1: Correct. The jugular venous arch formed by the anterior jugular veins is present in the suprasternal space.

 

Statement 3: Correct. The interclavicular ligament is part of the contents of the suprasternal space.

 

Statement 4: Correct. The sternal head of the sternocleidomastoid muscle forms part of the boundary and content of the suprasternal space.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 2: Incorrect. The external jugular vein is located in the supraclavicular space, not the suprasternal space.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The suprasternal space of Burns contains the jugular venous arch, interclavicular ligament, and sternal head of the SCM, but does not include the external jugular vein, which is located in the supraclavicular space.

questions.text:
A premature infant is diagnosed with retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). The following fundus findings are noted during progression of the disease. Arrange them in the correct order of occurrence: 

 

a) Partial retinal detachment
b) Demarcation line
c) Elevated ridge
d) Total retinal detachment
e) Extraretinal neovascularization extending into vitreous
questions.solution:
Ans. A) b, c, e, a, d

 

  • Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) progresses through several stages. The fundus findings occur in the following order:
    • Demarcation line (b): The earliest sign in ROP, marking the boundary between the vascularized and avascular retina.
    • Elevated ridge (c): As the disease progresses, the demarcation line becomes elevated, indicating more severe retinal changes.
    • Extraretinal neovascularization extending into vitreous (e): New blood vessels form at the ridge and extend into the vitreous, which is characteristic of more advanced ROP.
    • Partial retinal detachment (a): This is a later stage, where the retina starts detaching partially.
    • Total retinal detachment (d): In the final stage, the retina detaches completely, leading to vision loss if untreated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In retinopathy of prematurity, the correct order of progression of fundus findings is: Demarcation line → Elevated ridge → Extraretinal neovascularization extending into vitreous → Partial retinal detachment → Total retinal detachment.

questions.text:
Which of the following bacterial toxins are most likely responsible for inhibiting protein synthesis?

 

  1. Pertussis
  2. Cholera
  3. Pseudomonas
  4. Diphtheria
  5. Shiga toxin
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 3, 4 and 5

 

  • The patient's presentation of protein synthesis inhibition suggests exposure to bacterial toxins that directly disrupt the ribosomal machinery. The following toxins are known to inhibit protein synthesis:
  • 3. Pseudomonas exotoxin A (produced by Pseudomonas aeruginosa) inactivates elongation factor 2 (EF-2) by ADP-ribosylation, halting protein synthesis. This mechanism is shared with several other toxins that target EF-2.
  • 4. Diphtheria toxin (produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae) also inactivates EF-2, effectively inhibiting protein synthesis in eukaryotic cells.
  • 5. Shiga toxin (produced by Shigella dysenteriae) cleaves the 28S rRNA of the ribosome, leading to a cessation of protein synthesis.

 

Other Options:
 

1 and 2: The Pertussis toxin (produced by Bordetella pertussis) and Cholera toxin (produced by Vibrio cholerae) work by increasing cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels in cells, which disrupts cellular signaling and causes other systemic effects but does not directly inhibit protein synthesis. Therefore, these toxins are not included in the answer.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Pseudomonas exotoxin A, Diphtheria toxin, and Shiga toxin are bacterial toxins that directly inhibit protein synthesis by targeting elongation factors or the ribosome, leading to cellular dysfunction.

choices.text: People with respiratory issues are advised to avoid prolonged outdoor activity.
Healthy individuals may experience mild irritation, but sensitive groups should take precautions.
The air quality is good for all individuals, including those with respiratory issues.
All individuals, including those with respiratory conditions, should avoid outdoor activities.

questions.text: A city reports an AQI value of 350. Based on this value, which of the following health advisories would most likely apply to the general population?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All individuals, including those with respiratory conditions, should avoid outdoor activities.

 

  • An AQI value of 350 falls in the "Very Poor" category, indicating severe air pollution. 
  • This level can cause significant health effects in the general population, especially those with pre-existing respiratory conditions. 
  • Hence, the advisory suggests avoiding outdoor activity for all individuals.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. People with respiratory issues are advised to avoid prolonged outdoor activity: Incorrect, as the AQI is much higher, indicating more severe risks.

 

Option B. Healthy individuals may experience mild irritation, but sensitive groups should take precautions: Incorrect, as the air quality is too poor for healthy individuals to engage in outdoor activities.

 

Option C. The air quality is good for all individuals, including those with respiratory issues: Incorrect, as the AQI in this range is harmful even for healthy individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • AQI values in the "Very Poor" range (301-400) require all individuals, especially those with respiratory conditions, to avoid outdoor activities due to severe health risks.

choices.text: Deficiency of sphingomyelinase enzyme in tissues
Deficiency of LCAT enzyme in tissues
All of the above are correct

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with complaints of loss of appetite, frequent nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and weight loss for several months. Upon interaction with the physician, the child demonstrates slurred speech and ataxic gait. Clinical examination reveals hepatomegaly and splenomegaly. The child is diagnosed with type B Niemann–Pick disease. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding Niemann–Pick disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deficiency of LCAT enzyme in tissues

 

  • Niemann–Pick disease is a genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of sphingomyelin in tissues due to a deficiency in the sphingomyelinase enzyme. 
  • There are two types of Niemann–Pick disease: Type A and Type B. In Type B, the accumulation of sphingomyelin primarily affects the liver, spleen, and central nervous system. 
  • This leads to clinical manifestations such as hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and neurological symptoms like slurred speech and ataxia, as seen in the child described in the case.
  • The deficiency of LCAT (lecithin-cholesterol acyltransferase) enzyme is associated with Norum’s disease, not Niemann–Pick disease. LCAT deficiency leads to high plasma cholesterol and its accumulation in tissues, causing different symptoms such as corneal opacities and retinopathy, but not the liver, spleen, and neurological involvement seen in Niemann–Pick disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Deficiency of sphingomyelinase enzyme in tissues: Correct. Deficiency of sphingomyelinase enzyme leads to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in tissues, which is the hallmark of Niemann–Pick disease. This results in the symptoms observed in the patient, including hepatomegaly, splenomegaly, and neurological impairments.

 

Option C. Mutations in the SMPD1 gene: Correct. Mutations in the SMPD1 gene result in the absence of sphingomyelinase enzyme. This gene mutation is the primary cause of Niemann–Pick disease type B, as it leads to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in tissues like the liver and spleen.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Niemann–Pick disease is caused by a deficiency of the sphingomyelinase enzyme due to mutations in the SMPD1 gene, leading to the accumulation of sphingomyelin in the liver, spleen, and central nervous system. 
  • It is distinct from LCAT deficiency, which is associated with a different disorder called Norum’s disease.

questions.text: A patient came with clinical picture of Silvery white scaly plaques. Which of the following histological findings is most specific for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Parakeratosis

 

  • The clinical picture points out to the diagnosis of psoriasis. The histological image shows parakeratosis (retained nuclei in the stratum corneum), which is a hallmark of psoriasis.
  • Munro microabscesses (collections of neutrophils in the stratum corneum) further confirm the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spongiosis: Associated with eczematous dermatitis, not psoriasis.

 

Option C. Acantholysis: Indicates keratinocyte detachment in conditions like pemphigus vulgaris.

 

Option D. Hypergranulosis: Refers to thickened granular layer, typical of lichen planus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Parakeratosis with Munro microabscesses is a key histological feature of psoriasis, distinguishing it from other dermatoses.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male is scheduled for an elective cholecystectomy. The surgical team discusses the classification of wounds and associated risks of surgical site infections (SSIs). Which of the following statements regarding wound classification and SSI risk is/are correct?

 

  1. Clean wounds, such as in thyroid surgery, have no role for prophylactic antibiotics unless an implant is placed.
  2. Clean-contaminated wounds involve entry into the GI or GU system without significant inflammation and have an SSI risk of 3–9%.
  3. Contaminated wounds, like emergency appendectomies, carry a higher SSI risk of 20% when prophylactic antibiotics are used.
  4. Dirty wounds, such as abscess drainage, have the highest risk of SSIs, even with prophylactic antibiotics.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

1. Clean wounds, such as in thyroid surgery, have no role for prophylactic antibiotics unless an implant is placed. Prophylactic antibiotics are not typically recommended for clean wounds unless a prosthesis or mesh is used.

 

2. Clean-contaminated wounds involve entry into the GI or GU system without significant inflammation and have an SSI risk of 3–9%.
Clean-contaminated wounds, like elective cholecystectomy, have a moderate risk of infection, which increases with improper antibiotic use.

 

4. Dirty wounds, such as abscess drainage, have the highest risk of SSIs, even with prophylactic antibiotics. Dirty wounds are associated with significant contamination (e.g., abscess, fecal spillage) and a high SSI risk (20–40%) despite antibiotics.

 

Other Option:

 

3. Contaminated wounds, like emergency appendectomies, carry a higher SSI risk of 20% when prophylactic antibiotics are used.
Contaminated wounds have a lower SSI risk (6%) with prophylactic antibiotics, compared to 20% without them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wound classification determines the risk of surgical site infections, with SSI risk increasing from clean to dirty wounds, and prophylactic antibiotics significantly reduce infection rates in contaminated and dirty wounds.

questions.text: The Kaplan-Meier survival curve shown indicates survival over time for two different patient groups, labeled as Gene A signature and Gene B signature. Which of the following statistical methods is most commonly used to assess if the difference between the two survival curves is statistically significant?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Log-rank test

 

  • The log-rank test is used to compare survival distributions between two or more groups based on the Kaplan-Meier survival curve. 
  • It assesses whether the observed differences in survival between the groups (such as Gene A vs. Gene B) are statistically significant.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chi-square test: Incorrect. The Chi-square test is typically used for categorical data comparisons, not survival analysis.

 

Option C. T-test: Incorrect. The T-test compares means between two groups, which is not suitable for survival data.

 

Option D. Wilcoxon signed-rank test: Incorrect. The Wilcoxon signed-rank test is used for paired samples, not for comparing survival curves between two groups.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The log-rank test is the appropriate method for comparing survival curves between different groups, like those with Gene A and Gene B signatures.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic abnormality is most commonly associated with condition as shown in the CT image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C)Trisomy 13

 

  • Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder where the prosencephalon (forebrain) fails to divide into two hemispheres.
  • This results in alobar holoprosencephaly, characterized by a single ventricular cavity and fusion of brain structures, leading to the "pancake" brain appearance on CT scans.
  • The condition is most commonly associated with Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome), a genetic disorder that involves severe malformation of the brain, heart, and other organs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Trisomy 21 (Down Syndrome): Incorrect. Trisomy 21 is associated with structural brain abnormalities such as ventricular dilation, but it does not cause holoprosencephaly.

 

Option B. Trisomy 18 (Edwards Syndrome): Incorrect. Trisomy 18 is associated with congenital anomalies like rocker-bottom feet and micrognathia, but holoprosencephaly is rare.

 

Option D. Turner Syndrome (45, XO):Incorrect. Turner syndrome presents with features like webbed neck, coarctation of the aorta, and short stature, but does not cause holoprosencephaly.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Trisomy 13 (Patau syndrome) is commonly associated with alobar holoprosencephaly, characterized by fusion of the frontal lobes and pancake brain sign on imaging.

choices.text: It is a diagnostic test for chromosomal abnormalities
It has a 99% detection rate for Down syndrome but is limited by placental mosaicism
It can only be performed after 15 weeks of gestation
It is the most cost-effective screening modality for aneuploidy

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman opts for cell-free DNA (cfDNA) screening at 10 weeks’ gestation due to a high-risk result from first-trimester combined screening. Which of the following statements is true regarding cfDNA screening?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It has a 99% detection rate for Down syndrome but is limited by placental mosaicism

 

  • cfDNA screening has a high detection rate (99%) for Down syndrome, but its accuracy may be affected by factors like placental mosaicism, maternal mosaicism, or early demise of an aneuploid twin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a diagnostic test for chromosomal abnormalities: Incorrect. cfDNA is a screening test, not a diagnostic test. Confirmatory testing (CVS or amniocentesis) is required for definitive diagnosis.

 

Option C. It can only be performed after 15 weeks of gestation: Incorrect. cfDNA can be performed as early as 9–10 weeks gestation.

 

Option D. It is the most cost-effective screening modality for aneuploidy: Incorrect. cfDNA is more expensive than first-trimester combined screening or second-trimester quadruple screening.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • cfDNA screening is a non-invasive test with a high detection rate for Down syndrome. 
  • However, confirmatory diagnostic testing is necessary for definitive diagnosis, and limitations like placental mosaicism must be considered.

choices.text: Coronary artery blood flow and ischemia.
Myocardial perfusion during exercise and rest.
Function of the ventricles, particularly the ejection fraction.
Evaluation of valvular function and regurgitation.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with a history of heart failure and chemotherapy for breast cancer is evaluated using a MUGA scan to assess cardiac function. What specific aspect of heart function is primarily evaluated by a MUGA scan?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Function of the ventricles, particularly the ejection fraction.

 

  • A MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan is primarily used to evaluate the function of the ventricles, particularly assessing the ejection fraction, which is critical in the management of heart failure. 
  • This test helps assess the extent of myocardial damage and cardiac dysfunction, especially in patients with a history of chemotherapy (like anthracyclines) that may be cardiotoxic.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Coronary artery blood flow and ischemia: Incorrect. A MUGA scan does not evaluate coronary artery flow but focuses on ventricular function.
 

Option B. Myocardial perfusion during exercise and rest: Incorrect. MUGA scan is used to evaluate ventricular function, not myocardial perfusion during stress.
 

Option D. Evaluation of valvular function and regurgitation: Incorrect. A MUGA scan does not assess valvular function, but instead focuses on ventricular ejection fraction.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The MUGA scan primarily evaluates ventricular function and ejection fraction, which is crucial in diagnosing and managing heart failure.

choices.text: 20 mg of iron and 100 mcg of folic acid, weekly
45 mg of iron and 400 mcg of folic acid, weekly
20 mg of iron and 100 mcg of folic acid, biweekly
40 mg of iron and 400 mcg of folic acid, biweekly

questions.text: A 4-year-old child presents to the clinic for routine health check-up. The healthcare provider recommends supplementation with iron and folic acid as part of the child’s nutrition plan. What is the correct frequency and dosage of supplementation for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 20 mg of iron and 100 mcg of folic acid, biweekly

 

  • For children aged 6-59 months, the appropriate dosage of iron is 20 mg and folic acid is 100 mcg, with supplementation occurring biweekly. 
  • This schedule helps in the prevention of iron deficiency anemia and ensures adequate folic acid levels during the early years of life.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
Which of the following combinations regarding ERAS protocol is correct?

 

  1. Mechanical bowel preparation should be avoided
  2. Early ambulation within 24 hours
  3. Consume clear fluids up to 4 hours prior to surgery
  4. IV fluids are continued until discharge
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 & 2 only

 

Statement 1: Correct - ERAS advocates avoiding mechanical bowel prep

 

Statement 2: Correct - Early ambulation within 24 hours

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 3: False - Consume clear fluids up to 2 hours prior to surgery

 

Statement 4: False - IV fluids should be discontinued within 24 hours

 

Educational Objective: 

 

ERAS Protocol (Enhanced Recovery After Surgery Protocol)

questions.text:
Which of the following combinations is incorrect regarding the characteristics of the stretch reflex?

 

  1. The receptor for the stretch reflex is the muscle spindle.
  2. The afferent nerve fibers involved are Group Ib fibers.
  3. The efferent nerve fibers in the stretch reflex are α-motor neurons.
  4. The stretch reflex is disynaptic
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 4

 

  • Statement 2: The afferent nerve fibers involved are Group Ib fibers: The afferent nerve fibers involved in the stretch reflex are Group Ia and II endings, not Group Ib fibers (these are associated with the inverse stretch reflex).
  • Statement 4: The stretch reflex is disynaptic: The stretch reflex is indeed disynaptic

 

Other Options:

 

  • Statement 1: The receptor for the stretch reflex is the muscle spindle: This is correct as the receptor for the stretch reflex is indeed the muscle spindle.
  • Statement 3: The efferent nerve fibers in the stretch reflex are α-motor neurons: This is correct since the efferent nerve fibers involved are α-motor neurons, which stimulate the contraction of the muscle.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presented to the clinic with complaints of persistent vertigo and neck pain following a traumatic neck injury. A detailed evaluation was performed, including imaging of the cervical spine, which revealed normal anatomy. Which part of cervical vertebrae lies in relation with the third part of vertebral artery?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Atlas vertebra

 

Parts of atlas (C1) vertebra are shown in the figure

 

 

  • The third part of the vertebral artery, also known as the suboccipital part, extends from the foramen transversarium of the C1 vertebra to the foramen magnum of the skull. 
  • This segment lies within the suboccipital triangle, closely related to the posterior arch of the atlas vertebra.
  • Part A: Represents the anterior tubercle of the atlas, which is unrelated to the vertebral artery.
  • Part B: Indicates the lateral mass of the atlas, primarily articulating with the occipital condyles.
  • Part C: Refers to the posterior arch of the atlas, which is in direct relation to the third part of the vertebral artery as it courses toward the foramen magnum.
  • Part D: Depicts the transverse foramen, which is associated with the second part of the vertebral artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The third part of the vertebral artery (suboccipital part) lies in close relation to the posterior arch of the atlas vertebra (C1) as it travels within the suboccipital triangle toward the foramen magnum.

choices.text: Anal advancement flap is used in repair
Interdigital disease is an occupational disease of hairdressers.
Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine is often seen.
Hair follicles are rarely present in the walls of the sinus.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the condition shown below is incorrect ?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anal advancement flap is used in repair

 

  • Anal advancement flap is used in repair of fistula in ano, not pilonidal sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Interdigital disease is an occupational disease of hairdressers: An interdigital pilonidal sinus can be an occupational disease in hairdressers, caused by chronic embedding of hair fragments between the fingers.

 

Option C. Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine is often seen: Intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine are characteristic symptoms of a pilonidal sinus due to infection and abscess formation.

 

Option D. Hair follicles are rarely present in the walls of the sinus: Hair follicles themselves are not commonly found in the walls of a pilonidal sinus. The condition is associated with ingrown hairs that have created a foreign body reaction in the subcutaneous tissue.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Pilonidal sinus disease is characterized by intermittent pain, swelling, and discharge at the base of the spine and can be associated with occupational risks in hairdressers. 
  • Hair follicles are not commonly found in the walls of the sinus.

choices.text: Superficial branch of the radial nerve

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with tenderness in the region marked in the image. Which of the following structures is not present in this region?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Lunate

 

  • Shown image is anatomical snuff box. 
  • The lunate bone is located more proximally in the carpal region and not present in the anatomical snuffbox. 
  • The anatomical snuffbox contains structures like the radial artery and superficial branch of the radial nerve, but the lunate lies deeper and outside this area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial branch of the radial nerve: This nerve runs along the lateral border of the snuffbox and is palpable. It is easily rolled side to side during examination.

 

Option B. Radial artery: The radial artery lies on the floor of the anatomical snuffbox and can be palpated as a pulsatile structure.

 

Option D. Scaphoid: The scaphoid is one of the three bones that can be palpated in the floor of the snuffbox, along with the trapezium and the base of the first metacarpal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The anatomical snuffbox is a triangular depression located on the posterolateral side of the wrist. 
  • Structures within it include the radial artery, superficial branch of the radial nerve, and the cephalic vein, along with the scaphoid, trapezium, and the base of the first metacarpal bones. 
  • The lunate bone is located more proximally and is not a part of this region.

questions.text: A study on particle behavior in pneumoconiosis reveals that particles in the range of < 1 micron exhibit a specific type of movement that contributes to their inhalation. Which of the following describes this behavior?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Brownian 

 

  • Particles smaller than 1 micron exhibit Brownian movement, which refers to the erratic, random motion caused by the collisions between the particles and gas molecules. 
  • This movement allows particles of this size to remain suspended in the air and easily enter the lungs. 
  • Brownian motion is especially significant in respiratory health because it contributes to the inhalation of particles that may reach the deep parts of the lungs, causing pneumoconiosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vibrational: This refers to the oscillatory motion of atoms or molecules within a solid, which is not applicable to the movement of particles in air.

 

Option B. Translational: This movement involves particles moving in a straight line in one direction, which is not characteristic of particles < 1 micron in size.

 

Option D. Rotational: This involves particles spinning around their axes, which also doesn't apply to particles in the < 1 micron size range, which exhibit random motion instead.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The particle size and behavior related to pneumoconiosis:

choices.text: Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), indicating trisomy 13
Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), indicating trisomy 21

questions.text: A geneticist reviews the results of a cytogenetic analysis from a patient's sample shown in image below, where red signals indicate chromosome 21 and green signals indicate chromosome 13.  Which cytogenetic technique was used to generate this image, and how should it be interpreted?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), indicating trisomy 21

 

  • The technique used in the image is Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), which allows for the visualization of specific chromosomes using fluorescent probes. 
  • In the image, there are three red signals, indicating three copies of chromosome 21, which is diagnostic of trisomy 21, also known as Down syndrome. 
  • The green signals correspond to chromosome 13, and their normal count suggests a typical disomy for chromosome 13.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Karyotyping, indicating trisomy 21: Incorrect. While karyotyping can identify trisomy 21, the technique shown is FISH, not karyotyping.  

 

 

Option B. Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH), indicating trisomy 13: Incorrect. The image does not show an extra chromosome 13; it shows an extra chromosome 21.

 

Option D. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR), indicating monosomy 13: Incorrect. PCR is not used for visualizing chromosome numbers directly and the condition described does not match the image.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Recognize the application of FISH in cytogenetics for the identification of chromosomal abnormalities such as trisomies, by the specific binding of fluorescently labeled probes to distinct chromosomal regions.

choices.text: Invest to end TB. Save Lives.
Yes! We Can End TB: Commit, Invest, Deliver
Wanted: Leaders for a TB-free world.

questions.text: Which of the following themes is adopted for World TB Day in 2025?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) "Yes! We Can End TB: Commit, Invest, Deliver"

 

  • The theme for World TB Day 2025 is "Yes! We Can End TB: Commit, Invest, Deliver." 
  • This theme emphasizes the importance of sustained commitment, financial investment, and the effective delivery of interventions critical to TB prevention, diagnosis, treatment, and care. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It's time to end TB!: "It's time to end TB!" was the theme for World TB Day 2020.

 

Option B. Invest to end TB. Save Lives: "Invest to end TB. Save Lives." was the theme for World TB Day 2022.

 

Option D. Wanted: Leaders for a TB-free world: "Wanted: Leaders for a TB-free world." was the theme for World TB Day 2018.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The theme of World TB Day 2025 is "Yes! We Can End TB: Commit, Invest, Deliver."

choices.text: Degradation of keratin in the nail
Difficulty in extracting DNA from under-nail areas
Lack of forensic laboratories capable of processing nail DNA
The tendency for nails to break easily during postmortem handling

questions.text: In forensic science, which of the following factors most significantly limits the use of nail samples for postmortem identification?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Difficulty in extracting DNA from under-nail areas

 

  • The primary challenge with using nail samples for postmortem identification is the difficulty in extracting DNA from under-nail areas, unless fresh samples are available. 
  • This limits the efficacy of nails as a reliable identification source, especially when other tissue samples are more accessible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Degradation of keratin in the nail: Keratin in nails is durable, but the issue lies more in DNA extraction than keratin degradation.
 

Option C. Lack of forensic laboratories capable of processing nail DNA: Most forensic labs are capable of processing DNA from nails; the problem is the difficulty in obtaining usable DNA.
 

Option D. The tendency for nails to break easily during postmortem handling: While nails may break, this is not the primary issue in DNA identification.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The main limitation of using nails for identification is the difficulty in obtaining sufficient DNA, especially from under-nail areas.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Components of Cell Membrane and Their Functions

 

Column A (Components of cell Membrane)

 

  1. Phosphatidylcholine
  2. Cardiolipin
  3. Cholesterol
  4. Glycolipids

 

Column B (Functions)

 

  1.  Prevents RBC hemolysis and is abundant in the CNS
  2. Exclusive to the human heart in mitochondria and linked to Syphilis
  3. Maintains membrane fluidity and acts as a fluidity buffer
  4. Major component of surfactant
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

1-D: Phosphatidylcholine is the major component of surfactant, essential for reducing surface tension in alveoli.
 

2-B: Cardiolipin is exclusive to the human heart in mitochondria and is implicated in Syphilis (anticardiolipin antibodies).
 

3-C: Cholesterol maintains membrane fluidity and acts as a fluidity buffer, modulating the rigidity of the lipid bilayer.
 

4-A: Glycolipids, including cerebrosides and gangliosides, are abundant in the CNS and GIT, respectively, and help in preventing hemolysis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Phosphatidylcholine is the major component of surfactant, essential for reducing surface tension in alveoli.
  • Cardiolipin is exclusive to the human heart in mitochondria and is implicated in Syphilis (anticardiolipin antibodies).
  • Cholesterol maintains membrane fluidity and acts as a fluidity buffer, modulating the rigidity of the lipid bilayer.
  • Glycolipids, including cerebrosides and gangliosides, are abundant in the CNS and GIT, respectively, and help in preventing hemolysis.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Hormone and their Receptors Categories

 

Column A: Hormones

  1. Insulin
  2. Thyroid hormone
  3. Glucocorticoid
  4. Growth hormone

 

Column B: Receptor Type

  1. Intracellular nuclear receptor
  2. Receptor tyrosine kinase
  3. Cytoplasmic receptor
  4. Cytokine receptor family
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • Insulin (1-B): Insulin binds to receptor tyrosine kinase, leading to intracellular signaling cascades.
  • Thyroid hormone (2-A): Thyroid hormones utilize intracellular nuclear receptors for gene regulation.
  • Glucocorticoid (3-C): Glucocorticoids bind to cytoplasmic receptors, translocating to the nucleus.
  • Growth hormone (4-D): Growth hormone acts via cytokine receptor family through the JAK-STAT pathway.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Insulin: Insulin binds to receptor tyrosine kinase, leading to intracellular signaling cascades.
  • Thyroid hormone: Thyroid hormones utilize intracellular nuclear receptors for gene regulation.
  • Glucocorticoid: Glucocorticoids bind to cytoplasmic receptors, translocating to the nucleus.
  • Growth hormone: Growth hormone acts via cytokine receptor family through the JAK-STAT pathway.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding skin suturing is/are correct?

 

  1. The angle at which the suture bite should be taken is 90°.
  2. Mattress sutures are placed to evert edges and provide hemostasis.
  3. Subcuticular sutures leave visible marks on the skin.
  4. The distance between two sutures should be twice the length of the suture bite on each side.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

  • Statement 1: Correct. The needle should enter the skin at a 90° angle for optimal suturing.
  • Statement 2: Correct. Mattress sutures are specifically designed to evert the edges and provide hemostasis, making them ideal in areas where edges tend to invert.
  • Statement 4: Correct. The recommended distance between two sutures is twice the length of the bite on either side, ensuring adequate wound closure.

 

Other Option:

 

  • Statement 3: Incorrect. Subcuticular sutures are cosmetically better as they are buried inside the skin, leaving no visible marks.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Skin suturing requires a 90° needle entry, appropriate spacing, and technique selection (e.g., mattress or subcuticular) to ensure wound edge eversion, hemostasis, and cosmetic outcomes.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman presents with chills, headache, and muscle aches for one day. She recently returned from a month-long trip to Tanzania, where she stayed in local hotels, ate at local restaurants, and spent time outdoors, including swimming in local lakes. She took atovaquone-proguanil for malaria prophylaxis and was compliant. On examination, she has multiple urticaria-type lesions on the trunk and upper extremities. Lab results show marked eosinophilia (40%) with leukocytosis. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Schistosomiasis

 

  • This patient’s symptoms (chills, headache, muscle aches, urticarial rash, and eosinophilia) following freshwater exposure in Tanzania are highly suggestive of acute schistosomiasis (Katayama fever). 
  • Schistosoma larvae penetrate the skin in freshwater bodies, leading to a systemic hypersensitivity reaction with eosinophilia upon migration to the liver and other organs.
  • High-risk activity: Swimming in local lakes in an endemic region (Africa).
  • Eosinophilia: A hallmark of parasitic infections, especially helminths.
  • Urticaria: A hypersensitivity reaction to migrating schistosomes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amebiasis: Causes bloody diarrhea and liver abscesses, not eosinophilia or urticarial rash.

 

Option B. Chikungunya fever: Presents with fever, polyarthritis, and rash but does not cause eosinophilia.

 

Option C. Cutaneous leishmaniasis: Leads to chronic, non-healing skin ulcers, not systemic illness with eosinophilia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute schistosomiasis (Katayama fever) should be suspected in travelers returning from endemic areas with eosinophilia and a history of freshwater exposure.

choices.text: The vaccine vial should be discarded immediately.
The vaccine is usable if the expiry date has not passed.
The vaccine has expired and must not be used.
The vaccine has been frozen and is no longer effective.

questions.text: A healthcare worker shows a vaccine vial with a vaccine vial monitor (VVM). What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The vaccine is usable if the expiry date has not passed.

 

  • A vaccine vial monitor (VVM) is used to assess vaccine viability. A lighter inner square compared to the outer circle indicates that the vaccine has not been exposed to excessive heat and is safe to use if it hasn’t expired.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The vaccine vial should be discarded immediately: Incorrect. The vaccine does not need to be discarded unless the inner square matches or is darker than the outer circle.

 

Option C. The vaccine has expired and must not be used: Incorrect. The inner square-light outer circle configuration indicates proper storage, not expiration.

 

Option D. The vaccine has been frozen and is no longer effective: Incorrect. Freezing does not affect this visual change; this option is unrelated to the VVM mechanism.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • A vaccine vial is usable if the inner square of the vaccine vial monitor is lighter than the outer circle and the expiry date has not passed.

questions.text:
Match the following Aortic Arches with their derivatives: 

 

Column A (Aortic Arch):

 

  1. 1st Aortic Arch
  2. 2nd Aortic Arch
  3. 3rd Aortic Arch
  4. 4th Aortic Arch

 

Column B (Develops into):


A. Hyoid artery
B. Left side: Arch of aorta; Right side: Right subclavian artery
C. Maxillary artery
D. Common carotid artery, proximal internal carotid artery
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

 

  • 1st Aortic Arch (1-C): The first aortic arch develops into the maxillary artery, which supplies the deep facial structures.
  • 2nd Aortic Arch (2-A): The second aortic arch develops into the hyoid artery and the stapedial artery during fetal development, which contribute to the blood supply of the neck and middle ear.
  • 3rd Aortic Arch (3-D): The third aortic arch develops into the common carotid artery and the proximal part of the internal carotid artery. The external carotid artery also arises from this arch.
  • 4th Aortic Arch (4-B):
    • Left side: The 4th aortic arch forms the arch of the aorta between the left common carotid and the left subclavian arteries.
    • Right side: It forms the right subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Each aortic arch contributes to the development of specific arterial structures in the body, with the 1st arch forming the maxillary artery, the 2nd arch forming the hyoid artery, the 3rd arch contributing to the carotid arteries, and the 4th arch forming parts of the aortic and subclavian arteries. 
  • Understanding these derivatives is essential for embryology and vascular anatomy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with a history of progressive shortness of breath. The histological image is given below. What is the most likely associated risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Tobacco smoking

 

  • The histopathology shows destruction of alveolar walls and enlarged airspaces, which is characteristic of emphysema, a major component of COPD. 
  • Tobacco smoking is the most common risk factor for centriacinar emphysema, which primarily affects the upper lobes.
  • Strongly associated with tobacco smoking.
  • Often shows black pigment deposition and focal damage around bronchioles, which is visible in the image.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency: Incorrect. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency is associated with panacinar emphysema, which affects the lower lobes of the lungs, often seen in non-smokers.

 

Option C. Air pollution exposure: Incorrect. Air pollution exposure can contribute to COPD but is a less significant risk factor compared to smoking.

 

Option D. Chronic asthma: Incorrect. While asthma is associated with airway inflammation, it does not typically lead to alveolar wall destruction as seen in emphysema.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of emphysema:

choices.text: Hip pain on passive external rotation

questions.text: A 62-year-old man from Bengaluru with diabetes mellitus and hyperlipidemia presents with right hip pain for the last 3 months. The pain is aching, triggered by walking (especially uphill), and relieved quickly by rest. He also experiences leg weakness, sometimes requiring him to hold onto stationary objects. His other medical conditions include gallstones, benign prostatic hyperplasia, and erectile dysfunction. His simvastatin dose was recently increased due to an elevated LDL cholesterol level. Which of the following physical findings is most consistent with this patient’s diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Femoral bruit

 

  • This patient's symptoms are highly suggestive of peripheral artery disease (PAD), specifically aortoiliac occlusive disease (Leriche syndrome). 
  • His pain is exertional and relieved by rest, which is characteristic of claudication due to arterial insufficiency. 
  • The associated leg weakness and erectile dysfunction further support the diagnosis of aortoiliac PAD, as stenosis in the aortoiliac region can compromise blood flow to both the legs and the pelvic organs. 
  • The most consistent physical finding in PAD is a femoral bruit, which suggests arterial narrowing.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Decreased vibration sense at ankles: Diabetic peripheral neuropathy causes sensory loss, tingling, and burning pain, but not exertional pain relieved by rest. His symptoms fit vascular claudication rather than neuropathic pain.

 

Option C. Hip pain on passive external rotation: Hip osteoarthritis presents with pain worsened by movement, particularly with weight-bearing. However, this patient's symptoms are vascular (intermittent claudication) rather than mechanical.

 

Option D. Limited lumbar spine mobility: Lumbar spinal stenosis can cause neurogenic claudication, but this pain is typically relieved by sitting or leaning forward rather than standing still. This patient's classic pattern of exertional pain relieved by rest is more indicative of vascular claudication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Peripheral artery disease (PAD), particularly aortoiliac occlusive disease (Leriche syndrome), presents with exertional leg pain relieved by rest, leg weakness, and erectile dysfunction. 
  • A femoral bruit is a key clinical finding suggestive of this diagnosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female with ovarian cancer is undergoing chemotherapy. Which of the following chemotherapeutic agents does not act on tubulin but instead works via another mechanism to inhibit cell growth?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Bleomycin

 

  • Bleomycin is an antitumor antibiotic that works by inducing DNA strand breaks rather than interacting with tubulin. 
  • It is not a microtubule-targeting agent like colchicine, paclitaxel, or vincristine.
  •  Paclitaxel and vincristine work by disrupting microtubule dynamics, while colchicine also disrupts microtubule polymerization.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Colchicine: Incorrect. Colchicine is a microtubule inhibitor that prevents tubulin polymerization, which is central to its action.
 

Option C. Paclitaxel: Incorrect. Paclitaxel stabilizes microtubules and prevents their depolymerization, affecting cell division.
 

Option D. Vincristine: Incorrect. Vincristine binds to tubulin and inhibits microtubule formation, leading to cell cycle arrest in metaphase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Bleomycin does not act on tubulin; instead, it causes DNA strand breaks. Other agents like colchicine, paclitaxel, and vincristine target microtubules to disrupt cell division.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents with sudden, violent, uncontrollable flinging movements of his right arm. His symptoms started abruptly three days ago. On examination, the patient is alert and cooperative but is unable to control these movements. Neurological examination shows no sensory deficits, and cranial nerve examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hemiballismus

 

  • Hemiballismus is caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus, often due to ischemia or infarction.
  • It is characterized by sudden, violent, involuntary flinging movements of the limbs on one side of the body (contralateral to the lesion).
  • This condition results from disruption of the inhibitory pathway of the basal ganglia, leading to excessive motor activity.

 

Other Options:
