Option A. Parkinson's disease: Typically presents with resting tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability. It is caused by degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra. Hemiballismus is not a feature.

 

Option B. Huntington's disease: A hereditary condition caused by a mutation in the HTT gene. It presents with chorea, psychiatric symptoms, and cognitive decline. The movements are more choreiform (writhing) rather than ballistic.

 

Option D. Essential tremor: Presents as a bilateral, symmetric action tremor, typically affecting the hands. It is not associated with sudden, violent movements or basal ganglia lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman from India presents with abdominal discomfort, bloating, and watery diarrhea for the past 6 months, along with unintentional weight loss of 9 kg (20 lb). She also reports gastroesophageal reflux symptoms and Raynaud’s phenomenon, which has been present for 2 years. Her past medical history is unremarkable, and she takes over-the-counter omeprazole as needed. She does not smoke and drinks 2-3 glasses of wine on weekends. Physical examination reveals patchy skin thickening over the chest, upper back, forearms, and legs. Her fingers appear tight and tapered at the tips. The abdomen is mildly tender without guarding or rebound, and bowel sounds are normal. Laboratory studies show macrocytic anemia (Hb 10.0 g/dL, MCV 102 fL), positive ANA, and positive anti-Scl-70 antibody. Stool studies are negative for pathogens, and colonoscopy shows scattered diverticulosis with normal biopsies. Which of the following would be most helpful to relieve this patient's gastrointestinal symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antibiotic therapy

 

This patient has systemic sclerosis (scleroderma), as evidenced by:

 

  • Skin thickening with fingertip tapering (sclerodactyly) and Raynaud’s phenomenon
  • GERD symptoms (esophageal dysmotility)
  • Positive anti-Scl-70 (topoisomerase I) antibody, which is associated with diffuse systemic sclerosis

 

Her chronic diarrhea, bloating, and weight loss are likely due to small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO), a common complication of systemic sclerosis due to impaired gastrointestinal motility (dysmotility allows bacterial overgrowth in the small intestine). Macrocytic anemia (MCV 102 fL) is likely due to vitamin B12 deficiency caused by SIBO-induced malabsorption.

 

💊 Empirical antibiotic therapy (e.g., rifaximin, amoxicillin-clavulanate) is the treatment of choice for SIBO.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Calcium channel blocker: These are used for Raynaud’s phenomenon (e.g., nifedipine, amlodipine) but do not relieve GI symptoms.

 

Option C. Pancreatic enzyme supplements: Indicated for exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (chronic pancreatitis, cystic fibrosis), which presents with fatty stools (steatorrhea) rather than watery diarrhea.

 

Option D. Prokinetic agents: Used for gastroparesis (delayed gastric emptying, early satiety, postprandial fullness), but SIBO needs antibiotic therapy as the primary treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) is a common cause of chronic diarrhea and weight loss in systemic sclerosis due to dysmotility. Empirical antibiotic therapy is the treatment of choice.

choices.text: Naive T-cells actively suppress HIV replication.
Activated T-cells are resistant to HIV infection.
HIV enters latency in memory T-cells, which are reactivated upon immune stimulation.
Dendritic cells prevent viral replication in infected tissues.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with HIV develops opportunistic infections despite antiretroviral treatment. His immune system cannot effectively control viral replication. Which of the following factors most likely contributes to this persistence?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HIV enters latency in memory T-cells, which are reactivated upon immune stimulation.

 

  • HIV enters a latent phase in memory T-cells and persists even in the face of immune response. 
  • When these cells are activated, the virus is reactivated, leading to ongoing infection and immune dysfunction despite treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Naive T-cells actively suppress HIV replication: Incorrect. Naive T-cells are not actively involved in suppressing HIV replication due to their lack of infection markers.

 

Option B. Activated T-cells are resistant to HIV infection: Incorrect. Activated T-cells are more susceptible to HIV infection due to their expression of co-receptors.

 

Option D. Dendritic cells prevent viral replication in infected tissues: Incorrect. Dendritic cells can serve as viral reservoirs but do not significantly prevent viral replication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HIV latency in memory T-cells allows for viral persistence and reactivation upon immune activation.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is true, but R is false
A is false, and R is true

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Magnesium sulfate toxicity can cause respiratory depression.


Reason (R): Magnesium sulfate inhibits neuromuscular transmission at high levels.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A

 

  • Magnesium sulfate is commonly used in obstetrics for seizure prophylaxis in preeclampsia and eclampsia. However, at toxic levels, it can cause respiratory depression due to its neuromuscular blocking effects.
  • Magnesium acts by inhibiting acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, leading to decreased muscle excitability.
  • As magnesium levels increase, progressive toxicity occurs:
    • Loss of deep tendon reflexes (first sign of toxicity, occurs at serum Mg²⁺ >7 mEq/L)
    • Respiratory depression (>10 mEq/L)
    • Cardiac arrest (>15 mEq/L)
  • Since magnesium sulfate directly inhibits neuromuscular transmission, this mechanism explains the cause of respiratory depression at toxic doses.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Toxic levels of magnesium sulfate inhibit neuromuscular transmission, causing respiratory depression, necessitating close monitoring during treatment.

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with a high fever, irritability, and vomiting. A lumbar puncture reveals cloudy cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) with a positive Gram stain for small, gram-negative coccobacilli. The organism is cultured on chocolate agar and forms colonies as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely biochemical characteristic of the organism responsible for this child’s condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Catalase positive, oxidase positive

 

  • Haemophilus influenzae is a catalase-positive and oxidase-positive gram-negative coccobacillus that grows well on chocolate agar, forming smooth grayish colonies. 
  • These characteristics are key in identifying this pathogen in CSF cultures, especially in cases of meningitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Haemophilus influenzae is catalase-positive and oxidase-positive and grows on chocolate agar.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in all neonates with respiratory distress.

 

Reason (R): Positive pressure ventilation can worsen respiratory distress in conditions like diaphragmatic hernia, tracheoesophageal fistula, and meconium aspiration syndrome.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A is false, but R is true.

 

Assertion (A): False. Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in some specific conditions associated with neonatal respiratory distress. However, this is not universally applicable to all neonates with respiratory distress.

 

Reason (R): True. While positive pressure ventilation can worsen respiratory distress in conditions like diaphragmatic hernia and tracheoesophageal fistula, it is not universally harmful and is often life-saving in other causes of neonatal respiratory distress, such as transient tachypnea of the newborn.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated in specific conditions like diaphragmatic hernia, but it remains a vital and safe intervention in most other causes of neonatal respiratory distress, such as transient tachypnea.

questions.text: What does Chopart’s injury involves?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints

 

  • Chopart's injury specifically affects the midfoot and involves damage to the Talonavicular and Calcaneocuboid joints. 
  • These two joints form the Chopart joint complex, which connects the talus (with the navicular and calcaneus bones. 
  • Injury to these joints often occurs due to high-impact trauma or fractures, disrupting foot stability.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Tibiotalar and subtalar joints: The Tibiotalar joint and the subtalar joint are both located in the ankle, not the midfoot. These joints are involved in movements like plantarflexion, dorsiflexion, and inversion/eversion, but they are not affected in Chopart’s injury.

 

Option C. Metatarsophalangeal joints: The Metatarsophalangeal joints are located at the base of the toes and are responsible for flexing and extending the toes. While these joints are important for walking, they are not the focus of a Chopart's injury, which specifically involves the midfoot, not the toes.

 

Option D. Proximal and distal interphalangeal joints: The proximal and distal interphalangeal joints are found in the toes and allow for the bending of the toe segments. These joints are involved in toe movements like flexion and extension, but Chopart’s injury affects the midfoot joints (Talonavicular and Calcaneocuboid joints), not the toe joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints are the most commonly affected in Chopart's injury. 
  • The others describe joints in the foot and ankle that are not involved in this specific injury.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl with Sturge-Weber syndrome is being evaluated for glaucoma. She has a history of capillary-venous malformations in the brain and facial port-wine stains. Which of the following diagnostic findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Homonymous hemianopia

 

  • Homonymous hemianopia is a common visual field defect in Sturge-Weber syndrome due to the involvement of the occipital lobes or optic tracts by leptomeningeal capillary-venous malformations. 
  • This defect is a hallmark of the neurological impact of SWS on the visual pathways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Diffuse retinal hemorrhages: These are more characteristic of diabetic retinopathy or retinal vein occlusion, not Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Option C. Macular edema: Macular edema is more commonly associated with diabetic retinopathy or uveitis, not typically a feature of SWS.

 

Option D. Optic disc swelling: Optic disc swelling is a sign of optic neuritis or increased intracranial pressure but is not a prominent feature of Sturge-Weber syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Homonymous hemianopia is a common visual field defect in Sturge-Weber syndrome, resulting from leptomeningeal capillary-venous malformations affecting the occipital lobes or optic tracts.

questions.text:
Identify the components of Revised Trauma Score?

 

  1. Pulse rate
  2. Respiratory rate
  3. Patient age
  4. Glasgow coma scale
  5. Systolic BP
questions.solution:
Ans. C) b, d, e

 

  • The Revised Trauma Score (RTS) is a physiological scoring system, with the intent to provide an assessment of the severity of a trauma patient's condition. The components of the RTS include:

 

b. Respiratory rate d. Glasgow Coma Scale e. Systolic BP

These three parameters are used to calculate the RTS, which can help to predict the patient's chances of survival. Each component is given a score, and the sum of these scores is used to determine the overall RTS.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Understand the components of the Revised Trauma Score (RTS) as a tool for assessing the severity of trauma, which includes the patient's respiratory rate, Glasgow Coma Scale score, and systolic blood pressure. 
  • Lower RTS scores correlate with higher injury severity and potentially lower chances of survival.

questions.text:
Match the hypothalamic nuclei with their respective functions:

 

Column A (Nuclei):

 

  1. Anterior nucleus
  2. Ventromedial nucleus
  3. Suprachiasmatic nucleus
  4. Paraventricular nucleus
  5. Mammillary bodies

 

Column B (Function):

 

A. Memory
B. Heat dissipation
C. Satiety center
D. Circadian rhythm regulation
E. Oxytocin secretion
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-C, 3-D, 4-E, 5-A

 

  • Anterior nucleus (1-B): Involved in heat dissipation by activating cooling mechanisms like sweating.
  • Ventromedial nucleus (2-C): Functions as the satiety center, inhibiting hunger.
  • Suprachiasmatic nucleus (3-D): Regulates circadian rhythms by controlling the sleep-wake cycle.
  • Paraventricular nucleus (4-E): Secretes oxytocin, which is crucial for uterine contraction and milk ejection.
  • Mammillary bodies (5-A): Associated with memory and limbic system functions.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Combination of Drugs B and C

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with overactive bladder and narrow-angle glaucoma is being evaluated. Looking at the receptor locations in the diagram, which drug would be contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Drug A 

 

  • Drug A (M3 antagonist) is absolutely contraindicated in narrow-angle glaucoma due to its effects on multiple organ systems. 
  • M3 muscarinic receptors are present in:
  1. The ciliary body of the eye, controlling aqueous humor production
  2. The iris sphincter muscle, affecting pupillary constriction
  3. The trabecular meshwork, influencing aqueous humor outflow Blocking these receptors can:
  • Cause pupillary dilation
  • Impair aqueous humor drainage
  • Potentially precipitate acute angle-closure glaucoma
  • Lead to a dangerous rise in intraocular pressure

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Drug B: β3 receptor agonists exhibit high tissue selectivity for the bladder. These drugs don't significantly affect ocular structures or intraocular pressure, making them safe alternatives for patients with glaucoma who need overactive bladder treatment.

 

Option C. Drug C: α1 receptor antagonists, while affecting smooth muscle tone, don't have significant effects on intraocular pressure or aqueous humor dynamics. Some studies even suggest potential benefits in reducing intraocular pressure.

 

Option D. Combination of drugs B and C:  This combination provides complementary mechanisms for managing urinary symptoms without affecting intraocular pressure, making it a safe option for patients with glaucoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • M3 receptors regulate bladder contraction, pupillary response, and aqueous humor dynamics
  • β3 receptors show high bladder selectivity
  • Understanding contraindications based on receptor distribution prevents serious adverse effects
  • Importance of selecting receptor-specific drugs based on comorbidities

choices.text: The treatment of detainees, particularly focusing on torture and cruel treatment.
Human experimentation, outlining research ethics and ensuring safety for subjects.
Therapeutic abortion, focusing on ethical considerations when abortion is involved in medical treatment.
Humanitarian efforts, emphasizing the dedication of physicians to human welfare and ethics.

questions.text: The Oslo Declaration is most concerned with providing ethical guidelines for which of the following medical scenarios?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Therapeutic abortion, focusing on ethical considerations when abortion is involved in medical treatment.

 

  • The Oslo Declaration is primarily concerned with offering guidelines for therapeutic abortion, addressing ethical issues related to abortion as part of medical treatment. 
  • It is an important declaration when discussing abortion in clinical settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The treatment of detainees, particularly focusing ontorture and cruel treatment: Incorrect. This is the focus of the Tokyo Declaration, which deals with treatment of detainees and preventing torture.

 

Option B. Human experimentation, outlining research ethics and ensuring safety for subjects: Incorrect. The Helsinki Declaration specifically provides guidelines for human experimentation and the ethical treatment of research subjects.

 

Option D. Humanitarian efforts, emphasizing the dedication of physicians to human welfare andethics: Incorrect. The Geneva Declaration focuses on the humanitarian goals of medicine, not specifically therapeutic abortion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Oslo Declaration offers ethical guidelines for therapeutic abortion, focusing on ethical decision-making in situations where abortion is part of medical treatment.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about Methylergometrine?

 

  1. It leads to tetanic uterine contraction.
  2. It is contraindicated in preeclampsia and eclampsia.
  3. It is used only after the delivery of the second twin.
  4. It is absolutely safe in patients with organic heart disease.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

Statement 1: Methylergometrine causes sustained uterine contraction.

 

Statement 2: Contraindicated in hypertensive conditions (e.g., preeclampsia, eclampsia).

 

Statement 3: It is given after the delivery of the second twin

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 4: Incorrect It is contraindicated in organic heart disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methylergometrine is a potent uterotonic with specific contraindications and indications, particularly in hypertensive and cardiac conditions.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man from India, recently diagnosed with hemochromatosis and undergoing periodic phlebotomy, presents to the emergency department with sudden-onset nausea, vomiting, cramping abdominal pain, and watery diarrhea. His symptoms began 4 hours after eating at a buffet restaurant, and his sister also developed similar symptoms.

 

  • Vital signs: Normal
  • Abdomen: Soft with mild generalized tenderness, no guarding or rebound tenderness, and increased bowel sounds
  • Labs:
    • Hemoglobin: 14.0 g/dL
    • Platelets: 260,000/mm³
    • Leukocytes: 10,400/mm³

 

Which of the following is the most likely causative organism of this patient’s current illness?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Staphylococcus aureus

 

  • This patient has acute food poisoning, characterized by sudden-onset nausea, vomiting, abdominal cramps, and watery diarrhea within 4 hours of eating at a buffet. 
  • The rapid onset of symptoms suggests preformed toxin ingestion, which is highly characteristic of Staphylococcus aureus.
  • S. aureus food poisoning occurs due to heat-stable enterotoxins in contaminated food (e.g., dairy, mayonnaise-based salads, meats, cream-filled pastries) that are not destroyed by reheating.
  • Symptoms appear within 1-6 hours, mostly with vomiting as the predominant symptom along with mild diarrhea.
  • Self-limiting illness, usually resolves in 24 hours.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Campylobacter jejuni: Causes bloody diarrhea and is associated with contaminated poultry. Symptoms develop over 2-5 days, not within 4 hours.

 

Option B. Clostridium perfringens: Causes watery diarrhea but not significant vomiting. Incubation period is 8-16 hours, which does not match this case.

 

Option C. Enterotoxigenic Escherichia coli (ETEC): A common cause of traveler’s diarrhea, with symptoms appearing >24 hours after ingestion, not within 4 hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Preformed toxin-mediated food poisoning, especially with a rapid onset of vomiting within 6 hours after eating at a buffet or picnic, is highly suggestive of Staphylococcus aureus. The illness is self-limiting and resolves within 24 hours.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female diagnosed with tuberculosis develops resistance to streptomycin. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely responsible for this resistance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) rrs

 

  • Streptomycin resistance is associated with mutations in the rrs gene, which encodes for 16S ribosomal RNA. 
  • This gene is involved in the binding of streptomycin to the bacterial ribosome, and mutations here prevent the drug from binding, resulting in resistance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. rpoB: rpoB is responsible for rifampin resistance, not streptomycin.


Option C. katG: katG is involved in resistance to isoniazid (INH), not streptomycin.


Option D. embCAB: embCAB is associated with resistance to ethambutol, not streptomycin.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text:
A 65-year-old man, Mr. Ramesh from Chennai, is brought to the emergency department with left arm weakness and slurred speech, which began after waking up this morning. His symptoms partially improved after 2 hours but worsened again an hour ago. He has a history of hypertension, type 2 diabetes, coronary artery disease, and chronic kidney disease. He underwent a coronary stent placement 7 years ago and has a 40-pack-year smoking history.

 

On examination:

 

  • Blood pressure: 175/105 mmHg, Pulse: 65/min (regular)
  • Neurological findings:
    • Left homonymous hemianopia
    • Rightward gaze preference
    • Reduced sensation on the left side of the face
    • Left hemiplegia with an extensor plantar response

 

What is the most likely cause of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atherothrombosis of a large artery

 

  • This patient's stepwise progression of symptoms with initial improvement followed by worsening suggests an evolving large-vessel ischemic stroke due to an atherothrombotic event (e.g., carotid or middle cerebral artery disease).

 

Key features supporting large artery atherothrombosis:

 

  • Fluctuating symptoms (suggesting evolving infarction due to thrombosis and embolization).
  • Cortical signs (homonymous hemianopia, gaze preference, hemisensory loss) seen in large-vessel strokes.
  • Multiple vascular risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, smoking, prior coronary disease).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Embolism from a cardiac source: Cardioembolic strokes (e.g., atrial fibrillation) present suddenly with maximal deficits and do not improve transiently.

 

Option C. Lipohyalinosis of a small vessel: Lacunar strokes usually cause pure motor or sensory deficits without cortical involvement (hemianopia, gaze deviation).

 

Option D. Rupture of a berry aneurysm: Aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage presents with sudden, severe headache ("thunderclap headache"), which this patient lacks.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Large artery atherothrombosis is a leading cause of ischemic stroke, especially in patients with hypertension, diabetes, smoking, and cardiovascular disease. 
  • Fluctuating or stepwise deficits suggest an evolving large-vessel infarction, warranting urgent imaging and reperfusion therapy.

choices.text: No mask ventilation → Thiopentone sodium → Succinylcholine → Cricoid pressure → Inflate cuff.
Gentle mask ventilation → Propofol → Succinylcholine/Rocuronium → cricoid pressure → ET tube placement → Inflate cuff.
Gentle mask ventilation → Propofol → Succinylcholine→ Inflate cuff→ cricoid pressure
No mask ventilation → Propofol → Rocuronium → Inflate cuff → Cricoid pressure.

questions.text: Identify the correct sequence of steps for modified rapid sequence intubation (RSI).
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gentle mask ventilation → Propofol → Succinylcholine/Rocuronium → cricoid pressure → ET tube placement → Inflate cuff.

 

  • Modified RSI involves gentle mask ventilation, Propofol as the induction agent, and the choice of Succinylcholine or Rocuronium as a muscle relaxant.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Modified rapid sequence intubation prioritizes gentle mask ventilation, Propofol induction, muscle relaxation with Succinylcholine or Rocuronium, and precise sequence to ensure safety and effectiveness during airway management.

choices.text: Exudative ascites due to tuberculous peritonitis
Transudative ascites due to nephrotic syndrome

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with ascites is admitted with increasing abdominal distention. Analysis of her ascitic fluid shows a protein content of 2.1 g/dL, specific gravity of 1.014, and LDH levels of 80 IU/L. What is the most likely classification of this ascitic fluid?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Transudative ascites due to cirrhosis

 

  • The ascitic fluid analysis shows low protein content (<3g/dL), low LDH levels, and low specific gravity, which are characteristic of transudative ascites. 
  • This is seen in liver cirrhosis due to portal hypertension, where the fluid accumulation is not due to inflammation or malignancy but rather due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the portal circulation. 
  • The fluid is clear and non-infected, which further supports transudative ascites rather than an exudative or infected etiology.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Exudative ascites due to malignancy: Incorrect. Malignant ascites typically shows higher protein content and higher LDH levels due to tumor-related inflammation.

 

Option C. Exudative ascites due to tuberculous peritonitis Incorrect. Tuberculous peritonitis would cause exudative ascites with higher protein, higher cell count, and increased LDH levels.


Option D. Transudative ascites due to nephrotic syndrome: Can lead to transudative ascites, but low protein and low LDH with clear fluid are more characteristic of liver cirrhosis in this context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Transudative ascites in cirrhosis is characterized by low protein, low LDH, and low specific gravity, reflecting fluid accumulation due to portal hypertension rather than inflammation or malignancy.

 

Key Parameters for Ascitic Fluid Classification:

choices.text: The thrombus formed rapidly after the cessation of blood circulation.
The thrombus developed gradually after blood circulation ceased.
The thrombus is attached to the vessel wall and indicates an antemortem thrombotic event.
The thrombus is consistent with an embolic event rather than a local clot.

questions.text: A postmortem thrombus with a pale upper layer and a red lower layer is observed in a deceased patient. Based on the characteristics of this thrombus, which of the following can be inferred about the process of its formation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The thrombus developed gradually after blood circulation ceased.

 

  • The described thrombus, with pale and red layers, is indicative of chicken fat formation. 
  • This type of postmortem clot forms gradually as RBCs settle, creating distinct layers. 
  • The gradual clotting process leads to the separation of serum and fibrin from RBCs, forming the pale upper layer and red lower layer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The thrombus formed rapidly after the cessation of blood circulation: Rapid formation would result in a uniformly dark red clot (red current jelly) where RBCs are not allowed to settle.
 

Option C. The thrombus is attached to the vessel wall and indicates an antemortem thrombotic event: Antemortem thrombi are typically firmly attached to vessel walls and are not gelatinous or layered in appearance.
 

Option D. The thrombus is consistent with an embolic event rather than a local clot: Embolic events involve clots traveling through the bloodstream and are not related to the formation of postmortem thrombi with layered appearances.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Appearances of thrombus:

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with hypertension and chronic kidney disease is being evaluated for enalapril therapy. Which of the following conditions would not contraindicate the use of enalapril?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Diabetic nephropathy with albuminuria

 

  • Enalapril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor, is commonly used in the management of hypertension and chronic kidney disease, especially in patients with diabetic nephropathy and albuminuria.
  •  ACE inhibitors, including enalapril, help reduce proteinuria and slow the progression of kidney disease. 
  • Therefore, diabetic nephropathy with albuminuria is not a contraindication but rather an indication for ACE inhibitor therapy in appropriate patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Enalapril is contraindicated in the following conditions:

 

Option B. Single kidney: ACE inhibitors can decrease glomerular filtration rate (GFR) and may exacerbate renal dysfunction in patients with only one functioning kidney.

 

Option C. Bilateral renal artery stenosis: ACE inhibitors can further reduce renal perfusion in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis, potentially leading to acute kidney injury.

 

Option D. Hyperkalemia: ACE inhibitors increase potassium retention, which can worsen hyperkalemia in predisposed individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Enalapril is contraindicated in conditions like a single kidney, bilateral renal artery stenosis, and hyperkalemia. It is beneficial in conditions like diabetic nephropathy with albuminuria.

questions.text: A healthcare facility is conducting screening for breast cancer using a two-step process. First, all women are tested using a mammography (test A), followed by an ultrasound (test B) for those who are positive on mammography. If the sensitivity of mammography is 90% and that of ultrasound is 85%, what is the combined sensitivity of the two tests when used in series?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 76.5%

 

  • The combined sensitivity of two tests in series is calculated by multiplying the sensitivity of both tests:
    Combined sensitivity = Sensitivity (A) × Sensitivity (B) = 0.90 × 0.85 = 0.765, or 76.5%.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Tests in Series & Parallel:

choices.text: PCOD is associated with glucose intolerance.
PCOD leads to elevated LH levels.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about PCOD is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) PCOD results in postdated pregnancy.

 

  • PCOD does not cause postdated pregnancy. It is more commonly associated with infertility and ovulatory dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PCOD can cause infertility: Infertility is a hallmark of PCOD due to anovulation.

 

Option B. PCOD is associated with glucose intolerance: Glucose intolerance is common due to insulin resistance.

 

Option C. PCOD leads to elevated LH levels: Elevated LH levels are a characteristic biochemical abnormality in PCOD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PCOD leads to ovulatory dysfunction, infertility, insulin resistance, and metabolic abnormalities but does not cause postdated pregnancy.

questions.text: A 26-year-old software engineer is brought to the emergency by his family with a 1-week history of decreased sleep (sleeping only 2-3 hours/night), excessive talking, making grand plans to start multiple companies, and beliefs that he is being followed by his colleagues who are jealous of his "special abilities". What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Olanzapine + Valproate

 

  • The patient's decreased need for sleep, excessive talking, grandiosity, and paranoid delusions suggest acute manic episode with psychotic features, likely due to bipolar I disorder. 
  • The most appropriate initial treatment involves a combination of an antipsychotic (e.g., olanzapine) and a mood stabilizer (e.g., valproate) for rapid control of mania and psychotic symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lithium alone 

 

  • While lithium is a first-line mood stabilizer, it has a slow onset of action (takes 1-2 weeks for full effect).
    • Not ideal for acute agitation, severe mania, or psychotic features.
    • Valproate is preferred in patients with agitation, mixed features, or rapid cycling.

 

Option C. Risperidone alone

 

  • Atypical antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone, olanzapine) alone can help with mania but do not stabilize mood as effectively as a combination with a mood stabilizer.
    • Combination therapy is preferred for severe mania with psychotic features.

 

Option D. Carbamazepine + Haloperidol 

 

  • Carbamazepine is a second-line mood stabilizer with a less favorable safety profile than valproate or lithium.
    • Haloperidol (a typical antipsychotic) has a higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects compared to newer atypical antipsychotics (e.g., olanzapine, risperidone).

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For acute mania with psychotic features, the preferred treatment is a combination of a second-generation antipsychotic (e.g., olanzapine, risperidone, quetiapine) + a mood stabilizer (e.g., valproate, lithium). Valproate is especially useful for agitated or mixed episodes and has a faster onset than lithium.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man, Rajesh from Mumbai, visits the clinic for routine follow-up after undergoing pneumatic dilation for esophageal achalasia. He reports significant improvement in dysphagia and nocturnal regurgitation. His medical history includes borderline hypertension and an anxiety disorder. He previously smoked (5 pack-years) and has a family history of Sjögren’s disease and lymphoma. He is currently taking omeprazole and clonazepam.

 

On examination:

 

  • BP: 135/85 mmHg
  • Pulse: 67/min
  • BMI: 30 kg/m²
  • Systemic examination: Unremarkable

 

Over the next 10 years, which of the following conditions is he at the highest risk for?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Squamous cell carcinoma

 

  • Achalasia is a chronic motility disorder that leads to the accumulation of food and stasis in the esophagus, which increases the risk of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) over time. 
  • The constant irritation and inflammation from retained food, along with bacterial overgrowth, predispose the esophageal mucosa to dysplasia and subsequent malignancy.
  • Achalasia-associated SCC risk: 30-fold increase compared to the general population
  • Peak risk: 10-20 years after diagnosis
  • Typical location: Mid to distal esophagus

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fibrosing mediastinitis: A rare condition caused by granulomatous inflammation, often due to Histoplasma capsulatum infection, not achalasia.

 

Option B. Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma: More likely in patients with chronic immunosuppression or autoimmune disorders (e.g., Sjögren’s disease). Rajesh's family history of lymphoma does not significantly elevate his personal risk.

 

Option C. Pyloric stenosis: Pyloric stenosis typically occurs in infants due to hypertrophy of the pyloric muscle, unrelated to achalasia or its treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Patients with achalasia have a significantly increased risk of esophageal squamous cell carcinoma due to prolonged food stasis, bacterial overgrowth, and chronic mucosal irritation. Long-term surveillance with periodic endoscopy is crucial in monitoring for early malignant changes.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of acromegaly is being treated with Octreotide. Which of the following side effects is most commonly associated with Octreotide therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hyperglycemia

 

  • Octreotide can cause hyperglycemia as a side effect due to its inhibitory effect on insulin secretion from the pancreas. 
  • While it is effective in controlling GH levels, it may disrupt glucose metabolism. 
  • Other side effects include gastrointestinal disturbances, but hyperglycemia is the most notable metabolic effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypotension: Incorrect. Octreotide does not typically cause hypotension.
 

Option C. Hyperthyroidism. Incorrect: Hypothyroidism is not a common side effect of Octreotide.
 

Option D. Visual disturbances: Incorrect. Visual disturbances are not a common side effect of Octreotide treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Octreotide therapy in acromegaly can lead to hyperglycemia due to inhibition of insulin secretion.

questions.text: A 36-week gestation newborn is born via spontaneous vaginal delivery to a 28-year-old primigravida mother. The pregnancy was uneventful with normal antenatal ultrasound findings. The newborn is noted to have respiratory distress immediately after delivery and is quickly transferred to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) for further evaluation and management. On examination, the neonate is tachypneic with subcostal retractions and decreased breath sounds on the left side. CXR is shown in the image below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

 

  • An X-ray of the chest shows a left-sided congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)-Bochdalek type with the stomach and intestines occupying the left chest cavity and compressing the left lung. 
  • There is a defect in posterior-lateral aspect of the left pleuroperitoneal canal from which the diaphragm develops. 
  • This allows the abdominal contents to herniate into the chest cavity, leading to pulmonary hypoplasia and respiratory distress.

 

Initial management: 

 

  • The neonate is started on mechanical ventilation, and a nasogastric tube is inserted for decompression of the stomach. 
  • The neonate is also started on a prostaglandin infusion to maintain the patency of the ductus arteriosus and optimize pulmonary blood flow. 
  • The neonate is stabilized and is taken up for surgical repair of the diaphragmatic hernia within the first few days of life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pulmonary hypoplasia: Underdevelopment of the lungs usually associated with other conditions.

 

Option C. Trachea esophageal fistula: An abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus.

 

Option D. Eventration of the diaphragm: Thinning and elevation of part of the diaphragm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The correct diagnosis is congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which presents with respiratory distress and is confirmed by the presence of abdominal organs in the thoracic cavity on X-ray. 
  • Bag and mask ventilation is contraindicated due to the risk of gastrointestinal perforation and worsening respiratory distress.

 

Note – Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in Congenital Diaphragmatic Hernia

questions.text: A 22-year-old patient presents with progressive central vision loss. Fluorescein angiography (FFA) reveals the following image as shown below. What is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Stargardt's disease

 

  • The hallmark feature of Stargardt's disease on fluorescein angiography is the "silent choroid" or "dark choroid" phenomenon. 
  • This is caused by the retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) abnormalities and the accumulation of lipofuscin. 
  • The mixed hyper- and hypofluorescence in the macula on FFA is typical of Stargardt’s disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Retinitis pigmentosa: Retinitis pigmentosa usually presents with peripheral vision loss and shows characteristic "bone spicule" pigmentation, not a dark choroid on FFA.

 

Option C. Diabetic macular edema: Diabetic macular edema presents with retinal thickening and microaneurysms, but it does not show a dark choroid phenomenon on FFA.

 

Option D. Central serous chorioretinopathy: This condition typically presents with a localized area of retinal detachment and hyperfluorescence on FFA, not the silent choroid seen in Stargardt's disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "silent choroid" or "dark choroid" phenomenon on fluorescein angiography is a key diagnostic feature of Stargardt’s disease, a form of macular dystrophy.

choices.text: Cubilin receptor-mediated endocytosis of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is impaired.
Pancreatic protease secretion is insufficient to release vitamin B12 from haptocorrin.
Haptocorrin binding to vitamin B12 is defective, leading to reduced transport.
Intrinsic factor is not secreted, preventing B12 binding in the stomach.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female who has had a history of Crohn's disease for many years, underwent ileal resection, now presents with megaloblastic anemia despite adequate dietary intake of vitamin B12. Which of the following steps in the absorption of vitamin B12 is most likely disrupted due to her ileal resection?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cubilin receptor-mediated endocytosis of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is impaired.

 

  • In patients with ileal resection due to Crohn's disease, cubilin receptors on ileal enterocytes are lost. 
  • These receptors are essential for the endocytosis of the intrinsic factor-vitamin B12 complex, which is necessary for the absorption of vitamin B12 in the ileum. 
  • Without these receptors, the complex cannot be absorbed, leading to B12 deficiency and resultant megaloblastic anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pancreatic protease secretion is insufficient to release vitamin B12 from haptocorrin: Incorrect. Pancreatic proteases aid in the release of B12 from haptocorrin in the duodenum, but their dysfunction does not directly impair the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex absorption in the ileum.

 

Option C. Haptocorrin bindingto vitamin B12 is defective, leading to reduced transport: Incorrect. Haptocorrin binding occurs in the stomach and aids initial B12 transport, but it is the cubilin receptors in the ileum that mediate the complex's final absorption.

 

Option D. Intrinsic factor is not secreted, preventing B12 binding in the stomach: Incorrect. Intrinsic factor is usually present, and the problem is in the absorption of the complex in the ileum, not its initial binding in the stomach.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ileal resection disrupts cubilin receptor-mediated endocytosis, impairing the absorption of the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex and leading to B12 deficiency.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Episiotomy should be performed routinely to reduce laceration severity during delivery.


Reason (R): Routine episiotomies prevent severe perineal tears
questions.solution:
Ans. D) A is false, but R is true.

 

  • Routine episiotomies are not recommended as they do not necessarily reduce the severity of lacerations. 
  • They should only be performed when necessary. 
  • However, mediolateral episiotomy may be beneficial in instrumental deliveries.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Routine episiotomies are not recommended; they should be used selectively to prevent unnecessary perineal trauma.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man, Ravi from Pune, diagnosed with Crohn’s disease, presents with persistent diarrhea for the past 3 months following ileal resection for small-bowel obstruction. He reports 4-5 loose bowel movements daily, significantly disrupting his daily activities and studies. He denies fever, abdominal pain, vomiting, or weight loss.

 

He had a perianal abscess treated with metronidazole 7 months ago. Physical examination is unremarkable, apart from a well-healed abdominal scar.

 

Laboratory findings:

 

  • Mild anemia (Hb: 12.0 g/dL)
  • Hypokalemia (K+: 3.4 mEq/L)
  • Normal ESR (10 mm/h)
  • Normal B12 levels

 

Which of the following is most likely to improve his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cholestyramine

 

  • This patient has post-ileal resection diarrhea, most likely due to bile acid malabsorption. 
  • The terminal ileum is responsible for reabsorbing bile salts, and when resected, excess bile acids enter the colon, leading to secretory diarrhea and irritation of the colonic mucosa.
  • Cholestyramine (a bile acid sequestrant) binds excess bile acids, preventing their colonic irritation and reducing diarrhea.
  • The ileocecal valve sparing suggests mild/moderate bile acid loss, making cholestyramine highly effective.
  • B12 deficiency is not yet present but may develop over time due to impaired absorption in the terminal ileum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lactose-free diet: Post-surgical diarrhea here is not related to lactose intolerance as he has no history of bloating or dairy-induced symptoms.

 

Option C. Mesalamine: Used for mild Crohn’s colitis, but not effective for post-ileal resection bile acid diarrhea.

 

Option D. Prednisone: Indicated for acute Crohn’s disease flares, but this patient has no inflammatory symptoms (abdominal pain, fever, or high ESR), so steroids are unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Bile acid malabsorption is a common cause of chronic diarrhea following ileal resection, as the terminal ileum plays a crucial role in bile salt reabsorption. 
  • Excess bile acids in the colon lead to secretory diarrhea, which can significantly impact daily life. 
  • Cholestyramine, a bile acid sequestrant, effectively binds bile acids and alleviates symptoms. 
  • Early recognition and appropriate management are essential to improving quality of life in post-resection patients.

choices.text: To assess corneal thickness for LASIK eligibility
To assess the retina for macular degeneration

questions.text: A patient is undergoing eye evaluation, as shown in the image, which of the following is the primary purpose of this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) To assess corneal thickness for LASIK eligibility

 

  • The primary purpose of pachymetry is to measure corneal thickness, which is essential for evaluating the eligibility of a patient for LASIK surgery. 
  • Sufficient corneal thickness is necessary to ensure the safety and success of the procedure. 
  • Pachymetry does not measure intraocular pressure or detect retinal conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. To measure intraocular pressure: Intraocular pressure is measured by tonometry, not pachymetry.

 

Option C. To detect corneal abrasions: Corneal abrasions are typically diagnosed using fluorescein staining, not pachymetry.

 

Option D. To assess the retina for macular degeneration: This would require specialized imaging tests like OCT (Optical Coherence Tomography), not pachymetry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Pachymetry is used to measure corneal thickness, which is a key consideration for LASIK surgery eligibility.

questions.text:
Match the clinical conditions in neonates with their key distinguishing features:

 

Column A:

  1. Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF)
  2. Neonatal jaundice on Day 1
  3. Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
  4. Neonatal cholestasis

 

Column B: 

  1. Frothing, excessive drooling, cyanosis during feeding 
  2. Respiratory distress unresponsive to surfactant therapy 
  3. Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, elevated gamma-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT) 
  4. Hemolytic disease of the newborn, requiring phototherapy
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-A, 2-D, 3-B, 4-C

 

  1. Tracheoesophageal fistula (1-A): TEF is characterized by frothing, drooling, coughing, and cyanosis during feeding, due to abnormal connection between the trachea and esophagus.
  2. Neonatal jaundice on Day 1 (2-D): Jaundice within the first 24 hours is usually pathological, most often due to hemolytic disease of the newborn, necessitating phototherapy.
  3. Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis (3-B): This rare disorder presents with respiratory distress unresponsive to surfactant therapy and a ground-glass appearance on X-ray.
  4. Neonatal cholestasis (4-C): Extrahepatic cholestasis, such as biliary atresia, presents with conjugated hyperbilirubinemia and elevated GGT levels.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Early recognition of clinical features in neonatal conditions is essential for timely intervention and improved outcomes.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason is the correct explanation of Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason is not the correct explanation of Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.
Assertion is false, but Reason is true.

questions.text:
Assertion: The cervical curvature of the vertebral column develops when the infant starts supporting its head.
Reason: The thoracic curvature of the vertebral column develops when the infant starts walking
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Assertion is true, but Reason is false.

 

  • Assertion (True): The cervical curvature of the vertebral column develops as the infant begins to raise and support its head while prone and holding the head erect while sitting. This is a secondary curve (lordosis) that forms concave posteriorly.
  • Reason (False): The thoracic curvature is a primary curve and does not develop during infancy. It is concave anteriorly and is present at birth as part of the fetal kyphosis. It is incorrect to associate the development of the thoracic curvature with walking. The lumbar curvature, however, develops when the child starts standing and walking.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The vertebral column has four curvatures:
  • Primary curves (present at birth): Thoracic and sacral kyphoses, concave anteriorly.
  • Secondary curves (develop after birth): Cervical lordosis (infant raises head) and lumbar lordosis (child assumes upright posture).

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with full-thickness circumferential burns on the forearm develops progressive pain, paresthesia, and pallor. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Escharotomy

 

  • Escharotomy is performed to relieve pressure from the inelastic burned tissue and restore distal circulation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fasciotomy: Fasciotomy is for compartment syndrome, not initial treatment of burn-induced constriction.

 

Option C. Intravenous fluids: Fluids do not address the mechanical constriction.

 

Option D. Splinting: Splinting is not indicated in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Circumferential burns causing neurovascular compromise require escharotomy to relieve pressure and restore circulation.

questions.text: As per the WHO 2010 semen analysis criteria which parameter is considered abnormal according to these standards?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Volume of 1.2 mL

 

  • According to WHO 2010, a normal semen volume is ≥1.5 mL. A volume of 1.2 mL is below the normal range.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sperm motility of 45%: Correct as motility of ≥40% is normal.

 

Option C. Sperm count of 20 million/mL: Correct as sperm count of ≥15 million/mL is normal.

 

Option D. Sperm morphology with 5% normal forms: Correct as normal sperm morphology is ≥4%.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Normal semen analysis parameters according to WHO 2010 include a volume ≥1.5 mL, total motility ≥40%, and sperm morphology ≥4%.

choices.text: Water in the stomach and small intestine
Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist

questions.text: Which postmortem finding is most specific to freshwater drowning and can help distinguish it from saltwater drowning?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Gettler test for chloride content

 

  • The Gettler test is used to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning by estimating the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart. 
  • In freshwater drowning, the chloride content in the blood is typically lower than in saltwater drowning, where the chloride content is higher due to the salt in the water. 
  • This test can help forensic investigators determine the type of drowning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Water in the stomach and small intestine: Found in both freshwater and saltwater drownings, it does not help differentiate between the two.
 

Option B. Cadaveric spasm with mud in closed fist: This finding is related to ante-mortem drowning, where the victim may have grabbed debris, but it does not differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning.
 

Option D. Voluminous, ballooned-out lungs: This finding is common in both types of drowning, as the lungs fill with water during submersion, and does not provide a distinction between freshwater and saltwater drowning.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The Gettler test is used to differentiate freshwater drowning from saltwater drowning based on chloride content in the heart chambers.

questions.text: The nerve supplying the superior oblique muscle exits the brainstem at which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) B

 

Trochlear Nerve (CN IV):

 

  • The trochlear nerve is responsible for innervating the superior oblique muscle.
  • It is unique among cranial nerves as:
    • It emerges dorsally from the brainstem.
    • It crosses the midline to supply the contralateral superior oblique muscle.

 

Key Features of the Trochlear Nerve:

 

  1. Nucleus Location: The trochlear nerve nucleus is located in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus.
  2. Emergence: It exits the brainstem dorsally, making it the only cranial nerve to do so, at the site marked B in the image.
  3. Course:
    • Passes between the posterior cerebral artery and superior cerebellar artery, making it prone to compression by aneurysms.
    • Enters the middle cranial fossa and the orbit via the superior orbital fissure, outside the annulus of Zinn.
  4. Innervation: It supplies the superior oblique muscle, which functions to depress and internally rotate the eye.

 

Comparison of Cranial Nerve Origins:

 

  1. Midbrain (III-IV):
    • CN III: Oculomotor nerve arises at the level of the superior colliculus.
    • CN IV: Trochlear nerve arises at the level of the inferior colliculus.
  2. Pons (V-VIII):
    • Trigeminal to Vestibulocochlear nerves.
  3. Medulla (IX-XII):
    • Glossopharyngeal to Hypoglossal nerves.

 

Nerve Supply of Extraocular Muscles:

 

  • Oculomotor nerve (CN III): Medial rectus, superior rectus, inferior rectus, inferior oblique.
  • Trochlear nerve (CN IV): Superior oblique.
  • Abducent nerve (CN VI): Lateral rectus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The trochlear nerve (CN IV) is the only cranial nerve to:

 

  1. Emerge dorsally from the brainstem.
  2. Supply the contralateral superior oblique muscle.
  3. Have its nucleus in the midbrain at the level of the inferior colliculus.

 

It exits the brainstem dorsally at the site marked B in the provided image.

choices.text: Muscle relaxation without any initial muscle contraction
Prolonged blockade that can only be reversed by high doses of neostigmine
Initial muscular fasciculations, followed by muscle paralysis
Complete lack of effect in patients with myasthenia gravis

questions.text: A 55-year-old male undergoing general anesthesia for surgery receives succinylcholine as a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker. Which of the following is the most likely consequence of using succinylcholine in this patient, particularly after the initial dose?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Initial muscular fasciculations, followed by muscle paralysis

 

  • Succinylcholine is a depolarizing neuromuscular blocker that mimics acetylcholine, binding to the nicotinic receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  •  The initial effect is muscular fasciculations (brief muscle contractions) due to initial depolarization, followed by muscle paralysis as the depolarized muscle fibers become unresponsive to further stimulation. 
  • This effect leads to the desired muscle relaxation for surgical procedures.
  •  The blockade is not reversed by neostigmine, as neostigmine works on non-depolarizing agents.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Muscle relaxation without any initial muscle contraction: Incorrect. Succinylcholine causes initial muscle fasciculations before achieving relaxation.


Option B. Prolonged blockade that can only be reversed by high doses of neostigmine: Incorrect. Neostigmine is ineffective in reversing succinylcholine's depolarizing blockade, unlike non-depolarizing blockers like rocuronium or vecuronium.
 

Option D. Complete lack of effect in patients with myasthenia gravis: Incorrect. Myasthenia gravis typically involves reduced acetylcholine receptor availability, which would actually enhance the effect of succinylcholine rather than cause a lack of effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Succinylcholine causes initial fasciculations followed by muscle paralysis through depolarization of muscle fibers at the neuromuscular junction.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female diagnosed with breast cancer is being considered for treatment with an LHRH (Luteinizing Hormone-Releasing Hormone) analogue. Which of the following agents is most commonly used in this context to treat her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leuprolide

 

  • Leuprolide is an LHRH analogue commonly used in the treatment of breast cancer, particularly in premenopausal women.
  •  It works by suppressing ovarian estrogen production, which can help in treating estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. 
  • Leuprolide acts as a GnRH agonist, leading to a downregulation of the pituitary gland’s release of luteinizing hormone (LH) and follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH), thereby reducing ovarian estrogen secretion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Cetrorelix: Incorrect. Cetrorelix is a GnRH antagonist, used for ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome or in prostate cancer treatment, but not commonly for breast cancer.
 

Option B. Anastrozole: Incorrect. Anastrozole is an aromatase inhibitor, which inhibits estrogen production, but it is not an LHRH analogue.
 

Option D. Tamoxifen: Incorrect. Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM), not an LHRH analogue, though it is used in estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leuprolide is an LHRH analogue used in the treatment of breast cancer by inhibiting ovarian estrogen production.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male with HIV presents with papules on his trunk and face, as shown in the image. Histopathological examination reveals the presence of intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies in the affected cells. What is the name of these inclusion bodies?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Henderson-Patterson bodies

 

  • Henderson-Patterson bodies, also known as molluscum bodies, are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies found in the epidermal cells of lesions caused by molluscum contagiosum. 
  • These inclusion bodies are a key diagnostic feature of molluscum contagiosum and are visible on histopathological examination.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Koilocytes: Koilocytes are found in HPV-induced lesions such as genital warts, not molluscum contagiosum.
 

Option B. Cowdry type A bodies: Cowdry type A bodies are seen in herpesvirus infections, not molluscum contagiosum.
 

Option C. Mallory bodies: Mallory bodies are abnormal cytoplasmic inclusions seen in alcoholic liver disease, not in skin lesions.
 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Henderson-Patterson bodies (molluscum bodies) are intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies seen in molluscum contagiosum lesions.

choices.text: Observation and repeat endoscopy in 5 years
Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and endoscopic surveillance

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with chronic GERD undergoes endoscopy, revealing columnar epithelium in the distal esophagus. Biopsy confirms goblet cells without dysplasia. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy and endoscopic surveillance

 

  • PPI therapy reduces acid reflux, and surveillance detects early dysplastic changes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Observation and repeat endoscopy in 5 years: Observation alone neglects the cancer risk.

 

Option C. Endoscopic mucosal resection (EMR): EMR is for dysplasia.

 

Option D. Esophagectomy: Esophagectomy is reserved for high-grade dysplasia or invasive cancer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • PPI therapy reduces acid reflux, and surveillance detects early dysplastic changes.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female with schizophrenia was started on an antipsychotic medication 3 weeks ago. She presents to the emergency with complaints of severe anxiety, subjective restlessness, and an irresistible urge to keep moving around. She paces continuously during the interview and says "I just can't sit still, doctor." Which of the following would be most appropriate for first-line management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Start oral propranolol

 

  • The patient’s symptoms of severe restlessness, anxiety, and an inability to sit still suggest akathisia, a common extrapyramidal side effect (EPS) of antipsychotic medications, especially first-generation antipsychotics and high-potency second-generation antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone, aripiprazole). First-line treatment includes beta-blockers such as propranolol, which helps reduce dopamine blockade-induced motor restlessness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Switch to clozapine:

 

  • Clozapine is reserved for treatment-resistant schizophrenia and is not the first-line treatment for akathisia.
  • Additionally, it has a high risk of agranulocytosis, requiring close monitoring.

 

Option C. Add trihexyphenidyl:

 

  • Trihexyphenidyl is an anticholinergic used for antipsychotic-induced parkinsonism (rigidity, bradykinesia) or acute dystonia, but it is not effective for akathisia.

 

Option D. Reduce antipsychotic dose:

 

  • While lowering the dose can help, it may compromise symptom control in schizophrenia.
  • Adding propranolol allows the continuation of treatment while managing akathisia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acute akathisia is the commonest side effect of antipsychotic medications. It is characterized by an inner sense of restlessness along with objective, observable movements such as fidgeting of legs, pacing around, inability to sit or stand in one place for a long time. 
  • The drug of choice is β-blockers such as propranolol. Other treatment options include anticholinergics and benzodiazepines.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Methotrexate is contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy with fetal cardiac activity.


Reason (R): Methotrexate is ineffective when the gestational sac is larger than 4 cm or fetal cardiac activity is present.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.

 

Methotrexate is contraindicated in ectopic pregnancy with fetal cardiac activity because its efficacy is significantly reduced when the gestational sac is larger than 4 cm or when fetal cardiac activity is present. Methotrexate works by inhibiting DNA synthesis in rapidly dividing trophoblastic cells, making it effective for small, early-stage ectopic pregnancies. However, when fetal cardiac activity is present, the pregnancy is more advanced, and the trophoblastic tissue is more resilient, leading to a higher failure rate of medical management. In such cases, surgical intervention, such as laparoscopic salpingostomy or salpingectomy, is the preferred treatment to prevent complications like rupture and hemorrhage. Since the reason directly explains why methotrexate is contraindicated in these cases, both the assertion and reasoning are correct, making option A the best answer.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Methotrexate is contraindicated in ectopic pregnancies with fetal cardiac activity or large sac size due to reduced efficacy.

questions.text: Match the following co-morbid conditions with their respective perioperative concerns and management strategies.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

 

  • 1-C: Hypertension: ACE inhibitors and ARBs are discontinued preoperatively to prevent severe intraoperative hypotension.
  • 2-A: Diabetes Mellitus: Long-acting insulin is reduced to one-third of the dose to prevent intraoperative hypoglycemia.
  • 3-B: Epilepsy: Avoidance of enflurane and methohexitone is necessary as they can provoke seizures.
  • 4-D: Psychiatric Medications (MAO inhibitors): These are stopped 3–4 weeks prior to avoid a hypertensive crisis when interacting with synthetic opioids or anesthetics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Proper perioperative management of co-morbid conditions, including medication adjustments, is essential to prevent complications like hypotension, hypoglycemia, and hypertensive crises.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding auricular hematoma is/are correct?

 

  1. It is caused by trauma leading to blood collection between the ear's cartilage and perichondrium.
  2. Definitive management requires systemic antibiotics.
  3. If untreated, it can result in cauliflower ear.
  4. Cold compress is the first-line treatment.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 3 only

 

1. It is caused by trauma leading to blood collection between the ear's cartilage and perichondrium: Correct. Trauma causing blood accumulation leads to auricular hematoma.

 

3. If untreated, it can result in cauliflower ear: Correct. Untreated hematomas result in deformities like cauliflower ear.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Definitive management requires systemic antibiotics: Incorrect. Antibiotics are not routinely required unless infection is present.

 

4. Cold compress is the first-line treatment: Incorrect. Cold compress is supportive but not definitive treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Recognize the pathophysiology and management of auricular hematoma, focusing on the consequences of delayed treatment.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child, weighing 21 kg, presents for HIV PEP after being exposed to HIV during an accident. The child is in a high-risk situation, and timely intervention is crucial. What is the most appropriate HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen for this child?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lamivudine + Zidovudine + Dolutegravir

 

  • For children over 6 years or weighing more than 20 kg, the recommended HIV post-exposure prophylaxis regimen is Lamivudine + Zidovudine + Dolutegravir.
  • This combination is specifically tailored for children in this weight group to provide effective HIV prevention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Duration of prophylaxis is 28 days

questions.text: Which site is most likely involved in immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) CNS and gastrointestinal tract (GIT).

 

  • Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma typically involves the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) and central nervous system (CNS). 
  • This form is seen in patients with HIV/AIDS or other immunodeficiencies.
  • It is not associated with the classic mandibular or abdominal organ involvement seen in other forms of Burkitt’s lymphoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mandible and kidneys: Incorrect. Mandibular involvement is characteristic of endemic Burkitt's lymphoma, and kidneys are often involved in endemic cases, not in immunodeficiency-associated types.

 

Option C. Peritoneum and ileocecum: Incorrect. Peritoneal and ileocecal involvement is more typical of sporadic Burkitt's lymphoma, particularly in association with EBV.

 

Option D. Bone marrow and peripheral blood: Incorrect. Bone marrow and peripheral blood involvement are uncommon in immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma, which mainly affects the GIT and CNS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Immunodeficiency-associated Burkitt's lymphoma typically involves the gastrointestinal tract (GIT) and central nervous system (CNS).

 

Burkitt Lymphoma Recap — 3 Clinical Variants:

 

 

  • In HIV-associated (immunodeficiency-associated) Burkitt lymphoma, there's a higher predilection for extranodal involvement, especially:
    • Central nervous system (CNS) — including leptomeningeal spread.
    • Gastrointestinal tract (GIT) — including ileocecal, stomach, and other bowel involvement.
  • CNS involvement is more common and earlier than in sporadic or endemic forms.
  • These patients may present with neurologic symptoms, seizures, and abdominal complaints.

 

Where confusion may arise:

 

Peritoneum and ileocecum (Choice C) are indeed classic for sporadic Burkitt lymphoma (Western world) - hence, C would be correct for sporadic, but not specifically for the immunodeficiency-associated form.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Minivac drain

 

  • The minivac drain is a negative-pressure drain, a smaller version of the Romovac drain, primarily used in procedures such as sentinel lymph node biopsies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Jackson Pratt drain: Jackson Pratt drain is a larger negative-pressure drain used in major surgeries.

 

Option B. Chest tube: Chest tube is used to drain air or fluid from the pleural space.

 

Option D. Penrose drain: Penrose drain is a passive drain that works by gravity without suction.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The minivac drain is a small negative-pressure drain designed for specific procedures like sentinel lymph node biopsies.

choices.text: Health Organization of the League of Nations

questions.text: In a historical analysis of early health diplomacy, a researcher examines the evolution of global health collaboration. Specifically, the researcher focuses on the transition from the Pan American Sanitary Bureau to a broader international health organization. Which of the following health organizations, established in 1923, served as a precursor to the World Health Organization (WHO) in terms of global health policy and collaboration?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Health Organization of the League of Nations

 

  • The Health Organization of the League of Nations, established in 1923, was a key precursor to the World Health Organization (WHO). 
  • The League's Health Organization laid the groundwork for global health governance, which the WHO later expanded upon. 
  • This organization focused on addressing international health issues and coordinating health policy among nations, thereby significantly contributing to the development of the WHO in 1948.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Pan American Health Organization (PAHO): Pan American Health Organization (PAHO): While PAHO has played a critical role in the health sector, it was established in 1902 and was separate from the League of Nations. It is still an important regional office for the WHO but is not the direct precursor to the WHO.

 

Option C. United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF): United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF): Established in 1946, UNICEF focuses on children's health and welfare, not as a precursor to the WHO in global health collaboration.

 

Option D. International Labour Organization (ILO): International Labour Organization (ILO): The ILO, founded in 1919, focuses on labor rights and working conditions, but it does not serve as a precursor to the WHO for global health policy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The first international health agency to be established was the Pan American Sanitary Bureau (PASB) in 1902.
  • This was followed by the establishment of the Health Organization of the League of Nations in 1923.
  • The World Health Organisation (WHO) was established on 7th April 1948.

choices.text: Risk of secretory diarrhoea due to interference with 5-ASA
Monitoring for thyroid dysfunction during treatment with methotrexate
Regular screening for peptic ulcer disease due to prednisone therapy

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with moderate Crohn’s disease has failed conventional therapies and is started on natalizumab. Which of the following is the most important monitoring consideration for this patient during natalizumab therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)

 

  • Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody targeting the α4 integrin, used to treat moderate to severe Crohn’s disease. 
  • However, it has a serious risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), a potentially fatal brain infection caused by the JC virus. 
  • The risk of PML is heightened when natalizumab is used with other immunosuppressive therapies. 
  • Regular monitoring for PML is essential, especially in patients receiving multiple immunosuppressive drugs.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Risk of secretory diarrhoea due to interference with 5-ASA: Incorrect. Natalizumab does not cause secretory diarrhoea, a known side effect of olsalazine.
 

Option C. Monitoring for thyroid dysfunction during treatment with methotrexate: Incorrect. Methotrexate is used for Crohn’s disease but is not the focus here. Natalizumab has a much more critical monitoring requirement for PML.
 

Option D. Regular screening for peptic ulcer disease due to prednisone therapy: Incorrect. Peptic ulcer disease is a concern with corticosteroid therapy like prednisone, but the primary concern with natalizumab is PML.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Natalizumab therapy in Crohn’s disease requires careful monitoring for progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML), especially when used with other immunosuppressive agents.

questions.text:
Match the following nephron parts with their respective epithelial lining: 

 

Column A (Part of Nephron):

 

  1. Glomerulus
  2. Neck
  3. Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT)
  4. DCT

 

Column B (Epithelial Lining):


A. Simple Cuboidal or Columnar with brush border
B. Simple Squamous with podocyte cells
C. Simple Squamous
D. Simple Cuboidal without brush border
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-C, 3-A, 4-D

 

  1. Glomerulus (1-B): The glomerulus is lined by simple squamous epithelium with specialized podocyte cells. Podocytes are crucial for filtration, forming the filtration barrier in Bowman's capsule.
  2. Neck (2-C): The neck of the nephron is lined by simple squamous epithelium, which ensures smooth transition of the filtrate into the proximal tubule.
  3. Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT) (3-A): The PCT is lined by simple cuboidal or columnar epithelium with a brush border to increase surface area for reabsorption of water, ions, and nutrients.
  4. DCT (4-D): These segments are lined by simple cuboidal epithelium without a brush border.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The nephron's structure is closely related to its function, with specialized epithelial linings like podocytes in the glomerulus for filtration, brush border epithelium in the PCT for reabsorption, and simple squamous epithelium in the thin loop of Henle for passive diffusion.

choices.text: Direct PCR testing of the virus

questions.text: A pregnant woman is screened for CMV and the result shows positive IgG antibodies. To determine if the infection is primary, which of the following tests would most likely be helpful?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IgG avidity test

 

  • The IgG avidity test helps distinguish between primary and past CMV infections by assessing the strength of IgG binding to the virus. 
  • In primary infection, IgG has low avidity, which increases over time.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Direct PCR testing of the virus: PCR testing detects viral DNA but does not provide information about IgG avidity.
 

Option C. HIV test: HIV testing is unrelated to CMV infection status.
 

Option D. IgM test: IgM testing could indicate acute infection, but the IgG avidity test is more specific for distinguishing primary versus past infection.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The IgG avidity test is used to differentiate between primary and past CMV infections based on IgG binding strength.

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with osteoporosis is being treated with zoledronate. Which of the following is the most serious adverse effect associated with zoledronate use?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Acute renal failure

 

  • Zoledronate, a bisphosphonate, is used in the treatment of osteoporosis and to prevent fractures.
  •  Acute renal failure is a known serious adverse effect of zoledronate, particularly when the patient has pre-existing renal dysfunction or inadequate hydration. 
  • Monitoring renal function before and during treatment is essential to prevent this side effect.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ventricular fibrillation: Incorrect. Ventricular fibrillation is not a common adverse effect of zoledronate, though it may occur in severely ill patients, but it is not directly related to the drug.
 

Option C. Peptic ulcer: Incorrect. Peptic ulcers are not a significant adverse effect of zoledronate. This side effect is more commonly associated with NSAIDs and corticosteroids.
 

Option D. Anterior uveitis: Incorrect. Anterior uveitis is a rare but known side effect of bisphosphonates like zoledronate, but it is not the most common or serious adverse effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Zoledronate can cause acute renal failure as a serious adverse effect, and renal function should be monitored regularly during treatment.

choices.text: The nymph and adult life stages of the mite transmit the infection to humans when they feed on vertebrate animals.
The infection is transmitted to humans only by the larval stage of the mite.
The infection can only be maintained in adult mites, which pass the infection to the larvae through transstadial transmission.
Both nymphs and larvae of the mite feed on vertebrates and can transmit the disease to humans.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the lifecycle of the mite responsible for transmitting Orientia tsutsugamushi to humans?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The infection is transmitted to humans only by the larval stage of the mite.

 

  • The larval (chigger) stage of the mite is the only one that can transmit Orientia tsutsugamushi to humans by feeding on vertebrates. 
  • The nymph and adult stages do not feed on vertebrates and thus do not transmit the infection. 
  • The larvae are infected by feeding on small mammals that harbor the bacteria, and the infection is then passed to humans when they encounter these infected larvae.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. The nymph and adult life stages of the mite transmit the infection to humans when they feed on vertebrate animals: Only the larval stage of the mite transmits the infection to humans, not the nymph or adult stages.
 

Option C. The infection can only be maintained in adult mites, which pass the infection to the larvae through transstadial transmission: The infection is maintained in mites via both transstadial (larva to adult) and transovarial (adult to egg) transmission.
 

Option D. Both nymphs and larvae of the mite feed on vertebrates and can transmit the disease to humans: Nymphs and adults do not feed on vertebrates and are not involved in the transmission to humans.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The larval stage of the mite is the only life stage that can transmit Orientia tsutsugamushi to humans.

choices.text: The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum.
The appendicular artery is an end artery
Neuroendocrine tumors of the appendix arise from the mucosal cells present at the base of the crypts
There is abundant lymphoid tissue in the sub-mucosa of the appendix

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement concerning the anatomy of the appendix?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Neuroendocrine tumors of the appendix arise from the mucosal cells present at the base of the crypts
