  • Neuro endocrine tumours (NETS’s) arise from the argentaffin cells (Kulchitsky) which are situated at the base of the crypts, not mucosal cells. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The base of the appendix is found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum: The position of the base of the appendix is constant, being found at the confluence of the three taeniae coli of the caecum, which fuse to form the outer longitudinal muscle coat of the appendix. 

 

Option B. The appendicular artery is an end artery: Appendicular artery is an ‘end-artery’, thrombosis of which results in necrosis of the appendix. 

 

Option D. There is abundant lymphoid tissue in the sub-mucosa of the appendix: The submucosa contains numerous lymphatic aggregations or follicles. The prominence of lymphatic tissue in the appendix of young adults seems to be important in the etiology of appendicitis. 

 

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Neuro endocrine tumours (NETS’s) arise from the argentaffin cells (Kulchitsky cells) and not the mucosal cells which are situated at the base of the crypts.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about HELLP syndrome are correct?

 

  1. Platelet count is often below 100,000/mm³.
  2. Hemolysis is diagnosed using peripheral smear findings.
  3. Liver enzymes are normal in most cases.
  4. It is a variant of preeclampsia.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 4 only

 

Statement 1- Platelet count is reduced (<100,000/mm³).

 

Statement 2- Hemolysis is identified by abnormal peripheral smear.

 

Statement 4- HELLP syndrome is a variant of preeclampsia.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 3: Elevated liver enzymes are a hallmark of HELLP syndrome, so this statement is incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HELLP syndrome is a severe variant of preeclampsia involving hemolysis, thrombocytopenia, and elevated liver enzymes.

choices.text: Flutamide inhibits DHT production by reducing the activity of 5-reductase.
Flutamide binds to androgen receptors, preventing androgen activation and inhibiting tumor growth.
Flutamide enhances the action of GnRH agonists by increasing testosterone production.
Flutamide reduces the size of the prostate by inhibiting DHT production in the prostate.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male with metastatic prostate cancer is started on flutamide in combination with a GnRH agonist. Which of the following best describes the role of flutamide in this therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flutamide binds to androgen receptors, preventing androgen activation and inhibiting tumor growth.

 

  • Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist that works by blocking the effects of testosterone and DHT at the androgen receptor, thus inhibiting the growth of androgen-dependent prostate cancer cells. 
  • It is commonly used in combination with GnRH agonists, which lower testosterone production, to treat metastatic prostate cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flutamide inhibits DHT production by reducing the activity of 5-reductase: Incorrect, Flutamide does not affect DHT production directly; it works by blocking androgen receptors.

 

Option C. Flutamide enhances the action of GnRH agonists by increasing testosterone production: Incorrect, Flutamide does not increase testosterone production but blocks androgen effects.

 

Option D. Flutamide reduces the size of the prostate by inhibiting DHT production in the prostate: Incorrect, Flutamide does not affect prostate size but inhibits the androgen receptor to reduce tumor growth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Flutamide is an androgen receptor antagonist used in combination with GnRH agonists to treat metastatic prostate cancer by blocking androgen activity.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about sperm capacitation are true?

 

  1. It occurs in the female genital tract.
  2. It involves cyclic AMP-dependent phosphorylation and increased intracellular pH.
  3. It takes about 2-6 hours.
  4. It is completed in the testis.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

Statement 1, 2 and 3:  Sperm capacitation is a crucial physiological process that occurs in the female genital tract, preparing sperm for fertilization. This process involves biochemical changes, including cyclic AMP-dependent phosphorylation and an increase in intracellular pH, which enhance sperm motility and facilitate the acrosome reaction necessary for penetration of the oocyte. Capacitation typically takes about 2-6 hours and is influenced by factors in the female reproductive tract. Importantly, this process is not completed in the testis; rather, spermatozoa acquire motility and fertilization potential only after undergoing capacitation post-ejaculation.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 4: It is completed in the testis: Incorrect because capacitation does not occur in the testis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Capacitation is a biochemical process in the female reproductive tract that prepares sperm for fertilization.

choices.text: (a) Buccopharyngeal Fascia, (b) Pharyngobasilar Fascia, (c) Muscular Coat (d) Mucous Membrane
(a) Pharyngobasilar Fascia, (b) Buccopharyngeal Fascia, (c) Muscular Coat (d) Mucous Membrane.
(a) Mucous Membrane, (b) Pharyngobasilar Fascia, (c) Muscular Coat (d) Buccopharyngeal Fascia.
(a) Buccopharyngeal Fascia, (b) Mucous Membrane, (c) Muscular Coat (d) Pharyngobasilar Fascia.

questions.text: Identify the structures of pharyngeal wall.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) (a) Mucous Membrane, (b) Pharyngobasilar Fascia, (c) Muscular Coat (d) Buccopharyngeal Fascia

 

This is the correct sequence. The Mucous membrane (a) is the innermost layer that lines the pharynx. Beneath the mucous membrane is the Pharyngobasilar Fascia (b), which is a Fibrous Layer. The Muscular Coat (c) is beneath the Pharyngobasilar fascia and is responsible for the pharyngeal constrictions during swallowing. The Buccopharyngeal fascia (d) is the outermost layer that defines the pharyngeal wall's interface with the retropharyngeal space and other structures.

 

Structure of Pharyngeal Wall 

 

From within outwards it consists of four layers:

 

  1. Mucous Membrane
  2. Pharyngeal Aponeurosis (Pharyngobasilar Fascia)
  3. Muscular Coat
  4. Buccopharyngeal Fascia

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct anatomical sequence of the pharyngeal wall layers from innermost to outermost is: mucous membrane, pharyngobasilar fascia, muscular coat, and buccopharyngeal fascia.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man is diagnosed with a Corynebacterium diphtheriae infection. The laboratory confirms the presence of volutin granules in the bacteria using Albert’s stain. Which of the following chemical components is primarily responsible for the formation of these granules?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Polyphosphate

 

  • The volutin granules or metachromatic granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae are primarily composed of polyphosphate. 
  • These high-molecular-weight polymers are stored by the bacteria and can be visualized using Albert's stain.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. RNA: RNA is not a primary component of volutin granules.
 

Option C.Lipopolysaccharide: Lipopolysaccharide is a major component of the outer membrane of Gram-negative bacteria, but not of volutin granules.


Option D. Peptidoglycan: Peptidoglycan forms the bacterial cell wall but is not associated with volutin granules.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Volutin granules in Corynebacterium diphtheriae are composed of polyphosphate and can be visualized using Albert’s stain.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman undergoes a vaginal delivery. After delivery, you observe that the placenta separates from the center and is delivered fetal side first. Which of the following methods of placental separation is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schultz method

 

  • Schultz method involves separation from the center, with blood collecting behind the placenta and the fetal side appearing first during delivery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duncan method: Duncan method involves separation from the periphery, with the maternal side appearing first.

 

Option C. Active management method & Option D. Expectant management method: These are methods of managing the third stage of labor, not types of placental separation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Schultz and Duncan methods describe different mechanisms of placental separation based on the site of detachment.

questions.text: A 57-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with complaints of difficulty in speaking after a stroke. Upon examination, he has reduced speech output but is able to understand spoken and written language. His speech is effortful and telegraphic, with predominantly content words. Which of the following areas is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Broca's area

 

  • Located in the inferior frontal gyrus (Brodmann's area 44), it is responsible for motor speech functions, including word formation. 
  • A lesion in this area leads to Broca’s aphasia, characterized by reduced speech output, effortful speech, and intact comprehension.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Wernicke's area: Located in the superior temporal gyrus, it is responsible for language comprehension. A lesion here causes fluent but nonsensical speech (Wernicke’s aphasia), which is not consistent with the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. Angular gyrus: Involved in language, number processing, and spatial cognition, lesions here do not typically cause speech production deficits.

 

Option D. Primary auditory cortex: Responsible for processing auditory information, its lesion results in hearing impairments rather than speech production issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A lesion in Broca's area results in Broca’s aphasia, characterized by effortful speech with intact comprehension.

questions.text:
Match the Following: Intermediate Filaments as Markers of tumors / conditions

 

Column A

  1. Keratin
  2. Desmin
  3. Vimentin
  4. Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP)
  5. Lamin

 

Column B

  1. Sarcomas
  2. Epithelial carcinomas
  3. Astrocytomas
  4. Mesenchymal tumors
  5. Progeria
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-B, 2-A, 3-D, 4-C, 5-E

 

1-B: Keratin is found in epithelial tissue and is a marker for epithelial carcinomas.
 

2-A: Desmin is present in muscle tissue and is a marker for sarcomas.
 

3-D: Vimentin is found in connective tissue (fibroblasts) and is a marker for mesenchymal tumors.
 

4-C: Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is abundant in astrocytes and is a marker for astrocytomas.
 

5-E: Lamin is found in the nucleus and is a marker for Progeria (premature aging).

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Keratin is found in epithelial tissue and is a marker for epithelial carcinomas.
  • Desmin is present in muscle tissue and is a marker for sarcomas.
  • Vimentin is found in connective tissue (fibroblasts) and is a marker for mesenchymal tumors.
  • Glial fibrillary acidic protein (GFAP) is abundant in astrocytes and is a marker for astrocytomas.
  • Lamin is found in the nucleus and is a marker for Progeria (premature aging).

questions.text:
A 10-month-old infant presents with an abdominal mass and features such as macroglossia and umbilical hernia. Genetic testing confirms Wilms' tumor. Which of the following statements are true regarding the underlying syndrome?

 

  1. The syndrome is associated with hemihypertrophy.
  2. It involves an overgrowth disorder caused by IGF-2 dysregulation.
  3. The risk of Wilms’ tumor decreases after 8 years of age.
  4. The most likely diagnosis is Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome.
questions.solution:
Ans. D) All of the above

 

1. True: Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is associated with hemihypertrophy.

 

2. True: It is caused by IGF-2 dysregulation, leading to overgrowth.

 

3. True: The risk of Wilms’ tumor significantly decreases after 8 years.

 

4. True: The clinical presentation strongly suggests Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome is an overgrowth disorder associated with hemihypertrophy and Wilms’ tumor.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents with right arm weakness and clumsiness that has progressively worsened over several months, causing her to drop objects. She has also had stumbling episodes over the last month. She denies headaches, vision problems, or vertigo. Her past medical history is notable for acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in childhood, for which she received combination chemotherapy, cranial irradiation, and intrathecal chemotherapy.

 

  • Vitals: BP 111/68 mm Hg, pulse 68/min
  • Physical exam:
    • Pronator drift on the right side
    • Deep tendon reflexes symmetric
    • Romberg test negative, but mild instability on tandem walking
    • No lymphadenopathy, carotid bruits, heart murmurs, or splenomegaly

 

Brain imaging in this patient would most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Meningioma

 

  • This patient has a progressively worsening focal neurological deficit (right arm weakness, clumsiness, pronator drift) and gait instability, which strongly suggests a space-occupying lesion affecting the motor cortex or corticospinal tract. 
  • Given her history of cranial irradiation for childhood leukemia, she is at high risk for developing radiation-induced meningioma, which is the most common secondary brain tumor in patients with prior radiation exposure. 
  • Meningiomas are slow-growing, extra-axial tumors, often presenting with gradually progressive focal neurological deficits without systemic symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Berry aneurysm: Typically presents with sudden subarachnoid hemorrhage (severe headache, loss of consciousness, neck stiffness, vomiting) rather than progressive focal deficits.

 

Option B. Glioblastoma: A primary aggressive brain tumor that would cause rapidly progressive symptoms, significant edema, and mass effect, which this patient lacks.

 

Option C. Intracranial infection: Brain abscess or chronic infections present with fever, systemic symptoms, and signs of increased intracranial pressure (ICP) like headache, nausea, vomiting, and papilledema), none of which are present here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Radiation-induced meningioma is a common long-term complication of childhood cranial irradiation. 
  • It typically presents years later with slow-onset focal neurological deficits and is best diagnosed with brain imaging.

choices.text: Egg → Miracidium → Sporocyst → Redia → Cercaria → Adult worm
Egg → Miracidium → Sporocyst → Redia → Cercaria → Metacercaria → Adult worm
Egg → Metacercaria → Miracidium → Sporocyst → Redia → Adult worm
Egg → Cercaria → Metacercaria → Sporocyst → Adult worm

questions.text: A 45-year-old man from a rural area presents with abdominal discomfort and jaundice. His stool analysis reveals operculated eggs. Which of the following represents the correct sequence of stages from egg to adult worm in the human host?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Egg → Miracidium → Sporocyst → Redia → Cercaria → Metacercaria → Adult worm

 

  • The correct life cycle of Fasciola hepatica involves eggs being excreted in the feces, which hatch into miracidia. 
  • The miracidia infect snails and develop into sporocysts, which in turn produce rediae.
  • The rediae then give rise to cercariae which swim freely and encyst on aquatic plants as metacercariae. 
  • The metacercariae are then ingested by the definitive host (humans) and mature into adult worms in the bile ducts.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The life cycle of Fasciola hepatica includes the stages egg → miracidium → sporocyst → redia→ Cercaria → metacercaria → adult worm in humans.

choices.text: Adjust insulin dose for strict glycemic control and follow up in several weeks
Discontinue lisinopril and repeat laboratory testing in 6 weeks
Initiate sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor therapy and repeat laboratory testing in 6 weeks

questions.text: A 63-year-old man from Chennai, diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus 8 years ago, presents with mild swelling in his legs and fatigue for the past 2 weeks. He has no shortness of breath, orthopnea, nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Over the past year, he had albuminuria on two separate occasions. Three months ago, his BP was 122/78 mm Hg, serum creatinine was 1.2 mg/dL, urine albumin/creatinine ratio was 250 mg/g, and HbA1c was 7.2%. He has been on lisinopril for a year, with a dose increase 3 months ago. His current BP is 155/95 mm Hg, and examination reveals 2+ bilateral pitting edema. Labs show elevated creatinine (1.8 mg/dL), albumin (3.1 g/dL), and RBC casts in urinalysis. Renal ultrasound reveals normal-sized kidneys. What’s the next step to find the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Discuss ultrasound-guided renal biopsy

 

  • This patient with long-standing diabetes, worsening renal function, albuminuria, hematuria, and RBC casts suggests a condition beyond diabetic nephropathy. 
  • While diabetic nephropathy presents with albuminuria and progressive renal dysfunction, hematuria with RBC casts is not a typical feature. 
  • The presence of these findings raises concern for an alternative diagnosis such as IgA nephropathy, membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, or another glomerular disease. 
  • A renal biopsy is warranted to confirm the underlying pathology and guide management.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Adjust insulin dose for strict glycemic control and follow up in several weeks: While glycemic control is essential, it will not address the underlying cause of hematuria, RBC casts, and worsening kidney function. Further evaluation is necessary.

 

Option B. Discontinue lisinopril and repeat laboratory testing in 6 weeks: ACE inhibitors can cause a mild rise in creatinine, but they do not typically cause hematuria or RBC casts. Stopping lisinopril without further investigation may lead to worsening kidney disease.

 

Option D. Initiate SGLT2 inhibitor therapy and repeat laboratory testing in 6 weeks: SGLT2 inhibitors are beneficial for diabetic nephropathy, but the presence of hematuria and RBC casts suggests a non-diabetic cause of kidney disease, requiring biopsy for definitive diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Diabetic nephropathy is characterized by albuminuria and progressive renal dysfunction without significant hematuria. 
  • When a diabetic patient presents with hematuria, RBC casts, and a rapid decline in renal function, alternative glomerular diseases should be suspected, necessitating a renal biopsy for accurate diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common complication of Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography (ERCP)?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pancreatitis

 

  • Post-ERCP pancreatitis is the most common complication of the procedure.
  • It occurs due to irritation or injury to the pancreas, leading to inflammation. 
  • Symptoms can include abdominal pain, nausea, and elevated pancreatic enzyme levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Duodenal perforation: Duodenal perforation is a rare but serious complication, occurring when the endoscope or instruments create a hole in the intestinal wall.

 

Option B. Cholangitis: Cholangitis is an infection of the bile ducts, typically resulting from bacterial spread, especially in the presence of bile duct obstruction.

 

Option C. Hemorrhage: Hemorrhage can occur, particularly following sphincterotomy, but it is not as common as pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Post-ERCP pancreatitis is the most common complication following ERCP, requiring careful risk assessment and monitoring to prevent and manage adverse outcomes.

questions.text:
Consider the following statements about Benzodiazepine use: 

Statement 1: The duration of action of diazepam is longer than alprazolam

Statement 2: Lorazepam is preferred in liver disease

Statement 3: Clonazepam has the highest potency among benzodiazepines

Statement 4: Elderly patients should be started on half the adult dose
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 4 are correct

 

Statement 1: The duration of action of diazepam is longer than alprazolam 

 

  • Diazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine with a half-life of 20-50 hours, whereas alprazolam is a short-acting benzodiazepine with a half-life of 6-12 hours.
  • Diazepam has active metabolites (e.g., desmethyldiazepam) that further prolong its action.

 

Statement 2: Lorazepam is preferred in liver disease 

 

  • Lorazepam, oxazepam, and temazepam ("LOT" drugs) are preferred in patients with liver disease because they are not metabolized by the liver's cytochrome P450 system. Instead, they undergo direct conjugation and are excreted renally, reducing the risk of drug accumulation.

 

Statement 4: Elderly patients should be started on half the adult dose Benzodiazepines can cause excessive sedation, cognitive impairment, and fall risk in elderly patients.

 

  • To minimize these risks, lower initial doses (typically half the adult dose) are recommended, with careful titration as needed.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 3: Clonazepam has the highest potency among benzodiazepines

 

  • Clonazepam is highly potent, but it does not have the highest potency among all benzodiazepines. Alprazolam and triazolam have even higher potency per milligram. Clonazepam is a long-acting benzodiazepine primarily used in seizure disorders and panic disorders, but it is not the most potent in clinical settings.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Benzodiazepines vary in their duration of action, metabolism, and potency, making their selection important based on patient-specific factors. 
  • Diazepam is long-acting, while lorazepam is preferred in liver disease due to its metabolism via direct conjugation.
  • Clonazepam is potent but not the most potent benzodiazepine, and elderly patients should be started on half the adult dose to reduce the risk of excessive sedation and falls. 
  • Proper selection and dosing can optimize efficacy while minimizing side effects.

choices.text: A Type I error has occurred because the null hypothesis is rejected with a P-value less than α.
The P-value is greater than the significance level, meaning the null hypothesis should be rejected.
The Type II error rate is at its maximum, indicating no significant difference.
The P-value is less than α, so the null hypothesis is rejected, and the result is statistically significant.

questions.text: A study reports a P-value of 0.03 and declares the results statistically significant with a significance level (α) set at 0.05. Which of the following statements is true based on this information?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The P-value is less than α, so the null hypothesis is rejected, and the result is statistically significant.

 

  • Since the P-value (0.03) is less than the significance level (α = 0.05), the null hypothesis is rejected, and the results are declared statistically significant. 
  • This does not necessarily mean the treatment is effective, but that there is a statistical difference according to the set threshold.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A Type I error has occurred because the null hypothesis is rejected with a P-value less than α: Incorrect. A Type I error would occur if the null hypothesis is true, but is incorrectly rejected, not simply by having a P-value less than α.

 

Option B. The P-value is greater than the significance level, meaning the null hypothesis should be rejected: Incorrect. Since the P-value is less than α, the null hypothesis should be rejected, not accepted.

 

Option C. The Type II error rate is at its maximum, indicating no significant difference: Incorrect. Type II error occurs when the null hypothesis is false, but is not rejected, which is not the case here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A P-value less than α indicates that the result is statistically significant, meaning the null hypothesis is rejected.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the sleep clinic with complaints of poor sleep quality. During an EEG study, his brain shows waves with a frequency of less than 4 Hz. These waves are primarily associated with deep sleep stages. Which of the following EEG waves is most likely recorded?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Delta wave

 

  • These waves have a frequency of less than 4 Hz and are the hallmark of deep sleep (NREM stages 3 and 4). 
  • They are generated during the most restorative stages of sleep and indicate slow-wave activity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alpha wave: These waves have a frequency of 8–13 Hz and are seen during a relaxed state with eyes closed but not sleeping.

 

Option B. Beta wave: These waves, with a frequency of 14–30 Hz, are associated with an alert and attentive state, generated from the frontal cortex.

 

Option D. Theta wave: These waves have a frequency of 4–7 Hz and are seen during light NREM sleep and memory processing, generated from the hippocampus.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Parents bring their 2-year-old son with concerns about his development. The child does not respond to his name, doesn't make eye contact, plays alone, lines up toys repeatedly, gets very upset if his routine is changed, and has not spoken any words yet. He started walking at 13 months. His birth and early development were normal until 18 months when his parents noticed he stopped saying "mama" and "dada". What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD)

 

The child exhibits multiple core features of Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD):

 

  • Social communication deficits → No response to his name, lack of eye contact, prefers playing alone
  • Restricted, repetitive behaviors → Lining up toys, distress with routine changes
  • Regression of language skills → Previously said "mama" and "dada" but lost these words around 18 months
  • Normal motor development → Walked at 13 months, ruling out broader motor deficits

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Normal developmental variation 

 

  • By 12 months, most children respond to their name and point to objects of interest.
    • By 2 years, children should be saying at least 50 words and using two-word phrases.
    • This child’s loss of language and social engagement is not a normal variation.

 

Option B. Language delay

 

  • Language delay alone does not explain the social deficits, repetitive behaviors, and regression.
    • Children with isolated language delay still engage socially, respond to their name, and show joint attention (e.g., pointing to share interest).

 

Option D. Global developmental delay 

 

  • Global developmental delay (GDD) affects two or more domains (e.g., motor, cognitive, social, language).
    • This child’s motor development (walking at 13 months) is normal, making GDD less likely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is characterized by social communication deficits and restricted, repetitive behaviors.
  • Language regression at ~18 months is a common early sign. Early diagnosis is crucial for initiating early intervention therapy (e.g., applied behavior analysis, speech therapy) to improve outcomes.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about Rubella infection in pregnancy are correct?

 

  1. Rubella infection is most teratogenic when it occurs before 16 weeks of gestation.
  2. Congenital rubella syndrome includes a triad of cataracts, congenital heart defects, and SNHL.
  3. Rubella vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.
  4. Rubella IgG testing is not recommended in pregnant women.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3 only

 

Statement 1: Rubella is highly teratogenic in the first trimester. 

 

  • Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) occurs when a fetus is infected with rubella, particularly in the first trimester and up to 16 weeks of gestation. The risk of fetal malformations is highest before 11 weeks (90%) and declines after 16 weeks. After 20 weeks of gestation, rubella infection rarely causes congenital anomalies.

 

Statement 2: The triad includes cataracts, congenital heart defects, and SNHL.

 

  • CRS is classically characterized by the Gregg’s triad:
    • Ophthalmic defects – Cataracts, microphthalmia, glaucoma.
    • Cardiac anomalies – Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA), pulmonary artery stenosis.
    • Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) – The most common sequela of CRS.
    • Other manifestations include growth restriction, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and "blueberry muffin" rash.

 

Statement 3: Rubella vaccine, as live attenuated, is contraindicated during pregnancy.

 

Other Option:

 

Statement 4: Incorrect: Rubella IgG testing is recommended in pregnant women.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Rubella infection in early pregnancy is highly teratogenic, and vaccination during pregnancy is contraindicated.

questions.text: Which one of the following amino acids is most likely to be found in the transmembrane region of a protein?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Leucine

 

  • The transmembrane region of a protein is typically embedded within the lipid bilayer of the cell membrane. 
  • The key characteristic of this region is that it is hydrophobic in nature. 
  • Amino acids with hydrophobic side chains are more likely to be found in this region, as they can interact favorably with the hydrophobic interior of the lipid bilayer.
  • Leucine is a hydrophobic amino acid, making it well-suited for insertion into the transmembrane region. 
  • It is classified as a nonpolar amino acid with a hydrophobic side chain, which allows it to integrate into the hydrophobic core of the membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysine: Lysine is a positively charged (basic) amino acid, making it hydrophilic rather than hydrophobic. Hydrophilic amino acids are more likely to be found on the outer surface of the membrane, interacting with the aqueous environment, rather than being buried in the transmembrane region.

 

Option B. Arginine: Arginine is also a positively charged (basic) amino acid, which makes it hydrophilic. Like lysine, it is more likely to be located on the surface of the protein in contact with the aqueous environment rather than being embedded in the hydrophobic interior of the lipid bilayer.

 

Option D. Aspartate: Aspartate is a negatively charged (acidic) amino acid, making it hydrophilic as well. Similar to lysine and arginine, it is more likely to be found on the surface of the protein, interacting with water, rather than within the hydrophobic transmembrane region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Amino acids with hydrophobic side chains, such as leucine, isoleucine, valine, and phenylalanine, are typically found in the transmembrane regions of membrane proteins. 
  • These hydrophobic amino acids interact favorably with the lipid bilayer, whereas hydrophilic amino acids (like lysine, arginine, and aspartate) are found on the exterior of the membrane, interacting with the aqueous environment.

choices.text: ECG, echocardiography, vital capacity, and ABG
ECG, echocardiography, and vital capacity only
ECG and serum creatine kinase only

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presents with a sign as shown in the image below. Which of the following tests should be part of routine surveillance?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) ECG, echocardiography, and vital capacity only

 

  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene leading to progressive muscle weakness.
  • Gower’s sign (shown in the image) is a classic feature of proximal muscle weakness, particularly in pelvic girdle muscles.
  • Routine surveillance in DMD includes:
    1. ECG & echocardiography: DMD is associated with dilated cardiomyopathy and conduction abnormalities (e.g., sinus tachycardia, AV block).
    2. Vital capacity measurement: Progressive muscle weakness affects the diaphragm and intercostal muscles, leading to restrictive lung disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ECG, echocardiography, vital capacity, and ABG: ABG is not routinely indicated unless advanced respiratory compromise develops.

 

Option C and D: Serum CK is diagnostic, not used for surveillance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • DMD requires regular monitoring of cardiac and respiratory functions through ECG, echocardiography, and vital capacity testing.

questions.text: The image below is most commonly seen in which of the following scenarios?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Windshield glass injury

 

  • The image shows lacerations resembling ‘sparrow foot marks’ which are seen in motor vehicle accidents when the skin comes in contact with shattered windshield glass.

 

Sparrow foot marks

 

  1. Sparrow’s foot marks are bizarre shaped lacerations that result from the face coming in contact with shattered windshield glass. The toughened glass breaks into small fragments which produce characteristic ‘sparrow foot marks’.
  2. These patterns resemble the imprints of bird footprints, with multiple lines radiating outward from a central point.
  3.  Seen in people sitting in front seats in motor vehicle in road traffic accidents.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Gunshot injuries: A gunshot wound can appear as a small, round entrance wound, often with an abrasion ring if the gun was fired at close range. Exit wounds are typically larger, irregular, and may have beveled edges.

 

Option B. Stab injury of face: Stab injury of face, Wound Stab wounds are typically linear or elongated, with a well-defined shape, resembling a slit or puncture. It doesn’t resemble with sparrow footmarks.

 

Option C. Vitriolage: Vitriolage or acid attack, the resulting wound is characterized by severe chemical burns and deep tissue damage. These wounds have irregular shapes, often resembling deep craters with irregular edges. The corrosive nature of the acid causes tissue necrosis, leading to open wounds and extensive scarring as the wounds heal.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • "Sparrow foot marks" are distinctive lacerations seen in motor vehicle accidents when the face contacts shattered windshield glass. 
  • These lacerations resemble the pattern of bird footprints with multiple lines radiating outward from a central point.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man from Mumbai presents with a 4-week history of fatigue. He reports feeling "drained" by the end of the day and has reduced exercise tolerance but denies chest pain, shortness of breath, or body aches. His appetite is good, and he has had no recent weight changes. He has a history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia, managed with amlodipine and rosuvastatin. His vitals include a BP of 144/90 mm Hg and a BMI of 22 kg/m². Initial laboratory tests reveal Hb 14.2 g/dL, potassium 4.6 mEq/L, creatinine 0.8 mg/dL, and fasting glucose 98 mg/dL. An ECG is provided. What’s the next investigation to be done ?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thyroid function tests

 

  • This elderly patient with a persistent fatigue and no other clear systemic symptoms requires evaluation for common causes of fatigue, such as hypothyroidism.
  • The absence of weight loss, appetite changes, or anemia makes other causes less likely. Subclinical or overt hypothyroidism is a frequent cause of fatigue in older adults and is often underdiagnosed. 
  • Checking thyroid function tests (TSH, free T4) is a low-cost, noninvasive first step that can easily confirm or rule out hypothyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankle-brachial index: Peripheral artery disease (PAD) can cause fatigue, but it typically presents with exertional leg pain (claudication) rather than generalized fatigue. This patient has no history of leg pain or signs of vascular disease.

 

Option B. Discontinue rosuvastatin: Statins can cause myopathy leading to fatigue, but this is typically associated with muscle pain or weakness, which this patient does not report. Checking creatinine kinase (CK) would be more appropriate before discontinuing statin therapy.

 

Option D. Treadmill stress testing: While cardiovascular disease can cause fatigue due to reduced cardiac output, this patient denies chest pain, dyspnea, or other cardiac symptoms. His normal ECG does not suggest ischemia, making stress testing unnecessary at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In an elderly patient with fatigue and no clear etiology, hypothyroidism should always be considered. 
  • Thyroid function tests (TSH, free T4) should be performed as an initial step before considering other causes.

choices.text: Mildly reduced vWF antigen levels and significantly prolonged PTT with normal factor VIII activity.
Normal vWF antigen levels but absent vWF activity and low factor VIII levels.
Elevated vWF antigen levels with normal platelet aggregation in response to collagen.
Normal vWF antigen and activity, but significantly reduced factor VIII half-life.

questions.text: Which of the following laboratory findings would most likely support the diagnosis of von Willebrand disease type 1?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mildly reduced vWF antigen levels and significantly prolonged PTT with normal factor VIII activity.

 

  • Type 1 von Willebrand disease is characterized by a mild reduction in vWF antigen and activity, which results in prolonged PTT and normal factor VIII levels. 
  • The deficiency in vWF impairs platelet adhesion and reduces the stabilization of factor VIII, leading to secondary decrease in factor VIII stability, which prolongs PTT.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Normal vWF antigen levels but absent vWF activity and low factor VIII levels: Incorrect. In type 1 vWD, there is a reduction in vWF levels, but not complete absence. Also, factor VIII levels should remain normal.

 

Option C. Elevated vWF antigen levels with normal platelet aggregation in response to collagen: Incorrect. In type 1 vWD, vWF antigen levels are reduced, and there is often impaired platelet aggregation with collagen due to inadequate platelet-vWF binding.

 

Option D. Normal vWF antigen and activity, but significantly reduced factor VIII half-life: Incorrect. Type 1 vWD typically shows a reduction in vWF levels, but factor VIII half-life is shortened only when the disease is more severe or in other types of vWD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Type 1 von Willebrand disease presents with mildly reduced vWF antigen and activity and prolonged PTT, but normal factor VIII levels.

choices.text: Antinuclear antibody and double-stranded DNA antibody assay

questions.text: A 33-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of left knee pain and swelling. He has no prior joint pain, trauma, fever, rash, or systemic symptoms. His medical history includes seasonal allergies, and he takes loratadine as needed. He does not smoke, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Examination reveals a moderate left knee effusion, slight warmth without erythema, and no ligamentous laxity or joint locking. Laboratory results show elevated ESR (46 mm/hr), normal blood counts, and creatinine. X-ray reveals linear calcifications of the menisci and articular cartilage, and synovial fluid analysis shows 15,400/mm³ leukocytes (80% neutrophils) with a negative Gram stain. Which of the following additional tests is most appropriate in the evaluation of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Serum iron studies

 

  • This patient presents with acute monoarthritis with X-ray evidence of chondrocalcinosis (cartilage calcification), suggestive of calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD or pseudogout). 
  • Given his young age (33 years old), an underlying metabolic disorder should be considered, with hemochromatosis being the most common metabolic cause of CPPD. 
  • Serum iron studies (iron, ferritin, transferrin saturation) are the best next step to evaluate for hereditary hemochromatosis, which can present with early-onset arthritis, diabetes, liver dysfunction, and skin pigmentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide antibody assay: Used for diagnosing rheumatoid arthritis (RA), which presents as symmetrical polyarthritis (MCP, PIP, wrists) rather than acute monoarthritis.

 

Option B. Antinuclear antibody and double-stranded DNA antibody assay: Used for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), which typically presents with polyarthritis, rash, and systemic symptoms, not isolated acute knee arthritis with chondrocalcinosis.

 

Option C. HLA-B27 testing: Associated with spondyloarthropathies (ankylosing spondylitis, reactive arthritis, psoriatic arthritis, IBD-associated arthritis), which cause axial symptoms (back pain), enthesitis, or dactylitis, not acute monoarthritis with chondrocalcinosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease (CPPD or pseudogout) in a young patient should raise suspicion for metabolic conditions such as hemochromatosis. Serum iron studies are the best next step in evaluation.

questions.text:
Match the suture with the correct property.

 

Column A

  1. Catgut
  2. Monocryl 
  3. Vicryl 
  4. Polydioxanone

 

Column B

  1. Absorption by enzymatic degradation in 90 days
  2. Monofilament, absorbed in 180 days
  3. Braided suture, absorption by hydrolysis in 60–90 days
  4. Monofilament, less infection rate, used for subcuticular suturing
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1 – A, 2 – D, 3 – C, 4 – B

 

  • 1 - A (Catgut): Derived from sheep submucosa, catgut is absorbed by enzymatic degradation in 90 days and has a tensile strength of 21–28 days. It is rarely used in modern surgery.
  • 2 - D (Monocryl): A monofilament suture with a lower infection rate, Monocryl is commonly used for subcuticular suturing.
  • 3 - C (Vicryl): A braided suture with intertwined fibers, Vicryl is easier to handle but has a higher infection rate. It is absorbed by hydrolysis in 60–90 days and is used in bowel and bladder surgeries.
  • 4 - B (Polydioxanone): A monofilament suture absorbed in 180 days, it has similar uses to Vicryl.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand the distinct properties and applications of absorbable sutures like Catgut, Monocryl, Vicryl, and Polydioxanone for effective surgical practice.

choices.text: Ciprofloxacin induces the cytochrome P450 1A2 enzyme, increasing theophylline metabolism
Ciprofloxacin inhibits the cytochrome P450 1A2 enzyme, reducing theophylline metabolism
Theophylline increases the renal clearance of ciprofloxacin, leading to increased theophylline levels
Ciprofloxacin competes with theophylline for protein binding, causing increased free drug concentration

questions.text: A 52-year-old male with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and asthma is being treated with theophylline. He develops a urinary tract infection and is prescribed ciprofloxacin. After a few days of treatment, he develops signs of theophylline toxicity, including nausea, tachycardia, and tremors. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the increase in theophylline levels?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ciprofloxacin inhibits the cytochrome P450 1A2 enzyme, reducing theophylline metabolism

 

  • Ciprofloxacin is a known CYP1A2 inhibitor. 
  • Since theophylline is primarily metabolized by the CYP1A2 enzyme, ciprofloxacin reduces its metabolism, leading to increased plasma concentrations of theophylline. 
  • This can result in theophylline toxicity, manifested by symptoms such as nausea, tachycardia, tremors, and potentially life-threatening arrhythmias. The interaction requires monitoring and dose adjustments of theophylline when used with ciprofloxacin.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Ciprofloxacin induces the cytochrome P450 1A2 enzyme, increasing theophylline metabolism: Incorrect. Ciprofloxacin is an inhibitor, not an inducer, of CYP1A2.


Option C. Theophylline increases the renal clearance of ciprofloxacin, leading to increased theophylline levels: Incorrect. Theophylline does not increase the renal clearance of ciprofloxacin.


Option D. Ciprofloxacin competes with theophylline for protein binding, causing increased free drug concentration: Incorrect. Although protein binding interactions can occur with some drugs, the primary mechanism here is the CYP1A2 inhibition leading to reduced metabolism of theophylline.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ciprofloxacin inhibits CYP1A2, leading to reduced theophylline metabolism and an increased risk of theophylline toxicity.

questions.text:
All of the following statements about the liver are correct except: 

 

  1. The liver is covered by Glisson's capsule.
  2. Stellate cells are located in the space of Disse.
  3. Kupffer cells function as defense cells in the liver.
  4. The lobules of the liver are pentagonal in shape
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 only

 

  • The statement "The lobules of the liver are pentagonal in shape" is incorrect. The lobules of the liver are hexagonal in shape and are oriented around the terminal hepatic vein. 
  • The hexagonal lobules are the functional units of the liver.

 

Other Options:

 

1. The liver is covered by Glisson's capsule: This is correct. Glisson's capsule is a connective tissue sheath that covers the liver.

 

2. Stellate cells are located in the space of Disse: This is correct. Stellate cells in the space of Disse play a role in liver regeneration and storage of vitamin A.

 

3. Kupffer cells function as defense cells in the liver: This is correct. Kupffer cells are macrophages that reside in the liver and perform phagocytosis to eliminate pathogens and debris.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The liver is covered by Glisson's capsule and contains hexagonal lobules with sinusoidal capillaries and specialized cells, including stellate cells in the space of Disse and Kupffer cells as phagocytic defense cells. 
  • The lobules are not pentagonal but hexagonal.

questions.text: A stool sample is stained using the Modified Ziehl-Neelsen (mZN) technique. Under the microscope, bright red oocysts are observed. What organism is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Isospora belli

 

  • The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain can also be used to detect acid-fast oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Cryptosporidium and Isospora. 
  • These parasites are acid-fast, and their oocysts retain the primary stain, appearing bright red under the microscope. 
  • Isospora belli is a coccidian parasite that can cause gastrointestinal infections, particularly in immunocompromised individuals.

 

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Aspergillus fumigatus: Aspergillus fumigatus is a fungal organism and is not acid-fast, so it would not retain the stain.
 

Option C. Candida albicans: Candida albicans is a fungal organism that is not acid-fast and would not appear red in the mZN stain.
 

Option D. Entamoeba histolytica: Entamoeba histolytica is a protozoan parasite, but it does not retain the primary stain in the Modified Ziehl-Neelsen method.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • The Modified Ziehl-Neelsen stain can identify acid-fast oocysts of coccidian parasites, such as Isospora belli and Cryptosporidium, which appear red under the microscope.

choices.text: Activation of T-helper cells and cytokine release leading to vascular inflammation
Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the vessel walls, triggering complement activation
Activation of macrophages and neutrophils leading to granuloma formation
Infiltration of mast cells and eosinophils causing vascular constriction

questions.text: Which of the following immune responses is most likely responsible for the development of the condition as shown in the histopathology image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the vessel walls, triggering complement activation

 

  • Fibrinoid necrosis occurs when antigen-antibody complexes deposit in the blood vessels, leading to complement activation and cell injury. 
  • This causes fibrin leakage from blood vessels, giving the characteristic pinkish appearance. This mechanism is seen in conditions like SLE, polyarteritis nodosa, and others.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Activation of T-helper cells and cytokine release leading to vascular inflammation: Incorrect. While T-helper cells and cytokine release are involved in immune responses, fibrinoid necrosis is more directly linked to immune complex deposition rather than just vascular inflammation.
 

Option C. Activation of macrophages and neutrophils leading to granuloma formation: Incorrect. Granulomas are seen in conditions like tuberculosis, not in fibrinoid necrosis, which involves immune complex deposition and complement activation.
 

Option D. Infiltration of mast cells and eosinophils causing vascular constriction: Incorrect. Mast cells and eosinophils are involved in allergic reactions but do not cause fibrinoid necrosis in blood vessels.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Fibrinoid necrosis is caused by the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in blood vessels, leading to complement activation and fibrin leakage.

questions.text: Which pathway inhibition is observed with the inhibition of α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase in liver disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Citric acid cycle flux

 

  • Inhibition of α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, an enzyme critical for the decarboxylation and dehydrogenation of α-ketoglutarate in the citric acid cycle, results in decreased cycle flux. 
  • This leads to reduced efficiency in energy production, particularly impacting patients with liver disease where enzyme activities are compromised.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fatty acid synthesis: Incorrect as fatty acid synthesis is typically regulated by factors other than α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase activity.

 

Option C. Glycolytic activity: Incorrect because glycolytic activity is not directly affected by changes in this enzyme's activity.

 

Option D. Amino acid catabolism: Incorrect as amino acid catabolism can increase in some contexts to compensate for energy needs.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase inhibition leads to reduced citric acid cycle flux in liver disease.

questions.text:
Match the Following:

 

Column A (Conditions)

  1. Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma
  2. Adenoid Hypertrophy
  3. Killian’s Dehiscence
  4. Cholesteatoma

 

Column B (Features)

  1. Chronic foul-smelling discharge with keratin debris in attic retraction pockets
  2. Nasal obstruction and recurrent epistaxis in adolescent males
  3. Retraction pocket caused by negative pressure above the esophageal sphincter
  4. Mouth breathing, high-arched palate, and crowded teeth
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-B, 2-D, 3-C, 4-A

 

Explanation:

 

  • 1-B (Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma): Adolescent males typically present with recurrent epistaxis and nasal obstruction due to this highly vascular tumor.
  • 2-D (Adenoid Hypertrophy): Chronic mouth breathing alters facial structure, leading to the characteristic "adenoid facies."
  • 3-C (Killian’s Dehiscence): This anatomical weakness predisposes to Zenker’s diverticulum above the esophageal sphincter.
  • 4-A (Cholesteatoma): Chronic foul-smelling discharge with retraction pockets is the hallmark of this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Understand how to differentiate ENT pathologies based on their hallmark features and anatomical or clinical characteristics.

choices.text: Bipolar cautery requires a cautery pad for grounding.
It minimizes damage to nearby vital structures.
It can cut and coagulate tissues simultaneously.
It completes the circuit through the entire body.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with thyroid carcinoma is undergoing surgery. The surgeon chooses bipolar cautery for the procedure. What is the primary reason for selecting bipolar cautery in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It minimizes damage to nearby vital structures.

 

  • Bipolar cautery is localized and completes the circuit between its two tips, making it ideal for precision near vital structures such as the thyroid gland.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bipolar cautery requires a cautery pad for grounding: Incorrect as bipolar cautery does not require a cautery pad.

 

Option C. It can cut and coagulate tissues simultaneously: Bipolar cautery is limited to coagulation, unlike monopolar cautery.

 

Option D. It completes the circuit through the entire body: Bipolar cautery does not involve the entire body.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Bipolar cautery is preferred for surgeries near vital structures due to its localized and controlled current flow.

questions.text: Which management strategy is most appropriate for a hemodynamically unstable patient with a ruptured ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic salpingectomy

 

  • Laparoscopic salpingectomy is the preferred management for unstable patients with ruptured ectopic pregnancies, as it ensures definitive treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate therapy: Incorrect as methotrexate is contraindicated in unstable or ruptured cases.

 

Option C. Expectant management: Incorrect as expectant management is inappropriate for unstable cases.

 

Option D. Direct injection of hyperosmolar glucose: Incorrect as direct glucose injection is not standard for ruptured ectopic pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Laparoscopic salpingectomy is the treatment of choice for hemodynamically unstable patients with ruptured ectopic pregnancies.

choices.text: Inability of chloroquine to cross the blood-brain barrier
Genetic mutation in the Duffy blood group antigen
Drug efflux pumps mediated by Pfmdr1 gene
Resistance due to the lack of schizont formation in red blood cells

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with fever, chills, and severe headache. A blood smear reveals Plasmodium falciparum infection. Upon initiation of chloroquine therapy, the patient shows minimal improvement. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for the failure of chloroquine in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Drug efflux pumps mediated by Pfmdr1 gene

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum resistance to chloroquine is largely mediated by drug efflux pumps, specifically through the Pfmdr1 gene, which encodes an ABC transporter. 
  • This transporter pumps chloroquine out of the parasite, decreasing its efficacy. 
  • This mechanism is a key contributor to chloroquine resistance in malaria-endemic areas.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Inability of chloroquine to cross the blood-brain barrier: Chloroquine's failure is not due to its inability to cross the blood-brain barrier, as the drug is effective against the parasite in the red blood cells, not specifically the central nervous system.
 

Option B. Genetic mutation in the Duffy blood group antigen: The Duffy blood group antigen is primarily relevant in the context of Plasmodium vivax, where its absence confers protection, but it is not directly related to chloroquine resistance.
 

Option D. Resistance due to the lack of schizont formation in red blood cells: Resistance in Plasmodium falciparum does not result from a lack of schizont formation in RBCs but from mechanisms like drug efflux and mutation in the parasite’s genetic material.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chloroquine resistance in Plasmodium falciparum is mainly caused by the action of drug efflux pumps mediated by the Pfmdr1 gene, which decreases the intracellular concentration of chloroquine.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with fever, rash, and altered consciousness. Her boyfriend reports that she became increasingly confused throughout the morning. She has a history of abdominal surgery following a motor vehicle accident. Lumbar puncture confirms Gram-negative diplococci, and empiric antibiotic therapy is initiated. She is transferred to the ICU. What is the best initial choice for infectious precaution measures?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Droplet precautions

 

  • The patient has bacterial meningitis due to Neisseria meningitidis, a Gram-negative diplococcus. 
  • Meningococcal disease is transmitted via respiratory droplets, necessitating droplet precautions to prevent transmission to healthcare workers and close contacts.
  • Droplet precautions include surgical mask, gloves, gown, and eye protection when within 3-6 feet of the patient.
  • Household and close contacts should receive post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) with rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone.
  • Precautions should be continued for 24 hours after starting appropriate antibiotic therapy.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Airborne precautions: Used for tuberculosis, measles, and varicella, which are transmitted by airborne particles (<5 microns). N. meningitidis is transmitted via large respiratory droplets, not aerosols.

 

Option B. Contact precautions: Used for MRSA, VRE, C. difficile, and scabies. Meningococcal disease does not require contact isolation.

 

Option D. Standard precautions: Include hand hygiene and gloves for all patient interactions but are not sufficient for highly transmissible infections like N. meningitidis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meningococcal meningitis requires droplet precautions until the patient has received at least 24 hours of appropriate antibiotics. 
  • Close contacts should also receive post-exposure prophylaxis.

questions.text: Match the surgical blade numbers with their respective uses:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-C

 

  • Number 11 Blade: Pointed blade used for precise incision and drainage.
  • Number 12 Blade: Curved blade ideal for suture removal.
  • Numbers 10, 15, 20, 21, 22, 23: Versatile blades used for making various types of incisions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Different surgical blades are designed for specific tasks such as incisions, drainage, and suture removal, ensuring precision and safety.

choices.text: Guarantees private sector innovation and competition

questions.text: A country implements a healthcare model where the government funds all healthcare services, but these services are provided and regulated by professional groups. Which of the following best describes the potential advantages and challenges of this system?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Prevents monopolies and ensures equity

 

  • In socialized medicine, professional groups are responsible for regulating healthcare services funded by the government. 
  • This setup helps to prevent monopolies and ensures equitable access to healthcare, as no single entity controls both service delivery and regulation. 
  • The system is designed to promote social equity rather than competition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Guarantees private sector innovation and competition: Incorrect. Private sector innovation and competition are not a feature of socialized medicine, where the government provides and funds the services.

 

Option C. Promotes government-driven healthcare efficiency: Incorrect. While efficiency can be a goal, the focus in socialized medicine is on equity and professional regulation rather than government-driven control over healthcare delivery.

 

Option D. Fosters competition among healthcare practitioners: Incorrect. Competition between healthcare practitioners is actively prevented in socialized medicine, as the system is designed to ensure equitable access rather than competition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Socialized medicine ensures equitable healthcare and prevents monopolies, with professional regulation of healthcare services funded by the state.

 

Note:

choices.text: Oval cells act as stem cells for hepatic regeneration following acute injury.
They form part of the circulating blood in response to chronic inflammation.
Oval cells are activated to repopulate the liver when hepatocyte proliferation is insufficient.
They function as fibroblasts, contributing to the development of liver fibrosis.

questions.text: A pathologist notes the presence of oval cells within the liver biopsy of a 60-year-old man. Which of the following is the most accurate role of these cells?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Oval cells are activated to repopulate the liver when hepatocyte proliferation is insufficient.

 

  • In the setting of chronic liver injury, oval cells act as progenitor cells that are activated to repopulate the liver, particularly when hepatocyte proliferation is not sufficient for full regeneration. 
  • They are found in the canals of Hering and can differentiate into hepatocytes, restoring liver function in cases of prolonged damage.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oval cells act as stem cells for hepatic regeneration following acute injury: Incorrect. Oval cells are not involved in acute liver injury; instead, hepatocyte proliferation is the main mechanism for recovery after acute injury.

 

Option B. They form part of the circulating blood in response to chronic inflammation: Incorrect. Oval cells are not part of the circulating blood but are localized in the liver, particularly in the canals of Hering.

 

Option D. They function as fibroblasts, contributing to the development of liver fibrosis: Incorrect. While fibroblasts contribute to fibrosis, oval cells are involved in regeneration, not fibrosis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Oval cells are progenitor cells that play a crucial role in liver regeneration after chronic injury when hepatocyte proliferation alone is insufficient.

choices.text: Dilated renal pelvis on CT scan
Small kidney with a hypoechoic area on ultrasound
Presence of multiple echogenic spots on X-ray

questions.text: Which of the following radiographic findings is consistent with the diagnosis of Multicystic dysplastic kidney (MCDK)?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A soap-bubble appearance on ultrasound

 

  • In MCDK, ultrasonography reveals a soap-bubble appearance, which represents the presence of multiple non-communicating cysts within the kidney. 
  • This is a hallmark feature of the condition. The non-visualization of the kidney on an IVP correlates with the non-functioning nature of the affected kidney.

 

   

 

  Soap-bubble appearance

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dilated renal pelvis on CT scan: Incorrect. Dilated renal pelvis is more commonly seen in hydronephrosis rather than MCDK.

 

Option C. Small kidney with a hypoechoic area on ultrasound: Incorrect. Small kidney with a hypoechoic area is not characteristic of MCDK but could be indicative of renal atrophy or another pathology.

 

Option D. Presence of multiple echogenic spots on X-ray: Incorrect. Echogenic spots on X-ray would be more suggestive of stones or calcifications, not MCDK.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • MCDK is characterized by multiple non-communicating cysts in the kidney, leading to a soap-bubble appearance on ultrasound.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is not directly involved in recognizing microbial components but instead recognizes damaged cells as part of immune surveillance?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NOD-like receptors

 

  • NOD-like receptors are cytosolic receptors that primarily recognize bacterial peptidoglycan, a microbial component, not directly involved in recognizing damaged cells. 
  • On the other hand, other receptors like Toll-like and C-type lectin receptors also play a role in recognizing both microbial components and damaged cells.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. RIG-like receptors: Incorrect. RIG-like receptors detect viral RNA, and while their focus is on microbial pathogens, they also play a role in identifying cellular stress.
 

Option C. C-type lectin receptors: Incorrect. C-type lectin receptors are found on macrophages and dendritic cells, where they recognize microbial sugars and can interact with damaged cells.
 

Option D. Toll-like receptors: Incorrect. Toll-like receptors recognize pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs), but they also interact with damaged cells as part of immune activation.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • NOD-like receptors primarily detect bacterial components, not damaged cells, and are involved in the recognition of microbial patterns within the cytosol.
  • They are unique in that many family members (like NLRP3) are activated by host cell damage rather than microbial structures alone. This makes them central to sensing sterile inflammation, trauma, crystals (gout), and metabolic stress.

choices.text: Endothelial cell proliferation associated with a viral infection
Fibroblast proliferation in response to trauma
Malignant vascular proliferation due to immune dysregulation

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with a painful mass in his thumb that has been bothering him for several weeks. The pain is described as a sharp, localized sensation. Histology slide is given below. Which of the following is the most accurate description of the tumor's origin?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Arteriovenous structure involved in thermoregulation

 

  • Glomus tumors originate from the modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus bodies, which are specialized arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation. 
  • These structures help regulate temperature by controlling blood flow to the extremities, and the tumor arises due to abnormal growth of these structures.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Endothelial cell proliferation associated with a viral infection: Incorrect. Endothelial cell proliferation is seen in conditions like hemangiomas or Kaposi’s sarcoma, not in glomus tumors.

 

Option C. Fibroblast proliferationin response to trauma: Incorrect. Fibroblast proliferation occurs in fibromas or scar tissue formation, not in glomus tumors.

 

Option D. Malignant vascular proliferation due to immune dysregulation: Incorrect. Glomus tumors are benign, not malignant, and do not result from immune dysregulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Glomus tumors arise from modified smooth muscle cells of the glomus bodies, specialized arteriovenous structures involved in thermoregulation.

questions.text: Match the conditions involving the ear with their most appropriate management options:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1-B, 2-A, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • 1-B: Auricular hematoma requires incision and drainage followed by pressure dressing to prevent cartilage necrosis and deformation.
  • 2-A: Perichondritis, often caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, requires oral antibiotics and analgesics as initial management.
  • 3-C: External auditory canal infections (otitis externa) are treated with topical antibiotic ear drops for localized infection.
  • 4-D: Prominent ears in children are often treated with pinnaplasty to avoid psychological distress related to peer teasing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the appropriate management of common ear-related conditions based on clinical scenarios and presenting symptoms.

 

Auricular hematoma → B. Incision and drainage followed by pressure dressing

 

Perichondritis → A. Oral antibiotics and analgesics

 

External auditory canal infection → C. Topical antibiotic ear drops

 

Prominent ears in children → D. Psychological support and pinnaplasty

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteremia is treated with vancomycin. What is the primary target of vancomycin’s action in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Bacterial cell wall peptidoglycan

 

  • Vancomycin exerts its bactericidal activity primarily by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan, which is a critical component of the bacterial cell wall. 
  • This prevents elongation and cross-linking, effectively disrupting the cell wall synthesis, particularly in gram-positive organisms like MRSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 50S ribosomal subunit: Incorrect. This is the target of antibiotics like macrolides (e.g., erythromycin), not vancomycin.

 

Option C. 30S ribosomal subunit: Incorrect. This is the target of aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin), not vancomycin.

 

Option D. Bacterial DNA gyrase: Incorrect. This is the target of fluoroquinolones (e.g., ciprofloxacin), not vancomycin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Vancomycin acts by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the peptidoglycan pentapeptide in gram-positive bacteria, inhibiting cell wall synthesis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman with a history of asthma presents to the emergency department with worsening shortness of breath, wheezing, and cough. On examination, her blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg, and she has diffuse wheezing on auscultation. Laboratory tests show elevated eosinophil counts, and a chest X-ray reveals no consolidation. The patient's symptoms improve with administration of bronchodilators. Given the inflammatory nature of her condition, which of the following eicosanoids is most likely contributing to her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) LT- C4, D4, E4

 

  • In this patient with asthma, Leukotriene C4, D4, and E4 play a key role in the inflammatory response. 
  • These eicosanoids contribute to bronchospasm, intense vasoconstriction, and increased vascular permeability. 
  • The bronchospasm and wheezing seen in asthma are largely due to the actions of leukotrienes, which cause constriction of the bronchial smooth muscle and increase airway inflammation, leading to the observed symptoms. 
  • These leukotrienes are synthesized in response to inflammation and act on specific receptors in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PGI2: Incorrect. PGI2 (prostacyclin) is primarily involved in vasodilation and platelet inhibition. It is not typically associated with the bronchospasm or vasoconstriction seen in asthma.

 

Option C. TxA2: Incorrect. Thromboxane A2 causes vasoconstriction and platelet aggregation, but it is not a major contributor to the bronchospasm and airway inflammation characteristic of asthma.

 

Option D. PGE1, PGE2, PGD2: Incorrect. PGE1, PGE2, PGD2 are involved in vasodilation and inflammatory responses, but leukotrienes are more specifically implicated in bronchoconstriction in asthma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Leukotrienes C4, D4, and E4 are potent mediators in asthma and other allergic conditions, causing bronchospasm, vasoconstriction, and increased vascular permeability.

choices.text: Liver glycogen phosphorylase, causing intrahepatic glycogen build-up
Debranching enzyme, resulting in accumulation of limit dextrins

questions.text: A geneticist is investigating a newborn with marked hepatomegaly, hypotonia, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. Which enzyme deficiency should be suspected, and which substrate accumulation is most directly related to the observed symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Alpha-1,4-glucosidase, leading to lysosomal glycogen accumulation

 

  • Pompe's disease (Type II glycogen storage disease) is caused by a deficiency in lysosomal alpha-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase), which leads to the accumulation of glycogen within lysosomes. 
  • This accumulation affects multiple tissues, including the liver and heart, manifesting as hepatomegaly and cardiomyopathy. 
  • The presence of hypotonia is consistent with the systemic involvement of skeletal muscles as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liver glycogen phosphorylase, causing intrahepatic glycogen build-up: Incorrect, as liver glycogen phosphorylase deficiency typically does not cause cardiomyopathy.

 

Option C. Debranching enzyme, resulting in accumulation of limit dextrins: Incorrect, as debranching enzyme deficiency (Cori's disease, Type III) would not typically present with severe cardiomyopathy at birth.

 

Option D. Glucose-6-phosphatase, causing increased glucose-6-phosphate: Incorrect, as glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (Von Gierke’s disease, Type I) would not lead to cardiomyopathy but would primarily affect gluconeogenesis and glycogenolysis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is least likely to cause cholestatic jaundice?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ethambutol

 

  • Ethambutol, an antituberculosis drug, is generally not associated with cholestatic jaundice.
  •  While it can cause ocular toxicity (optic neuritis), it is less likely to cause liver-related adverse effects compared to the other drugs listed. 
  • The drugs listed in the other options are known to be associated with cholestatic jaundice through different mechanisms.

 

Other Options:


Option B. Chlorpromazine: Incorrect. Chlorpromazine, an antipsychotic, is known to cause cholestatic jaundice and can lead to hepatic damage as a result of the antipsychotic-induced liver injury.


Option C. Erythromycin estolate: Incorrect. Erythromycin estolate, a macrolide antibiotic, is one of the antibiotics associated with cholestatic jaundice. This occurs more frequently with the estolate form, which can cause hepatocellular and cholestatic liver injury.


Option D. Estrogens: Incorrect. Estrogens, especially in oral contraceptives and hormone replacement therapy, are well-known to cause cholestatic jaundice. This effect is related to the estrogen's impact on bile secretion and liver function.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Ethambutol does not typically cause cholestatic jaundice, whereas chlorpromazine, erythromycin estolate, and estrogens are associated with liver-related adverse effects, including cholestatic jaundice.

questions.text: A 53-year-old woman with a history of chronic migraines is being treated with methysergide to prevent migraine attacks. Which of the following is a potential serious side effect of methysergide that distinguishes it from other serotonin antagonists like ketanserin and tropisetron?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Retroperitoneal fibrosis

 

  • Methysergide is a 5-HT2 receptor antagonist used for migraine prophylaxis. One of the serious side effects associated with long-term use of methysergide is retroperitoneal fibrosis, a condition that can lead to kidney damage and other complications. 
  • This is a distinguishing side effect not commonly associated with other serotonin antagonists like ketanserin or tropisetron, which are used for different clinical purposes and have a different side effect profile.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Gastrointestinal bleeding: Incorrect. While gastrointestinal issues may occur with some serotonin antagonists, gastrointestinal bleeding is not a prominent side effect of methysergide.
 

Option C. Hypertension: Incorrect. Ketanserin, used to treat hypertension, can cause a blood pressure-lowering effect, not an increase. Methysergide is not associated with hypertension.
 

Option D. Nephrolithiasis: Incorrect. Nephrolithiasis is not typically associated with methysergide therapy and is not a common side effect of serotonin antagonists.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Methysergide, unlike other serotonin antagonists, is associated with the risk of retroperitoneal fibrosis, a serious side effect that can cause kidney and abdominal complications.

questions.text: A pediatrician is testing a baby’s hearing. When a sound is made with a toy, the baby looks at the toy diagonally. At what age is this milestone achieved?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 10 months

 

  • Diagonal localization of sound is achieved by 10 months, reflecting fine auditory-motor coordination.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Developmental progression of sound localization:

 

  • At birth to 3 months → Startles to loud sounds, turns head toward familiar voices.
  • By 4-6 months → Can turn the head laterally toward the direction of the sound.
  • By 7 months → Can localize sound horizontally (left or right).
  • By 10 months → Diagonal localization develops, where the baby can turn both laterally and vertically toward a sound source.
  • By 12 months → Full localization ability develops, allowing the baby to accurately locate a sound in any direction.

questions.text: At what cervical dilation is an epidural typically administered during labor to manage pain?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 3–4 cm

 

  • Epidural analgesia is commonly administered during the active phase of labor, typically when cervical dilation is around 3–4 cm. 
  • At this stage, the labor is established, and the patient can benefit from pain relief without significant risk of slowing labor progression.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1–2 cm: This is during the latent phase, and epidural administration at this stage is less common due to concerns about prolonging labor.

 

Option C. 5–6 cm: While epidurals can still be given, they are typically initiated earlier during the active phase.

 

Option D. 7–8 cm: This is during advanced labor, and though an epidural can be provided, it may not be as beneficial or practical at this stage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Epidural analgesia is typically administered during the active phase of labor, at 3–4 cm cervical dilation, to provide effective pain relief while minimizing the risk of labor delay.

choices.text: Evaluation of pulmonary and kidney function

questions.text: An 80-year-old man, Mr. Sharma from Mumbai, visits the physician for a preoperative assessment before undergoing elective hip replacement. He lives independently but reports occasional fatigue and difficulty rising from a chair. He has hypertension and mild chronic kidney disease, but his cardiac and pulmonary function tests are normal. His Mini-Mental Status Exam (MMSE) score is 28/30. He walks slowly and has a weak grip strength. Which of the following is the best predictor of 30-day postoperative complications and likelihood of discharge to a nursing facility?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Frailty determination

 

  • Frailty is the strongest predictor of poor postoperative outcomes, including prolonged hospital stays, complications, and nursing home discharge. 
  • It is more predictive than cardiac, pulmonary, or kidney dysfunction. Markers of frailty include weak grip strength, slow walking speed, fatigue, and reduced physical activity, all of which are present in this patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Evaluation of Cardiac status: Important but not as predictive as frailty for functional recovery and discharge needs.

 

Option B. Evaluation of Pulmonary & kidney function: Affect surgical risk but are less predictive than frailty for postoperative decline.

 

Option D. Mini-Mental Status Exam: Cognitive status matters, but frailty is a stronger predictor of surgical outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Frailty is the best predictor of postoperative complications and need for nursing care in older adults undergoing surgery.

questions.text: Based on these clinical presentations, which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

 

  • The images depict classical signs of Vitamin A deficiency. 
  • The eye manifestations include corneal xerosis, characterized by dryness of the cornea, and keratomalacia, a severe softening of the cornea, both of which can lead to blindness if untreated. 
  • The skin changes showing scaly hyperkeratotic plaques are indicative of phrynoderma, a condition associated with Vitamin A deficiency, which affects the body's ability to maintain healthy epithelial tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin D: Incorrect. Vitamin D deficiency typically presents with bone abnormalities such as rickets or osteomalacia, not with the ocular or skin changes seen in these images.
