Option C. Thiamine: Incorrect. Thiamine deficiency leads to neurological and cardiovascular symptoms, such as those seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome or beriberi, not the dermatologic or ocular manifestations noted here.

 

Option D. Riboflavin: Incorrect. Although riboflavin deficiency can cause ocular changes like angular stomatitis and cheilosis, the specific changes noted in the eye photos are more characteristic of Vitamin A deficiency.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The clinical signs of Vitamin A deficiency, include its effects on the eyes and skin, to diagnose and treat this condition effectively to prevent serious complications such as blindness and severe dermatological issues.

questions.text:
Match the fetal skull diameters in Column A with their respective borders and lengths in Column B.

 

Column A:

  1. Suboccipitobregmatic
  2. Mentovertical
  3. Biparietal
  4. Occipitofrontal

 

Column B:

  1. From midpoint of chin to highest point of sagittal suture - 14 cm
  2. Extends between two parietal eminences - 9.5 cm
  3. From nape of neck to center of bregma - 9.5 cm
  4. From occipital eminence to root of nose - 11.5 cm
questions.solution:
Ans.  D) 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-D

 

  • Suboccipitobregmatic (1-C): The diameter extends from the nape of the neck to the center of the bregma, measuring 9.5 cm.
  • Mentovertical (2-A): The diameter extends from the midpoint of the chin to the highest point of the sagittal suture, measuring 14 cm.
  • Biparietal (3-B): The diameter extends between the two parietal eminences, measuring 9.5 cm.
  • Occipitofrontal (4-D): The diameter extends from the occipital eminence to the root of the nose, measuring 11.5 cm.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The mentovertical diameter is the longest fetal diameter, measuring 14 cm, while the suboccipitobregmatic and biparietal diameters are both 9.5 cm, critical for understanding the mechanics of fetal skull measurements during labor.

choices.text: The gallstone is causing a complete obstruction of the bile duct.
There is a small amount of bile behind the gallstone.
The gallstone is blocking the X-ray during a radiograph.
The gallstone is absorbing sound waves and preventing their passage.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presents with right upper quadrant pain and is suspected to have chronic cholecystitis with gallstones. During the ultrasound, the Wall-Echo-Shadow (WES) sign is noted. What does the presence of the acoustic shadowing distal to the gallstone indicate?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) The gallstone is absorbing sound waves and preventing their passage.

 

  • Acoustic shadowing occurs when a solid structure, like a gallstone, absorbs or reflects sound waves, preventing them from passing through and creating a shadow on the ultrasound image. 
  • This is a hallmark of gallstone presence and is used to identify the stone and its relationship with surrounding structures.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The gallstone is causing a complete obstruction of the bile duct: Incorrect. Acoustic shadowing does not indicate bile duct obstruction, but rather the presence of a gallstone.

 

Option B. There is a small amount of bile behind the gallstone: Incorrect. The presence of acoustic shadowing suggests the stone is blocking the passage of sound waves, not the amount of bile.

 

Option C. The gallstone is blocking the X-ray during a radiograph: Incorrect. Acoustic shadowing is observed on ultrasound, not X-ray, which uses different principles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Acoustic shadowing on ultrasound occurs when a gallstone absorbs sound waves, preventing them from passing through and producing a shadow on the image.

questions.text:
A 56-year-old man with a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus is hospitalized after a mild concussion following a motor vehicle accident. His medications include aspirin, metformin, and lisinopril. He has a 20-year history of smoking (1 pack/day) but does not drink alcohol. He works as an accountant and has a family history of coronary artery disease and diabetes mellitus.

 

  • Vitals: BP 143/95 mm Hg, pulse 90/min (regular)
  • Exam: General and neurological examinations are unremarkable.
  • MRI brain is shown below. 

 

 

This patient is at the highest risk for which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dementia

 

  • This patient has vascular risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, smoking, and family history of coronary artery disease) and MRI evidence of a chronic basal ganglia infarct, suggesting silent cerebrovascular disease. 
  • He is at the highest risk for vascular dementia, which occurs due to multiple small or large vessel infarcts leading to cognitive decline.
  • Vascular dementia typically presents with:
    • Stepwise cognitive decline due to recurrent strokes
    • Executive dysfunction, impaired attention, and slowed processing speed
    • Focal neurological signs (e.g., gait disturbance, motor deficits)
    • History of strokes or silent infarcts on imaging

 

Given his vascular risk factors and MRI findings, this patient is at high risk for future strokes and vascular dementia.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Migraine headaches: While migraines are common, they usually begin in young adulthood, are associated with aura, and have no link to silent infarcts. This patient’s symptoms are not suggestive of migraines.

 

Option C. Multiple sclerosis: MS typically presents in younger adults (20-40 years old) with relapsing-remitting symptoms, such as optic neuritis, internuclear ophthalmoplegia, or sensory disturbances. The presence of a chronic basal ganglia infarct does not fit MS.

 

Option D. Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH): NPH presents with the classic triad of gait instability, urinary incontinence, and cognitive dysfunction. This patient has no symptoms of NPH, and an MRI would show ventriculomegaly without significant cortical atrophy, which is not described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Silent brain infarcts on MRI in patients with hypertension, diabetes, and smoking history indicate a high risk for vascular dementia. Preventive measures (BP control, smoking cessation, and glycemic control) are essential to reduce further stroke risk.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man, Ramesh from Chennai, presents to the hospital with progressive dizziness, nausea, dry cough, constipation, and excessive urination for the past two weeks. He denies fever, weight loss, or night sweats. His medical history is unremarkable, and he takes no medications. He smokes 10 cigarettes daily and occasionally consumes alcohol. On examination, BP is 110/70 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and lung auscultation is unremarkable. Laboratory results show hypercalcemia (13.0 mg/dL), elevated creatinine (1.9 mg/dL), suppressed PTH (8 pg/mL), and increased 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (77 pg/mL). A chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following medications is most appropriate in addition to IV fluids?

 

 

Which of the following medications is most appropriate in addition to IV fluids?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Prednisone

 

  • This patient has PTH-independent hypercalcemia with elevated 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, strongly suggestive of sarcoidosis.
  • Granulomatous macrophages produce excess 1-alpha hydroxylase, leading to increased calcium absorption and hypercalcemia.

 

Management:

 

  • IV fluids to enhance calcium excretion.
  • Glucocorticoids (Prednisone) to suppress macrophage-driven 1-alpha hydroxylase activity and reduce calcium levels.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Calcitonin: Provides rapid but short-term calcium reduction, not first-line for sarcoidosis-related hypercalcemia.

 

Option B. Cinacalcet: Lowers PTH secretion, used in primary/secondary hyperparathyroidism, not applicable here.

 

Option C. Furosemide: Promotes calcium excretion but may worsen dehydration, IV fluids alone are preferred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hypercalcemia with low PTH, high 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D, and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy suggests sarcoidosis. 
  • Prednisone is the treatment of choice to reduce calcium levels by suppressing macrophage-driven 1-alpha hydroxylase activity.

choices.text: Initial wound healing involves the deposition of type I collagen followed by type III collagen replacement
Type III collagen is laid down initially in the granulation tissue, later replaced by type I collagen
Type I collagen is deposited throughout the healing process
Type III collagen is replaced by type IV collagen during scar formation

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman undergoes a deep skin excision for the removal of a melanoma. The wound heals, and after several months, the scar is assessed. Which of the following best characterizes the progression of collagen deposition during wound healing in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Type III collagen is laid down initially in the granulation tissue, later replaced by type I collagen

 

  • During wound healing, type III collagen is deposited in granulation tissue during the initial repair phase. 
  • Over time, type I collagen, which is stronger and more durable, replaces type III collagen in the scar tissue. 
  • This transition is critical for the wound to gain tensile strength and stability.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Initial wound healing involves the deposition of type I collagen followed by type III collagen replacement: Incorrect. The initial deposition is type III collagen, which is replaced by type I collagen, not the reverse.

 

Option C. Type I collagen is deposited throughout the healing process: Incorrect. Type I collagen is present in the final scar, but type III collagen is initially deposited.

 

Option D. Type III collagen is replaced by type IV collagen during scar formation: Incorrect. Type IV collagen is associated with basement membranes, not with the scar formation process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During wound healing, type III collagen is deposited early in the process and later replaced by type I collagen to strengthen the tissue.

questions.text: A study investigates the effect of three different drug regimens (A, B, and C) on cholesterol levels. The study measures cholesterol levels in 120 individuals before and after treatment. Which of the following is the most appropriate statistical test to compare the change in cholesterol levels among these three regimens?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) ANOVA

 

  • The appropriate statistical test is ANOVA because there are three groups (Drug A, B, and C), and ANOVA allows for the comparison of means across more than two groups. 
  • Since the data are measurements taken before and after treatment on the same individuals, a paired approach should still be applied within each group. 
  • ANOVA can handle multiple groups and evaluate if there are significant differences between the groups.

 

Other Options:

Option A. Paired t-test: The Paired t-test is used for comparing means in the same group (before and after) for two conditions, not three groups.
 

Option B. Unpaired t-test: The Unpaired t-test compares two independent groups, but here we are dealing with three groups.
 

Option D. Mann-Whitney U test: The Mann-Whitney U test compares two independent groups with non-parametric data, not more than two groups.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • ANOVA is the most appropriate test for comparing the means across more than two groups.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman, Priyanka from Chennai, undergoes an ultrasound evaluation for dyspepsia. While no gallstones are found, imaging reveals three cortical cysts in the right kidney, two cortical cysts in the left kidney, and two liver cysts. She is asymptomatic, has no urinary symptoms, and is otherwise in good health. Her father died at age 52 from a stroke, but there is no known family history of kidney disease.

 

Vitals & Labs:
BP: 132/78 mm Hg
Pulse: 89/min
BMI: 29 kg/m²
Serum creatinine: 0.8 mg/dL (normal renal function)
Urinalysis: Normal

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Autosomal Dominant Polycystic Kidney Disease (ADPKD)

 

  • The presence of multiple bilateral renal cysts with hepatic cysts in an otherwise healthy young individual is highly suggestive of ADPKD.
  • ADPKD often presents asymptomatically in early adulthood but may later lead to hypertension, hematuria, or kidney failure.
  • Family history of stroke (father died at 52) raises concern for intracranial aneurysm, which is associated with ADPKD.
  • Liver cysts are common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by renal ultrasound criteria (e.g., at least 2 cysts in one kidney and at least 1 cyst in the other for ages 15-39).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acquired cystic disease: Acquired cystic disease occurs in chronic kidney disease and long-term dialysis patients, whereas this patient has normal renal function.

 

Option C. Multiple benign kidney cysts: Multiple benign kidney cysts may be incidental, but having multiple bilateral renal cysts with liver cysts is more suggestive of ADPKD.

 

Option D. Medullary sponge kidney: Medullary sponge kidney is associated with nephrocalcinosis and recurrent kidney stones, not widespread cortical cysts or liver cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • ADPKD should be suspected in young adults with bilateral renal cysts and extrarenal cysts (liver, pancreas).
  • Family history of stroke raises concern for intracranial aneurysm, a complication of ADPKD.
  • Ultrasound is the first-line diagnostic tool, and patients should be screened for hypertension, renal function decline, and aneurysms if indicated.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy falls off his bicycle while riding on a gravel path. He lands with his arm extended to break the fall. His parents bring him to the emergency department, where he complains of pain and tenderness over the forearm. On examination, there is mild swelling, but no open wound. There is pain with movement of the wrist and elbow, but the child is able to move his fingers. X-ray is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Greenstick fracture

 

  • A greenstick fracture is an incomplete fracture that commonly occurs in children, especially in the long bones (like the radius and ulna). 
  • In this type of fracture, one side of the bone bends or fractures partially, while the opposite side remains intact, somewhat like bending a green twig—hence the name "greenstick." 
  • The bone is not fully broken through.
  • Greenstick fractures usually happen due to bending forces on the bone. In this case, the child likely landed on his arm with outstretched hands, which caused the radius to bend and break on one side.
  • Tenderness over the fracture site (forearm). 
  • Pain with movement of the wrist and elbow, but the fingers remain mobile.
  • The fracture appears as an incomplete break with one side of the bone bent or cracked while the opposite side remains intact.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Spiral Fracture: A spiral fracture occurs when a bone is broken due to a twisting or rotational force. The fracture line spirals around the bone. It is commonly seen in cases of torsional injuries where the bone twists excessively. Spiral fractures typically happen in situations where a limb is twisted or rotated forcefully. This can occur in accidents where the body rotates while the limb remains stationary, or in situations involving child abuse or high-impact sports. Spiral fractures often involve long bones like the femur, tibia, or humerus. These fractures can be harder to detect initially because the fracture line may appear as a spiral on X-ray, which requires careful assessment.

 

Option C. Buckle (Torus) Fracture: A buckle fracture, also known as a torus fracture, is a compression fracture that occurs when the bone bends and causes a bulging or buckling on one side of the bone. This is most commonly seen in children due to the flexibility of their bones. Buckle fractures happen when a compressive force is applied to the bone, causing one side to bulge outward while the other side remains intact. This is common in distal radius fractures. Mild swelling and tenderness at the fracture site, but these fractures typically don’t cause complete breaks. The child may not have significant pain or deformity.

 

Option D. Comminuted Fracture: A comminuted fracture is a fracture that breaks the bone into multiple pieces. This type of fracture can occur due to high-impact trauma, where the bone is subjected to significant force. Comminuted fractures often occur in severe trauma situations, such as car accidents or falls from a great height, where the bone is shattered into several fragments. This type of fracture is often associated with severe pain, deformity, and swelling. X-ray typically shows multiple bone fragments.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Greenstick fracture involves an incomplete fracture in children, with one side of the bone broken and the other intact, typically caused by a bending force (which aligns with the fall with an outstretched arm).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of a tick bite and a rash that appeared several days later. He is concerned because the rash has a characteristic appearance shown in the image. He recalls hiking in wooded areas. Which of the following is the most likely transmitting agent of her condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 

 

 

 

  • The presentation of a bull's-eye rash (erythema migrans) along with flu-like symptoms is highly suggestive of Lyme disease, which is transmitted by the Ixodes scapularis tick (also known as the black-legged or deer tick). 
  • This tick is commonly found in wooded areas and is known for transmitting Borrelia burgdorferi, the causative agent of Lyme disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Amblyomma americanum (Lone star tick): This tick is associated with the transmission of Ehrlichia chaffeensis (causing human monocytic ehrlichiosis) and Francisella tularensis (tularemia), but not Lyme disease.

 

 

Option C. Rhipicephalus sanguineus (Brown dog tick): This tick is commonly found around dogs and is a vector for Rickettsia rickettsii, the causative agent of Rocky Mountain spotted fever, but does not transmit Lyme disease.

 

 

Option D. Dermacentor variabilis (American dog tick): This tick is associated with the transmission of Rickettsia rickettsii (Rocky Mountain spotted fever) and Francisella tularensis, but it is not the vector for Lyme disease.

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Lyme disease is a tick-borne illness primarily transmitted by Ixodes scapularis, characterized by the presence of a characteristic "bull's-eye" rash (erythema migrans) and flu-like symptoms. 
  • Proper identification of the vector is crucial for diagnosis and management.

choices.text: Inhibition of GABA-A receptors in the brainstem
Activation of GABA-B receptors in the spinal cord
Inhibition of dopamine reuptake in the basal ganglia
Direct inhibition of calcium channels in the skeletal muscle

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with severe spasticity due to multiple sclerosis is treated with baclofen. He presents with dizziness and fatigue. Given his condition, what is the underlying mechanism through which baclofen primarily acts to alleviate his symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Activation of GABA-B receptors in the spinal cord

 

  • Baclofen is a centrally acting muscle relaxant that works by binding to GABA-B receptors in the spinal cord. 
  • This activation inhibits the release of excitatory neurotransmitters, leading to reduced muscle spasticity and muscle relaxation. 
  • Baclofen does not directly affect muscle fibers or dopamine reuptake in the basal ganglia. It works centrally, modulating the excitability of spinal motor neurons.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Inhibition of GABA-A receptors in the brainstem: Incorrect. GABA-A receptors are involved in other forms of inhibitory neurotransmission, particularly in the brain, but baclofen acts via GABA-B receptors in the spinal cord.
 

Option C. Inhibition of dopamine reuptake in the basal ganglia: Incorrect. Dopamine reuptake inhibition is more relevant to drugs used in Parkinson's disease, not baclofen, which does not affect dopamine directly.
 

Option D. Direct inhibition of calcium channels in the skeletal muscle: Incorrect. While calcium channel blockers (such as dantrolene) can act on skeletal muscle directly, baclofen works centrally in the spinal cord, not on muscle tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Baclofen acts as a GABA-B receptor agonist in the spinal cord, reducing muscle spasticity through central inhibition of neurotransmitter release.

questions.text:
Match the Following (Dermatopathological Terminologies)

 

Column A:

  1. Parakeratosis
  2. Acanthosis
  3. Spongiosis
  4. Acantholysis

 

Column B: 

  1. Intraepidermal intercellular edema
  2. Thickened stratum spinosum
  3. Nucleated stratum corneum
  4. Lysis of desmosomes causing keratinocyte detachment
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1-c, 2-b, 3-a, 4-d

 

  • Parakeratosis (1-c): This refers to the retention of nuclei in the stratum corneum, often seen in conditions like psoriasis.
  • Acanthosis (2-b): Characterized by thickening of the stratum spinosum, commonly seen in chronic irritation or diabetes-related skin changes.
  • Spongiosis (3-a): Represents intraepidermal intercellular edema, a hallmark of acute eczema.
  • Acantholysis (4-d): Describes the lysis of desmosomes, leading to the detachment of keratinocytes, seen in pemphigus.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Parakeratosis, acanthosis, spongiosis, and acantholysis are key dermatopathological terms with distinct microscopic features that help in diagnosing specific skin disorders.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man, Rahul from Mumbai, is scheduled for an elective craniotomy for a benign brain tumor. He was diagnosed with type 1 von Willebrand disease (VWD) at age 17 and has a history of easy bruising and recurrent epistaxis, including a severe episode last year requiring nasal packing. He has no prior surgeries. On examination, vital signs are stable, but there is an ecchymotic patch on his left thigh. Laboratory tests reveal mild anemia, normal platelet count, and a prolonged activated PTT.What is the most effective strategy to reduce this patient’s perioperative bleeding risk?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) VWF preparations

 

  • For patients with von Willebrand disease (VWD) undergoing major surgery, VWF preparations (plasma-derived concentrates containing VWF and factor VIII) are preferred over desmopressin (DDAVP), especially in those with a history of significant bleeding episodes or severe surgery-related bleeding risk (e.g., craniotomy).
  • Desmopressin (DDAVP) is usually first-line for minor procedures but has limited efficacy for major surgeries or if the patient had severe bleeding in the past.
  • VWF preparations provide a reliable and sustained increase in VWF and factor VIII levels, ensuring adequate perioperative hemostasis.
  • Given the high risk of bleeding in neurosurgery, factor replacement therapy is preferred.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aminocaproic acid: Helps control mucosal bleeding but does not increase VWF or factor VIII levels, making it inadequate for surgical hemostasis.

 

Option B. Desmopressin (DDAVP): Effective for mild VWD and minor surgeries, but not reliable for high-risk major surgeries like craniotomy, especially in a patient with previous severe bleeding.

 

Option C. Platelet transfusions: Platelets contain some VWF, but this is not the primary defect in VWD Type 1, making this option unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • VWF concentrates are preferred over desmopressin for patients with von Willebrand disease undergoing high-risk major surgeries (e.g., craniotomy) to ensure sustained perioperative hemostasis and reduce bleeding complications.

choices.text: Both A and R are true, and R is the correct explanation of A.
Both A and R are true, but R is not the correct explanation of A.
A is true, but R is false.
A is false, but R is true.

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Delayed eruption of primary teeth is defined as the failure of any teeth to appear by 13 months of age.

 

Reason (R): Delayed eruption is most commonly caused by underlying endocrine abnormalities like hypothyroidism or hypoparathyroidism.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A is true, but R is false.

 

Assertion (A): True. Delayed eruption is considered when no primary teeth have erupted by 13 months, based on the mean age of eruption with a standard deviation.

 

Reason (R): False. The most common cause of delayed tooth eruption is idiopathic (unknown cause), not endocrine abnormalities. Other causes include familial patterns, mechanical blockage, and systemic disorders. Endocrine abnormalities like hypothyroidism are less common causes.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Delayed eruption of primary teeth is typically idiopathic, but systemic or mechanical causes, such as hypothyroidism or gum fibrosis, should be ruled out.

choices.text: CT imaging to visualize the cyst

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with left flank pain and hematuria. Imaging reveals a left renal hydatid cyst. Based on the risks associated with the management of this condition, which of the following should be avoided in the initial diagnostic workup?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Fine-needle aspiration (FNAC) of the cyst

 

  • Fine-needle aspiration (FNAC) of a hydatid cyst should be avoided due to the risk of puncturing the cyst and releasing hydatid fluid, which can lead to severe anaphylaxis. 
  • PAIR (Puncture, aspiration, injection, and reaspiration) is a safer approach in early stages and can be guided by ultrasound or CT imaging. 
  • CT is diagnostic and allows for visualizing daughter cysts within the larger cyst.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. CT imaging is essential for diagnosing hydatid cysts and visualizing daughter cysts.
 

Option C. Serum antibody testing for Echinococcus: Serum antibody testing can be useful to support the diagnosis, especially in atypical cases.
 

Option D. Ultrasound-guided puncture, aspiration, injection, and reaspiration (PAIR): PAIR is an appropriate technique in early-stage hydatid disease and should be performed with care to avoid cyst rupture.

 

Educational Objective:


FNAC should be avoided in suspected hydatid cysts due to the risk of anaphylaxis from cyst rupture and hydatid fluid release.

choices.text: Sheep act as definitive hosts for Echinococcus granulosus, shedding embryonated eggs in their feces.
Sheep serve as intermediate hosts, where they ingest embryonated eggs and develop hydatid cysts in their liver.
Sheep ingest the larvae from Echinococcus eggs and directly pass them on to humans through contaminated meat.
Sheep provide the food source for the adult tapeworms in definitive hosts, such as dogs.

questions.text: What is the role of sheep in the life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus in humans?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sheep serve as intermediate hosts, where they ingest embryonated eggs and develop hydatid cysts in their liver.

 

  • In the life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus, sheep are intermediate hosts that ingest embryonated eggs from the feces of infected dogs (definitive hosts). 
  • These eggs hatch in the sheep’s intestine, releasing oncospheres that travel to organs, commonly the liver, where they form hydatid cysts.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sheep act as definitive hosts for Echinococcus granulosus, shedding embryonated eggs in their feces: Sheep are not definitive hosts; dogs are the definitive hosts of Echinococcus granulosus.

 

Option C. Sheep ingest the larvae from Echinococcus eggs and directly pass them on to humans through contaminated meat: Sheep do not pass larvae to humans; they pass eggs that lead to infection.

 

Option D. Sheep provide the food source for the adult tapeworms in definitive hosts, such as dogs: While adult tapeworms reside in the intestines of definitive hosts (dogs), they do not feed on sheep.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sheep act as intermediate hosts in the life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus, where they ingest embryonated eggs, leading to the formation of hydatid cysts in various organs.

questions.text:
Match the Following:

 

Column A (Conditions)

  1. Fragile X Syndrome
  2. Down Syndrome
  3. Necrotizing Enterocolitis (NEC)
  4. Congenital Rubella Syndrome

 

Column B (Key Features)

  1. Pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas, and pneumoperitoneum on radiographs
  2. Continuous machinery murmur due to patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
  3. Intellectual disability, flat facial profile, and single palmar crease
  4. Large ears, prominent square jaw, and intellectual disability
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-D, 2-C, 3-A, 4-B

 

  • 1-D (Fragile X Syndrome): Features include intellectual disability, large ears, and a prominent square jaw.
  • 2-C (Down Syndrome): Hallmark features include intellectual disability, flat facial profile, and a single palmar crease.
  • 3-A (NEC): Radiographic signs include pneumatosis intestinalis, portal venous gas, and pneumoperitoneum.
  • 4-B (Congenital Rubella Syndrome): Common features include PDA presenting as a continuous machinery murmur.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Correlate Fragile X syndrome, Down syndrome, NEC, and congenital rubella syndrome with their hallmark clinical and diagnostic features, including intellectual disability, specific craniofacial findings, radiographic changes, and cardiac manifestations.

questions.text:
Which of the following combinations is incorrect regarding second messengers?

 

  1. cAMP is used by vasopressin (V2) for water reabsorption.
  2. Calcium is the second messenger for vasopressin (V1), leading to uterine contraction.
  3. cGMP mediates vasoconstriction by nitric oxide.
  4. Epinephrine (beta) uses cAMP to increase metabolism.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Second messengers, such as cAMP, calcium, and cGMP, mediate distinct hormonal actions. 
  • Vasopressin (V2) uses cAMP for water reabsorption, vasopressin (V1) uses calcium for vasoconstriction, and nitric oxide mediates vasodilation via cGMP.

choices.text: IgG or IgM antibodies bind to cell-bound antigens, leading to immune complex formation and complement activation.
IgE antibodies bind to mast cells, causing degranulation and immediate inflammatory response.
T cells secrete cytokines that activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells.
IgG antibodies bind to a soluble antigen, forming immune complexes that deposit in tissues.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy is diagnosed with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis following a recent sore throat. His laboratory findings reveal the deposition of antigen-antibody complexes in the kidneys. Which of the following mechanisms is responsible for this type of immune reaction?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) IgG antibodies bind to a soluble antigen, forming immune complexes that deposit in tissues.

 

  • This describes Type III hypersensitivity, where immune complexes formed by IgG (or IgM) antibodies binding to soluble antigens deposit in tissues, triggering complement activation and causing inflammation, as seen in post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. IgG or IgM antibodies bind to cell-bound antigens, leading to immune complex formation and complement activation: This suggests Type II hypersensitivity, where antibodies target cell-bound antigens, not soluble antigens.
 

Option B. IgE antibodies bind to mast cells, causing degranulation and immediate inflammatory response: IgE binding to mast cells is involved in Type I hypersensitivity, not in immune complex diseases like glomerulonephritis.
 

Option C. T cells secrete cytokines that activate macrophages and cytotoxic T cells: T cell activation is the mechanism behind Type IV hypersensitivity, not immune complex deposition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 64-year-old male with a history of atrial fibrillation and heart failure is started on digoxin therapy. He also takes a thiazide diuretic to manage his edema. What is the most important factor to monitor to reduce the risk of digoxin toxicity in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Serum potassium levels

 

  • Digoxin toxicity is particularly sensitive to changes in serum potassium levels.
  •  Hypokalemia (low potassium) enhances the toxic effects of digoxin by increasing its binding to myocardial cells, increasing the risk of arrhythmias. 
  • Thiazide diuretics can lead to hypokalemia, making it essential to monitor potassium levels regularly.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Serum calcium levels: Incorrect. While calcium can influence cardiac function, it does not directly increase the risk of digoxin toxicity like low potassium does.
 

Option C. Serum sodium levels: Incorrect. Sodium imbalances are important for overall fluid balance but are not as directly linked to digoxin toxicity.
 

Option D. Serum magnesium levels: Incorrect. Magnesium affects cardiac stability but does not have as direct a role in digoxin toxicity as potassium levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Monitoring serum potassium levels is critical in preventing digoxin toxicity, particularly when the patient is on diuretics that can lead to hypokalemia.

choices.text: Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis.
Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within red blood cells.
Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens.
Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old child presents with pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort. Laboratory investigations reveal a hemoglobin level of 9.5 g/dL and a peripheral blood smear demonstrates a peculiar finding as shown below:

 

 

Which of the following differential diagnoses is most likely responsible for this finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lead poisoning affecting heme synthesis and resulting in aggregates of ribosomal material within red blood cells.

 

  • The image shows basophilic stippling characteristic of lead poisoning. 
  • Also clinical features are of lead poisoning (pallor, fatigue, and abdominal discomfort). The blue dots are ribosome aggregates.

 

Basophilic stippling:

 

  • It refers to blue dots in cytoplasm of RBCs when seen in microscope. 
  • It is most characteristically seen in lead poisoning. Though can also be seen in few other conditions like Thalassemia, sideroblastic anaemia, MDS, etc.
  • It can basically be seen in any condition in which heme synthesis is disturbed, and precursors of heme (e.g. protoporphyrin) accumulate. These precursors of heme interfere with ribosome functions and hence aggregates of ribosomes are formed in RBCs. These ribosome aggregates appear like blue dots.
  • Lead interferes with multiple enzymes involved in the synthesis of heme.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Viral infection affecting erythropoiesis, causing aberrant RNA synthesis: Viral infections typically affect WBCs and may lead to various hematological abnormalities, but basophilic stippling is not a characteristic feature of viral infections.

 

Option B. Lead poisoning leading to abnormal iron metabolism, leading to intracellular iron accumulation within RBCs: While lead poisoning can indeed affect iron metabolism, basophilic stippling is not primarily caused by abnormal iron accumulation within RBCs. Instead, it results from the interference of lead with enzymes involved in heme synthesis, leading to the accumulation of ribosomal material within erythrocytes. 

 

Option C. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia, caused by the production of autoantibodies against red blood cell antigens. Basophilic stippling is not a feature of autoimmune hemolytic anemia. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia involves the destruction of RBCs. Basophilic stippling, however, is associated with disturbances in heme synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Basophilic stippling in red blood cells, which appears as blue dots under the microscope, is characteristic of lead poisoning. 
  • It occurs due to the accumulation of ribosomal material within RBCs when lead interferes with heme synthesis.

questions.text: An 18-year-old male presented with limp. X-ray of the pelvis was taken. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fibrous dysplasia

 

  • Fibrous dysplasia is a bone disorder in which normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue, resulting in bone weakening and deformities. 
  • It can affect one bone (monostotic) or multiple bones (polyostotic). The pelvis, femur, and ribs are commonly involved. 
  • It can occur at any age, but it is more commonly diagnosed in childhood or adolescence.
  • X-ray of fibrous dysplasia typically shows a "ground-glass" appearance or "café au lait" spots. 

 

 

  • The bone is often expanded or deformed, and there may be cortical thinning or bowing. 
  • The affected bone may appear irregular and weakened, making it prone to fractures.
  • Pain, deformities, and limping due to fractures or bone weakness are common. 
  • Depending on the location of the lesion, the individual may have functional limitations, such as difficulty walking.
  • Bone biopsy can be done to confirm the diagnosis, which will show fibrous tissue replacing normal bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Paget’s Disease: Paget's disease of bone is a chronic disorder characterized by abnormal bone remodeling. It involves excessive bone resorption followed by abnormal bone formation, leading to weakened bones that are prone to fractures. Paget’s disease typically affects older adults, and it is rare in individuals under 40. The disease commonly involves the pelvis, spine, femur, and skull. Paget's disease can show "cotton wool" appearance (patchy sclerosis), bowing of bones, and enlarged bones. In severe cases, it can lead to deformities and fractures. It may present with joint pain and deformities leading to difficulty with walking or limping, but this is rare in young people. Paget's disease can be confirmed with increased alkaline phosphatase (ALP) levels.

 

 

Option B. Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma is a cancer of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell that produces antibodies. It leads to the formation of multiple tumors in bone marrow, which can cause bone destruction, pain, fractures, and anemia. The disease is uncommon in young individuals and is typically diagnosed in people over 65 years old. In multiple myeloma, X-rays often show punched-out lesions (areas of bone destruction), and the bones may appear weakened. There may also be diffuse osteopenia (reduced bone density). Bone pain, fatigue, weakness, fractures, and in some cases, kidney problems. However, limping as an initial presenting symptom would be unusual. Multiple myeloma is diagnosed through blood tests (like serum protein electrophoresis) and bone marrow biopsy, along with imaging studies.

 

 

Option C. Osteopoikilosis: Osteopoikilosis is a rare, benign bone condition characterized by multiple, round or oval-shaped bone islands (sclerotic foci) within the bones. These are usually found incidentally on X-rays and are typically asymptomatic. It is a congenital condition, and affected individuals usually do not experience any symptoms. The key feature of osteopoikilosis is the presence of multiple small, well-circumscribed areas of increased bone density, often described as "bone islands." These are most commonly seen in the pelvis, femur, and other long bones. Typically, osteopoikilosis is asymptomatic and does not cause any pain or functional impairment. It is generally found incidentally during radiological investigations for other reasons. The diagnosis is based on the characteristic appearance of bone islands on X-ray. There is no need for further clinical investigation unless complications (like fractures) occur, which is very rare.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Paget's disease is unlikely due to the patient's young age.
  • Multiple myeloma is unlikely because it's very rare in young individuals and typically presents with systemic symptoms.
  • Osteopoikilosis is unlikely as it is asymptomatic and would not cause limping.
  • Fibrous dysplasia is the most likely diagnosis due to its characteristic appearance on X-ray and its association with bone pain, deformities, and limping in young individuals.

questions.text: A histopathology image shows intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions within the liver cells, as indicated by the arrows in the image. These inclusions are most likely composed of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intermediate keratin filaments

 

  • The inclusions shown in the image are Mallory-Denk bodies, which are composed of intermediate keratin filaments. 
  • These are found in various liver conditions, most notably in alcoholic liver disease, and are a characteristic feature on histological examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mitochondrial aggregates: Incorrect. Mitochondrial aggregates would be seen in conditions like mitochondrial myopathies, not in Mallory-Denk bodies.


Option C. Aggregated ribosomal RNA: Incorrect. Ribosomal RNA aggregates are not seen in Mallory-Denk bodies.
 

Option D. Hepatic iron deposits: Incorrect. Hepatic iron deposits are associated with hemochromatosis, not Mallory-Denk bodies.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Mallory-Denk bodies are composed of intermediate keratin filaments and are characteristic of alcoholic liver disease.

questions.text:
Match the Following

 

Column A: Muscle

 

  1. Masseter
  2. Temporalis
  3. Medial pterygoid
  4. Lateral pterygoid

 

Column B: Actions


A. Depression, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of mandible
B. Elevation & retraction of mandible 
C. Elevation, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of mandible
D. Elevation of mandible
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-D, 2-B, 3-C, 4-A

 

1. Masseter

 

  • Actions: Elevation of mandible, it is strongest muscle of body. 
  • Correct Match: D

 

2. Temporalis

 

  • Actions: Elevation of mandible. It is also only retractor of mandible. 
  • Correct Match: B

 

3. Medial pterygoid

 

  • Actions: Elevation, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of mandible.
  • Correct Match: C

 

4. Lateral pterygoid

 

  • Actions: Depression, protrusion, and side-to-side movement of mandible.
  • Correct Match: A

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary muscles of mastication (masseter, temporalis, medial, and lateral pterygoid) each have specific actions:
  • Masseter: Elevates the mandible.
  • Temporalis: Elevates & retracts the mandible.
  • Medial pterygoid: Elevates, protrudes, and moves the mandible side to side.
  • Lateral pterygoid: Depresses, protrudes, and moves the mandible side to side.

choices.text: Administration of ice to the upper eyelid

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with a history of difficulty holding his eyelids up for long periods presents with unilateral ptosis. You perform a test where the patient is asked to look up and hold that position. You notice that the upper eyelid begins to droop over time. Which of the following would provide a rapid diagnostic improvement in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Administration of ice to the upper eyelid

 

  • The ice test is highly specific and sensitive for diagnosing myasthenia gravis (MG). 
  • Applying an ice pack to the affected eyelid for 2-5 minutes results in temporary improvement of ptosis by more than 2mm, which is due to the cold decreasing acetylcholinesterase breakdown of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. 
  • This is a simple and effective test, especially for ptosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Oral administration of pyridostigmine: Pyridostigmine is used in the long-term management of MG, but it is not used as a diagnostic test.

 

Option C. Subcutaneous injection of atropine: Atropine is an anticholinergic agent, and it would worsen the symptoms of MG by inhibiting acetylcholine action at the neuromuscular junction, not improving it.

 

Option D. Edrophonium (Tensilon) test: While this is a useful test for MG, the ice test specifically helps in diagnosing ptosis and is preferred for acute office-based testing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The ice test is a quick and effective diagnostic method for ptosis in myasthenia gravis, where improvement in ptosis after cold application supports the diagnosis.

choices.text: It increases levodopa absorption from the gastrointestinal tract
It decreases the peripheral breakdown of levodopa, leading to prolonged plasma levels
It directly stimulates dopamine receptors in the brain
It converts levodopa into its active form in the brain

questions.text: A 62-year-old female with Parkinson’s disease has been experiencing motor fluctuations despite being on levodopa therapy. Her physician adds entacapone to her treatment regimen. Which of the following best describes the role of entacapone in levodopa therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) It decreases the peripheral breakdown of levodopa, leading to prolonged plasma levels

 

  • Entacapone works by inhibiting catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT), an enzyme responsible for metabolizing levodopa in the periphery (outside the brain). 
  • By inhibiting COMT, entacapone decreases the peripheral breakdown of levodopa, which results in prolonged plasma levels of levodopa. 
  • This effect helps reduce the fluctuations in motor control that often occur with levodopa therapy, improving the overall effectiveness of the drug.

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. It increases levodopa absorption from the gastrointestinal tract: Incorrect. Entacapone does not affect the absorption of levodopa in the gut. It affects its metabolism in the periphery.
 

Option C. It directly stimulates dopamine receptors in the brain: Incorrect. Entacapone does not stimulate dopamine receptors; it works on levodopa metabolism in the periphery.
 

Option D. It converts levodopa into its active form in the brain: Incorrect. Entacapone does not affect the conversion of levodopa to dopamine; it prevents its breakdown in the periphery, ensuring more levodopa reaches the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Entacapone enhances levodopa therapy by inhibiting COMT, decreasing levodopa's peripheral breakdown and prolonging its plasma levels to improve motor control in Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: A synthetic polyribonucleotide with the repeating sequence CAA is translated in a cell-free protein synthesizing system, resulting in three homopolypeptides: polyglutamine, polyasparagine, and polythreonine. The codon for glutamine and asparagine are CAA and AAC, respectively. Based on this information, which of the following triplets codes for threonine?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) ACA

 

  • In this scenario, the repeating sequence provided is CAA, meaning this sequence is continuously translated. 
  • The question informs us that the translation produces three distinct homopolypeptides: polyglutamine, polyasparagine, and polythreonine. To deduce the codon for threonine, consider the following:
    1. Glutamine (polyglutamine) is encoded by the triplet CAA, as per the provided information.
    2. Asparagine (polyasparagine) is encoded by the triplet AAC.
  • Since the sequence is repeating, the possible triplets formed from reading this repeating sequence in different frames are:
    • CAA (already identified as glutamine),
    • AAC (already identified as asparagine),
    • The remaining triplet would be ACA.

  • Thus, since the sequence of interest codes for polyglutamine, polyasparagine, and polythreonine, and we already know CAA and AAC represent glutamine and asparagine, the only remaining possibility for threonine is ACA.

     

Other Options:

 

Option A. AAC: This codon codes for asparagine, not threonine. It has already been identified as the codon for asparagine in the given sequence.
 

Option B. CAA: This codon codes for glutamine, not threonine. It has already been identified as the codon for glutamine in the repeating sequence.
 

Option C. CAC: While this is a triplet, it does not correspond to the codon for threonine. It might represent histidine, but it is not relevant to this context, as threonine's codon is ACA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In this case, the ACA triplet codes for threonine in the context of a repeating synthetic polyribonucleotide sequence. 
  • Codons for glutamine (CAA) and asparagine (AAC) have been provided, leaving ACA as the correct codon for threonine.

questions.text: A public health official is assessing the safety of various insecticides used in agricultural settings. Which of the following insecticides, synthesized by Michael Faraday, is commonly used for its residual action up to 3 months and is characterized by a high percentage of gamma isomer?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) HCH

 

  • HCH (hexachlorocyclohexane) was synthesized by Michael Faraday and is known for its high percentage of gamma isomer. 
  • It has a short residual action of approximately 3 months, unlike DDT, which has a much longer residual effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. DDT: Known for its long residual action, but it does not contain a high percentage of gamma isomer.

 

Option B. Malathion: Has low toxicity and is used for ultra-low volume spraying, but it does not have a high percentage of gamma isomer.

 

Option D. Fenthion: Similar to Malathion, used for residual sprays but lacks the gamma isomer characteristics of HCH.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insecticides and their characteristics:

choices.text: The pan and brush are discarded.
The worker should immediately dispose of gloves.
The worker should wash the pan and brush under running water and allow them to dry.
The worker should apply 0.5% sodium hypochlorite to the pan and brush.

questions.text: During the cleaning of a blood spillage, the worker uses a pan and brush to remove broken glass. What is the next step after cleaning the glass according to the protocol?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The worker should wash the pan and brush under running water and allow them to dry.

 

  • After cleaning broken glass, the pan and brush should be washed under running water and allowed to dry, ensuring that no contamination remains for future use.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. The pan and brush are discarded: Discarding the pan and brush is not recommended as they can be reused after proper cleaning.

 

Option B. The pan and brush are discarded: Gloves are removed after cleaning and before hand washing.

 

Option D. The worker should apply 0.5% sodium hypochlorite to the pan and brush: Sodium hypochlorite is used on the surface, not the cleaning tools.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cleaning and sanitizing the tools used during spillage cleanup is critical for maintaining hygiene and preventing cross-contamination.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man on a prolonged hunger strike presents to the emergency department with symptoms of fatigue and confusion. His urine sample is analyzed with a specific diagnostic test, as shown in the image below. What is the name of this diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rothera’s test

 

  • The test depicted in the image is Rothera's test, which is used specifically to detect ketone bodies in the urine. 
  • The presence of a purple ring at the interface signifies a positive result, indicating the metabolism of fat for energy—a common physiological response to prolonged fasting or starvation, as seen in this patient on a hunger strike.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Benedict’s test: Incorrect. This test identifies the presence of reducing sugars, such as glucose, not ketones.

 

Option C. Aldehyde test: Incorrect. This test is used to detect aldehydes in various substances, unrelated to the presence of ketones in urine.

 

Option D. Molisch’s test: Incorrect. This is a general test for the presence of carbohydrates in aqueous solutions and does not apply to the detection of ketone bodies in urine.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Learn to recognize the application of Rothera’s test in diagnosing ketosis, particularly in clinical scenarios involving prolonged fasting or caloric deprivation.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true about breech presentation?

 

  1. It is more common in pelvic anomalies.
  2. The incidence is about 3-4% at term.
  3. External cephalic version increases the incidence of breech presentation.
  4. It is more common in postdated pregnancies.
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 and 2 only

 

  • Statement 1 (True): Breech presentation is more common in pelvic anomalies such as uterine malformations (e.g., bicornuate uterus, fibroids) or placenta previa, which restrict fetal movement and hinder normal cephalic positioning.
  • Statement 2 (True): The incidence of breech presentation is 3-4% at term, but it is more common in preterm pregnancies (25% at 28 weeks, decreasing as gestation progresses due to spontaneous cephalic version).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Statement 3 (False): External cephalic version (ECV) is a procedure performed to convert a breech presentation to cephalic presentation, thereby reducing the incidence of breech at term, not increasing it.
  • Statement 4 (False): Breech is more common in preterm births, while postdated pregnancies (≥42 weeks) are more likely to have cephalic presentations due to spontaneous version.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Breech presentation is associated with pelvic anomalies and has a term incidence of 3-4%, with external cephalic version reducing its occurrence.

choices.text: Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason correctly explains the Assertion.
Both Assertion and Reason are true, but Reason does not explain the Assertion.
Assertion is true, but Reason is false.
Both Assertion and Reason are false.

questions.text:
Assertion: The larger the triplet repeat expansion in Fragile X syndrome, the more severe the intellectual disability.


Reason: Fragile X syndrome is caused by a trinucleotide repeat expansion (CGG) in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Both Assertion and Reason are true, and Reason correctly explains the Assertion.

 

  • Fragile X syndrome is the most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and is caused by an expansion of CGG trinucleotide repeats in the FMR1 gene located on the X chromosome.
  • Normal individuals have <45 CGG repeats, while individuals with >200 CGG repeats have full mutation Fragile X syndrome due to hypermethylation and silencing of the FMR1 gene.
  • The larger the repeat expansion, the greater the gene silencing, leading to reduced levels of Fragile X Mental Retardation Protein (FMRP), which is crucial for synaptic function and neural development.
  • This explains why greater repeat expansion leads to more severe intellectual disability, making R the correct explanation of A.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • The degree of intellectual disability in Fragile X syndrome correlates with the size of the trinucleotide repeat expansion

choices.text: 10% relative reduction in harmful use of alcohol
25% reduction in premature mortality from NCDs
30% reduction in the mean population intake of sodium
20% relative reduction in physical inactivity

questions.text: Which of the following is not one of the voluntary global NCD targets set by WHO for 2025?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 20% relative reduction in physical inactivity

 

  • The WHO target for 2025 includes a 10% reduction in physical inactivity in the population, not 20%. 
  • The other targets, including alcohol reduction, sodium intake reduction, and premature mortality reduction, are accurate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 10% relative reduction in harmful use of alcohol: Alcohol reduction is indeed a 10% relative reduction target.

 

Option B. 25% reduction in premature mortality from NCDs: A 25% reduction in premature mortality from NCDs is a core target.

 

Option C. 30% reduction in the mean population intake of sodium: The 30% reduction in sodium intake is another of WHO's goals for 2025.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A researcher is studying the adenovirus and is focusing on the proteins involved in viral assembly. Which protein is specifically involved in the structural integrity of the capsid and aids in the assembly of the adenovirus particle?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hexon protein

 

  • The hexon protein forms the major structural unit of the adenovirus capsid.
  • It is involved in the assembly of the capsid, providing stability and structural integrity to the viral particle. 
  • It constitutes a significant portion of the adenovirus's outer shell.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Fiber protein: The fiber protein is responsible for host cell attachment but not involved in capsid assembly.
 

Option C. Penton base (Protein III): Penton base aids in viral assembly and release but not in the formation of the capsid.
 

Option D. Core protein μ: Core protein μ is involved in genome packaging but does not contribute directly to capsid assembly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The hexon protein plays a crucial role in the assembly of the adenovirus capsid.

questions.text: Which treatment is most appropriate for the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intralesional triamcinolone

 

  • For localized alopecia areata, intralesional corticosteroids like triamcinolone are first-line therapy to reduce localized inflammation and promote hair regrowth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Systemic corticosteroids: Reserved for extensive or rapidly progressive alopecia areata.

 

Option C. Methotrexate: Used in refractory or severe cases, not localized disease.

 

Option D. Minoxidil: Effective in androgenetic alopecia but not the first choice for alopecia areata.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Intralesional triamcinolone is the treatment of choice for localized alopecia areata to suppress inflammation and stimulate hair regrowth.

choices.text: It is caused by the infectious β-sheet form of a host-cell protein.
It results from the accumulation of denatured proteins that have random conformations.
It is associated with the accumulation of amyloid precursor protein.
It is associated with the deposition of neurotoxic amyloid β peptide aggregates.

questions.text: An 80-year-old man presented with impairment of intellectual function and alterations in behaviour. His family reported progressive disorientation and memory loss over the last 6 months. There is no family history of dementia. The patient was tentatively diagnosed with Alzheimer disease (AD). Which of the following best describes the pathological mechanism underlying Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is associated with the deposition of neurotoxic amyloid β peptide aggregates.

 

  • Alzheimer disease (AD) is associated with long, fibrillar protein assemblies consisting of β-pleated sheets found in the brain and elsewhere. 
  • The disease is associated with abnormal processing of a normal protein. 
  • The accumulated altered protein occurs in a β-pleated sheet conformation that is neurotoxic. 
  • The amyloid β that is deposited in the brain in AD is derived by proteolytic cleavages from the larger amyloid precursor protein, a single transmembrane protein expressed on the cell surface in the brain and other tissues. 
  • Most cases of AD are sporadic, although at least 5% of cases are familial. Prion diseases, such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob, are caused by the infectious β-sheet form (PrPSc) of a host-cell protein (PrPC).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is caused by the infectious β-sheet form of a host-cell protein: Prion diseases (such as Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease) are caused by the infectious β-sheet form of a host-cell protein, which is known as PrPSc. This is not associated with Alzheimer disease.
 

Option B. It results from the accumulation of denatured proteins that have random conformations: Denatured proteins with random conformations are more relevant to other diseases but not to Alzheimer's. AD specifically involves structured β-pleated sheets in amyloid plaques, not random protein conformations.
 

Option C. It is associated with the accumulation of amyloid precursor protein: Amyloid precursor protein (APP) is a precursor to amyloid β, but AD is primarily associated with the accumulation of the amyloid β peptide rather than the precursor protein itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Alzheimer’s disease is characterized by the accumulation of amyloid β peptide aggregates, which are derived from the amyloid precursor protein (APP). 
  • These aggregates form neurotoxic plaques, contributing to neuronal dysfunction and cognitive decline.

questions.text: A 32-year-old multiparous woman presents in active labor. The fetal head is engaged, and the mentum is anterior. Vaginal delivery is being attempted. What is the most likely mechanism of head delivery in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Flexion

 

  • In mento-anterior face presentation, the submental region hinges below the symphysis pubis, and the head delivers by flexion. This is possible only if the mentum is anterior.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Extension: Incorrect because extension is associated with occipito-anterior or occipito-posterior vertex presentations.

 

Option C. Rotation: Incorrect because rotation occurs before flexion during labor.

 

Option D. Hyperextension: Incorrect because hyperextension prevents vaginal delivery in mento-posterior presentations.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • In mento-anterior face presentation, vaginal delivery is achieved through flexion of the fetal head, provided the mentum is anterior.

questions.text: Match the following infections in pregnancy with their respective clinical features:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1-A, 2-B, 3-C, 4-D

 

  • 1-A (Toxoplasma): Triad of intracerebral calcification, chorioretinitis, and hydrocephalus.
  • 2-B (Cytomegalovirus): Periventricular calcifications and sensorineural hearing loss (most common congenital viral syndrome).
  • 3-C (Parvovirus B19): Causes hydrops fetalis and anemia due to cytotoxic effects on fetal RBCs.
  • 4-D (Rubella): Classic triad includes cataract, congenital heart defects (PDA), and SNHL.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Infections during pregnancy have distinct clinical features and complications that are critical for diagnosis and management.

choices.text: PD-L1 and PD-L2 prevent the activation of T-cells by binding to PD-1 receptors on T-cells.
PD-L1 and PD-L2 promote the differentiation of T-cells into regulatory T-cells that suppress immune responses.
PD-L1 and PD-L2 enhance the production of cytokines that activate the immune system to destroy tumor cells.
PD-L1 and PD-L2 are upregulated by PD-1 receptor activation, which prevents T-cell recognition of tumor antigens.

questions.text: A patient with lung cancer is treated with PD-1 inhibitors as part of their immunotherapy regimen. The tumor's ability to evade the immune system is primarily through the upregulation of PD-L1 and PD-L2. What is the underlying role of these factors in immune evasion?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) PD-L1 and PD-L2 prevent the activation of T-cells by binding to PD-1 receptors on T-cells.

 

  • PD-L1 and PD-L2 are upregulated on tumor cells and interact with the PD-1 receptors on T-cells. 
  • This binding inhibits T-cell activation, allowing the tumor to escape immune detection. 
  • In this way, PD-L1 and PD-L2 contribute to immune evasion by preventing T-cells from recognizing and attacking tumor cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. PD-L1 and PD-L2 promote the differentiation of T-cells into regulatory T-cells that suppress immune responses: Incorrect. While regulatory T-cells may suppress the immune response, PD-L1 and PD-L2 do not promote their differentiation; they act directly to inhibit T-cell activation.

 

Option C. PD-L1 and PD-L2 enhance the production of cytokines that activate the immune system to destroy tumor cells: Incorrect. PD-L1 and PD-L2 inhibit immune activation by binding to PD-1, not promoting cytokine production.

 

Option D. PD-L1 and PD-L2 are upregulated by PD-1 receptor activation, which prevents T-cell recognition of tumor antigens: Incorrect. PD-1 receptor activation leads to immune suppression, not the upregulation of PD-L1 and PD-L2.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PD-L1 and PD-L2 contribute to immune evasion by inhibiting T-cell activation via their binding to PD-1 receptors on T-cells.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is diagnosed with dermatomyositis. Which of the following is the most likely associated finding in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Calcinosis

 

  • Juvenile dermatomyositis commonly presents with calcinosis (calcium deposits in the skin and soft tissues) as a major complication. 
  • The age of onset is typically around 7 years. The prognosis is generally better compared to adult dermatomyositis, but calcinosis is a distinctive finding in these patients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Underlying malignancy: Incorrect. Underlying malignancy is more commonly associated with adult dermatomyositis, with 15-25% of cases showing a link to malignancy.

 

Option C. Myositis-specific antibodies: Incorrect. Myositis-specific antibodies are more frequently observed in adult dermatomyositis, especially with malignancy.

 

Option D. Cardiac involvement: Incorrect. Cardiac involvement is more frequently seen in adult dermatomyositis, particularly in cases with malignancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Juvenile dermatomyositis is commonly associated with calcinosis and typically has a better prognosis compared to adult dermatomyositis.

choices.text: The BCG vaccine has high efficacy in preventing pulmonary TB in adults.
The BCG vaccine provides 80% efficacy against miliary TB and meningeal TB in children.
The BCG vaccine is effective for lifetime against all forms of TB.
The BCG vaccine has zero efficacy against meningeal TB.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the efficacy of the BCG vaccine is correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The BCG vaccine provides 80% efficacy against miliary TB and meningeal TB in children.

 

  • The BCG vaccine has a median efficacy of 50% but offers 0-80% efficacy in preventing miliary TB and meningeal TB in children, particularly in regions with high TB burden. 
  • It does not provide protection against pulmonary TB.

 

Other Options:

Option A. The BCG vaccine has high efficacy in preventing pulmonary TB in adults: Incorrect. The BCG vaccine has limited efficacy for pulmonary TB.
 

Option C. The BCG vaccine is effective for lifetime against all forms of TB: Incorrect. The BCG vaccine does not provide lifetime protection and has variable efficacy.


Option D. The BCG vaccine has zero efficacy against meningeal TB: Incorrect. The BCG vaccine is effective in preventing meningeal TB in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The BCG vaccine provides limited protection against pulmonary TB but is effective against miliary TB and meningeal TB in children.

choices.text: Stop surgery immediately and administer general anesthesia reversal agents.
Stop anesthesia and start calcium gluconate for hyperkalemia.
Administer 100% oxygen, give dantrolene sodium, and initiate cooling measures.
Begin rapid cooling measures and administer sedatives.

questions.text: What is the immediate management for malignant hyperthermia in a patient under general anesthesia?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer 100% oxygen, give dantrolene sodium, and initiate cooling measures.

 

  • Malignant hyperthermia requires immediate cessation of triggering agents, oxygen, and dantrolene to counteract muscle rigidity and hyperthermia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stop surgery immediately and administer general anesthesia reversal agents: Reversal agents are not primary management for malignant hyperthermia.

 

Option B. Stop anesthesia and start calcium gluconate for hyperkalemia: Calcium gluconate treats hyperkalemia but is secondary management.

 

Option D. Begin rapid cooling measures and administer sedatives: Cooling alone is insufficient without dantrolene.

 

Educational Objective:
 

  • Malignant hyperthermia management involves stopping triggering agents, administering 100% oxygen, and giving dantrolene sodium.
